The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Michael Beahan)

talk.start.para: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

petition.title: Census
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned shows:
That the current practice of destroying the Census is denying future generations an invaluable and irreplaceable resource of data on medical, historical, social, scientific, and demographic factors.
Your Petitioners request that the Senate should:

Request the Government to review its current policy of destroying the Census; and support a proposal to retain the census forms for release for specific research purposes in either 70 or 100 years time.

petition.title: National Flag
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

para.tab: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth
That the majority of Australians clearly stand united in satisfaction with their existing Australian National Flag which reflects their values, history and heritage.
And that they condemn unwarranted attacks on their historic Australian Flag, whenever or wherever made by any Australian citizens.

So therefore do we call upon the Senate to ensure that the Australian National Flag, as publicly acclaimed in 1901 and confirmed under the Flags Act (1953) is not changed, replaced or diminished at any time, or in any manner whatsoever without such a proposal being first voted upon and approved by a majority of Australian citizens in a national referendum.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

petition.title: Eastlink
petition.para: The undersigned citizens petition the Senate of the Australian Parliament requesting the establishment of an all party Senate Inquiry into Eastlink, the proposed connection to the National Grid and associated decision making processes.

para.tab: Eastlink,
1. Is contrary to the recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology in their 1992 Report, titled Gas and Electricity.

2. Is proceeding without proper comparison of other options for meeting Queensland's future energy needs. There has been no proper comparison of impacts on rural productivity, economic, environment, health, development or lifestyles issues.
3. Work on Eastlink easement acquisition occurred prior to parliamentary or public debate on the options for Queensland.
4. Eastlink itself will not be adequate for Interstate trading and would entail considerable further upgrading and expenditure on additional High Voltage Lines and switching station.

speech.para: If it is the wish of the Senate that I give a brief explanation in relation to that, I will be happy to do so.

talk.start.para: —I agree that it would be appropriate for Senator Faulkner to make a brief explanation. If he seeks leave, I am sure the Senate will agree.
—I would never pre-empt the Senate. I seek leave to make such a brief statement.

para.tab: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —These three bills, in each case, are bills which were introduced into the House of Representatives last year. They, however, are bills that have come into the Senate in this sitting. This means that they have, in fact, technically breached the cut-off motion, but I make the point that, because of their introduction into the House of Representatives last year, they have now received significant scrutiny from senators.

para.tab: These three bills fall into a category, as I am sure senators would be aware, that has been of some concern to the government. There have been discussions with the opposition, the minor parties and the Independent in the Senate in relation to this anomaly, and I believe it is an anomaly. I think it is an unintended consequence, in that sense, of the cut-off motion. We are planning to progress those discussions, and senators would be aware of a notice of motion that has been put down to deal with this issue.

I do not believe it was the intention of the Senate when the cut-off motion was originally proposed to see bills in this category—those that had been introduced into the House of Representatives—caught up by the cut-off motion in this way. Anyway, that is a matter that obviously the Senate will look at in due course, and I intend to have further discussions with senators about that.

However, in particular, there has been consultation with all senators and parties in the chamber about these three bills proceeding in this way. Obviously, the government would be pleased to receive the support of the Senate to ensure that they can be dealt with, given the fact that they have now been available for the perusal of senators for some considerable time.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I will make a very brief statement about this matter. It would not be brief if I were to canvass the matters that have been raised by Senator Faulkner. I do not accept the proposition he has put forward that this was an unintended consequence—but more of that later. I am prepared to argue that at any time.

para.tab: I am grateful that the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Faulkner) has made a statement to the Senate in respect of these three bills, and I will be supporting the motion that they be exempted from the cut-off. I will have more to say on the other debate later. But I emphasise the fact that I do not believe that this was an unintended consequence, as expressed by Senator Faulkner.

debate.title: BILLS RETURNED FROM THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES

debate.title: CLASSIFICATION (PUBLICATIONS, FILMS AND COMPUTER GAMES) BILL 1994

para.tab:
Debate resumed from 1 March, on motion by
Senator McMullan
:
That this bill be now read a second time.

speech.speaker: Harradine Sen B.

talk.start.para: —The Senate is dealing with the Classification (Publications, Films and Computer Games) Bill 1994. Before I refer in principle to that bill, I want first of all to refer to what was said last night in the chamber by Senator Chamarette. I understand that the matters to which she referred are ones which have been around the place for a considerable number of years. I thought the type of material that was advanced by Senator Chamarette in support of the suggestion being made about an NVE category had well and truly been canvassed before. Those who have been promoters of that have been well and truly identified as having an interest in that particular endeavour, if I can call it such.

para.tab: It is important for the Senate to know a few facts. I understand and admit that it is not the view of Senator Chamarette, in advancing the proposition that has been advanced principally by the pornography industry itself, the X-rated video industry itself, that there be a NVE classification and that all material currently in the X category go into the NVE category. But that is the view that has been expressed by the X-rated video materials industry. In justification for that, it is indicating three things: firstly, the material in the X category is not violent; secondly, the material is not harmful; and, thirdly, there are eminent persons, such as Dr Paul Wilson, who believe that this material should be classified as NVE.

Let me deal first of all with the latter proposition in respect of Dr Paul Wilson. Senator Chamarette referred to the newsletter
Australian Institute of Criminology: Trends and Issues No. 9
of December 1987 in support of what she was saying. That issue indicated that there had been a study completed by the institute about this matter. In subsequent examinations of Dr Wilson and the Institute of Criminology, it was found that the study was a search of the literature. It did not conduct any in-depth study at all.

The article was by Dr Paul Wilson and Mr Stephen Nugent. Dr Paul Wilson, in that article, relied upon, to some extent, arguments against the findings of the Meese Commission. The Meese Commission, the United States commission into prostitution and pornography ordered by US Attorney-General Meese, found that material of a similar character to that which is contained in the X category has harmful effects. Dr Wilson attacked that as being unfounded and used as his support for that attack Messrs Nobile and Nadler. It is all footnoted in the paper
Australian Institute of Criminology: Trends and Issues No. 9
. What is not footnoted, however, is who Nobile and Nadler were. Philip Nobile was at that time the editorial director of
Penthouse Forum
in the United States and Eric Nadler was its senior editorial director. Very impartial people, I would have thought, for an academic in the Institute of Criminology to rely upon in support of what he was saying! So I think that is pretty well dead and buried.

The second point goes to the question of harm. The Joint Select Committee on Video Materials discussed this matter quite substantially over a long period. Prior to that, the Senate Select Committee on Video Materials had done so. We received evidence to the effect that the habitual viewing of the type of material that is contained in the X category engenders a callous and manipulative orientation towards women. Quite an amount of evidence was given to us and to subsequent hearings, which is to be found in the archives of the committee. Those who suggested that there was no such effect included Robby Swan, the lobbyist for the X-rated pornography industry. That same person is not beyond some dissembling. He has been saying over a period of time that this material is not directed at the male population and does not objectify women; that it is also aimed at women—that they love it. This has been his approach for some considerable time.

I was interested to see in what I thought to be a serious journal—which turned out to have been conned—a statement by a Caroline Sweetly. She said that the material has a wide distribution amongst married people and is desired by women. A photograph of this Caroline Sweetly accompanied the article. I thought: I have seen her somewhere before. I asked a question in a meeting of the Senate Select Committee on Community Standards, inquiring into the standards relevant to the supply of services utilised in telecommunications technology, on 20 April 1993 of Mr Swan about Caroline Sweetly. He eventually admitted that it was his photograph—he was dressed up as Caroline Sweetly. It was
B and T
magazine, page 19, of 17 August 1990. He is there attempting to deceive the readers of
B and T Weekly
with this sort of material.

talk.start.para: —Are you telling me it was a man dressed up as a woman?

—Yes, and
B and T Weekly
fell for it. The credibility of these people is pathetic.

para.tab: I am not suggesting that Senator Margetts would be involved in any of this. Of course she would not. The first matter she raised related to the type of material that is contained in X-rated material being non-violent. It could possibly be physically non-violent. As I have said, I have seen much of this X-rated material. It may be physically non-violent to a certain extent, but one I can remember was on the borderline of being forced sexual intimacy. I outlined yesterday what the joint select committee described this material as. The committee report stated at paragraph 13.46:

speech.para: The dominant theme of the material is that it objectifies and commodifies women rather than treating women as free and responsible initiators of human activity. The material in this category, although non-violent, treats women as sexual commodities to arouse the sexual desires of its target audience. Thus sexual intercourse is typically depicted as a mechanical act devoid of love or human consequences—fellatio and cunnilingus are explicitly and voyeuristically portrayed as is masturbation, ejaculation, penetration of the female anus and diverse acts, other acts or fetishes.
I will not go into what it contains. It goes on to say in paragraph 13.49:

Women are often depicted as sexually malleable for the purposes of satisfying male sexual desires. This is sometimes manifested in themes involving workplace sexual favours. Women are frequently depicted as eager for sexual experience of any kind and ever ready for an opportunity for sexual activity. This is frequently manifested in the group sex scenes depicting diverse sexual activity, which are a feature of much of the material in this category.

I think it is important that the Senate understand what we are talking about and understand also that the material is not innocuous. My view is that it is the themes, as much as the explicit depictions, that are of concern. It is the themes that tend to engender a callous and manipulative orientation towards other human beings. That is one of the major problems. It is those themes that are included in much of the R material. A lot of the R material is exactly the same in content, intent, theme and title as the X equivalent. That is a matter that the Senate also needs to be aware of.

para.tab:
Much has been said about the film
Salo
. I went to the theatre and saw that film. I do not see how the producer of that film,
Salo
, could see that as an appropriate way to express oneself. I admit that you have to have a balance between the rights of persons to freedom of expression and the rights of others in the community. Normally speaking I would go down heavily on the side of the rights to freedom of expression, but this material acts the same way as racial vilification does. It vilifies a whole section of the community and portrays that section of the community as highly promiscuous and available. That is the message that comes across.

As to
Salo
, yes, I did see it. I viewed the film with part of my mind on the guidelines and the other part on the film itself, and I tried to work out how this film could possibly fit within the current R guidelines. I came to the conclusion that it could not. The description of the material is, I think, in our report; certainly, it is in
Hansard
, so I will not describe it now. It was a maniacal film—I suppose that is the only description that one can use.

In any event, under the existing provisions of the law, the Film Censorship Board can do something about it now. Its two years is up. I hope the board takes that under consideration because I will be asking the question in the committee stage. Perhaps the board should go back to the books and look at the timing. However, they are really digressions. That is not what I wanted to talk about. I was answering as to the matters that have come before the board, and I have only two minutes now to talk about this measure.

The measure before us consists of three elements: the provision for determining the standards against which publications, films and computer games are to be classified; the provision for an organisation to classify them; and the provision for laws that regulate the distribution and possession of publications. It relies on three elements: the first element is the national classification code; the second element is the creation of a body to apply the classification criteria; and the third element is to be carried out by the states and territories—that is, in regard to the question of distribution and possession or otherwise. In the committee stage, I will be asking questions about those matters. Because I had to answer some of the other matters, the committee stage might go on a little longer.

speech.speaker: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

talker.name: Senator BOSWELL
talker.role: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

talk.start.para: —The Senate is debating the Classification (Publications, Films and Computer Games) Bill 1994. Whilst I have not gone into this piece of legislation in great depth, this debate gives me an opportunity to put some comments on the record on matters that have concerned me and that I have pursued in the estimates committee.

para.tab:
On 17 November last year, I raised the case of a computer art display which contained graphic descriptions of violent child sexual abuse. This matter was raised in the
Courier-Mail
and concerned a child of seven printing out some very explicit information from a computer display. The computer art was on display at the Great Australian Science Show in Brisbane. This seven-year-old boy printed out two pages of it.

During the estimates committee hearings which dealt with the Attorney-General's Department, I was assured that this bill now before the Senate would prevent child pornography, abuse and gratuitous violence being displayed and created on computers. I sincerely hope that this bill will do all those things once it is enacted by all the states. But I think it raises a fundamental question: if government departments can give out taxpayers' money to fund a pornographic computer display accessible by children, has the horse already bolted with regard to classifying computer material?

On 29 November last I pursued the matter of the computer art display in questions. After chasing the answers for nearly three months—they were straightforward questions—they finally arrived in my office yesterday afternoon. The answers given by the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Mr Lee) raise fundamental concerns about the efficacy of the bill we have before us today. The minister did say he was concerned about the display, but if the government does not know when it has funded computer pornography how can we as a society hope to contain the offensive and obscene side of the great communication advances that are already around us?

talk.start.para:
—It funds
Cleo
.

—Senator Abetz raises a very significant point. If we are genuinely concerned about computer pornography, we have to have a commitment that extends beyond a classification scheme such as that we see before us today. The minister's answers to my questions indicate to me that the commitment is not being pursued with any efficiency in the arts and communication portfolio. I seek leave to incorporate my questions and the minister's answers to them in
Hansard
.

para.tab: Leave granted.

The document read as follows
—

speech.para: DEPARTMENT OF COMMUNICATIONS AND THE ARTS
Subprogram 3.1—Australian Cultural Development Office
Senator Boswell asked the following Question on Notice:

1. It has been reported in the Courier Mail today that the Federal Government gave a $25,000 grant to the Adelaide-based group Australian Network of Artists and Technology under the Visions for Australia program.
Is this correct? When was the grant paid? What was the grant paid for?
2. What guidelines are there for making these grants?

3. This grant was used by a Linda Dement to create a computer display called Artists Thinking about Art and Australia. According to the Courier Mail (17th November) it depicted graphic descriptions of a woman cutting off a child's penis and rubbing it over the child's body while he cried out in pain and then described in detail how the woman sexually abused the child. A 7 year old boy was able to print out several pages of the text at the display.
Is this sort of display an appropriate Vision for Australia? Aren't the applications vetted in some way? Who made the decision to spend taxpayers money on this group?
The Director of the group, David O'Halloran, was quoted as saying that he was not worried that children would see the display.
What else has this group received government funding for? Will they continue to receive it? What advice has been given to make sure these displays are censored and classified?
1. The grant was made on 18 August 1994. It was to assist the applicant to tour the exhibition `Artists thinking about Science' in Melbourne, Sydney and Brisbane.
2. The guidelines for assessment of the application by the Visions of Australia Committee are attached.
3. I am concerned that a work as described would be included in an exhibition and have written to the Chair of the Visions of Australia Committee seeking a full investigation of the grant.

Applications are assessed by the Visions of Australia Committee on the basis of the attached guidelines. Applicants submit information on the theme and contents of the proposed exhibition but are not required to submit details of individual works to be included in the exhibition, and none were submitted with this application. The grant was approved by the Minister on the basis of the Committee's recommendation.

This has been the only grant paid to the Australian Network for Art and Technology under the Visions of Australia program. The Australian Network for Art and Technology has also received assistance from the Australia Council for its general administration and operating costs and program since 1986-87. Since 1991 it has administered an Art Research and Development Fund (being a grant fund for artists).

An application for assistance submitted to the Visions of Australia program in a future grant round would be assessed by the Committee having regard to the guidelines for the program and to the performance of the applicant in relation to previous grants.
Censorship of non-electronic media is the responsibility of State and Territory Governments.

talk.start.para: —The minister for the arts confirms in that answer that a $25,000 grant was given by the government to the Australian Network for Art and Technology for the computer art display in Brisbane. The minister adds:

speech.para: I am concerned that a work as described would be included in an exhibition and have written to the Chair of the Visions of Australia Committee seeking a full investigation of the grant.

The Visions of Australia committee gave $25,000 to a group so that it could come up with a computer display which depicted violent child sexual abuse as part of a public exhibition, which a seven-year-old child was able to not only access but also print out. Every family in Australia would share the minister's concern, I am sure, at such a gross misuse of taxpayers' money. Not only should the whole process of grant assessment be investigated as promised by the minister, but the minister should also investigate in great detail all the activities of the group responsible, the Australian Network for Art and Technology. The group's director, Mr David Halloran, was quoted in the
Courier-Mail
last November as saying that he was not worried that children would see the display. He said:
It's quite an intellectual piece of work. It's not really intended for children.

That may be the case but, nevertheless, it was able to be accessed by a seven-year-old child. I defy any parent in Australia to see the art and accept the justification of a $25,000 government grant in the display provided by this group. The display was named `Artists thinking about science' and the grant made on 18 August 1994 was to assist in touring the exhibition to Melbourne, Sydney and Brisbane. The group, as we see from the minister's answer today, has been receiving public funding from the Australia Council since 1986-87. Since 1991, it has itself administered an art research and development fund.

para.tab: In the committee stage I will ask the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner) to provide details of all the public funding obtained by the Australian Network for Art and Technology and the qualifications, expertise and background of the principals of the group to be permitted to not only receive money themselves but also, in another position, give it out to others. If the minister is listening to me, he may be able to get his advisers to get those answers ready for the committee debate.

The assessment guidelines and processes are obviously not working. In May 1994 the Minister for Communications and the Arts, Mr Lee, announced grants for the visions of Australia touring program. He said:

speech.para: We want to ensure that all Australians, regardless of where they live, gain greater access to the treasures the nation holds.

Surely the minister does not believe that this sort of computer display is a national treasure. I will call on Senator Faulkner to advise the national parliament when Mr Lee wrote to the vision of Australia committee seeking a full investigation of the grant and when he expects a reply and whether the Australian Network for Art and Technology still owes its existence to the generosity of the Australian taxpayer. I will also ask the minister in the committee stage to justify taking three months to answer my simple, straightforward question regarding the grant. I reiterate: if a government department is a party, unwitting or otherwise, to the display of pornographic material, how can we expect this bill to solve the problem?

speech.speaker: Cooney Sen B.C.

talk.start.para: —I want to make some remarks in the context of the Classification (Publications, Films and Computer Games) Bill 1994, which is now before the chamber. I want to say this: you can have the very best system in the world but if it does not have the proper people running it it will be in trouble; you can have a fairly ordinary system but if you have the right people in charge it will work reasonably well—it will work very well, as a matter of fact.

para.tab: A lot of the debate that goes on in this area really depends upon what you make of the decision makers. The difficulty in this area comes from the fact that some people think a decision made by a particular decision maker is good while others say it is not. It is a very emotional area.

To illustrate this, one of the great classic statements on what is obscene followed a decision made by Mr Hicklin and another in a case back in 1867. Senator Harradine would know that. I do not suggest for one minute, Madam Acting Deputy President, that you would remember that case, but it is a very interesting one. The Lord Chief Justice Cockburn in hearing an appeal from the decision in 1868 said:

speech.para: . . . and I think the test of obscenity is this, whether the tendency of the matter charged as obscenity is to deprave and corrupt those whose minds are open to such immoral influences, and into whose hands a publication of this sort may fall.

Everybody would agree with that; I take it there would be general agreement upon it, in any event. Having stated the principle that everybody might well agree with, it then becomes an issue as to whether the particular matter before the decision-make is obscene.

para.tab:
That is the point at which greater motions flow. The case involving Mr Hicklin is a great illustration of that. The work that was alleged to be obscene was entitled
The Confessional Unmasked showing the depravity of the Romish priesthood, the iniquity of the confessional and the questions put to females in confession
. Being of the true faith, I would have taken the matter no further than gaol him for some time for writing such material.

talk.start.para: —You should have been dumped for blasphemous libel.

—Yes. The appellant—the person who wrote this—is Henry Scott. The report says that he was a metal broker residing in the town of Wolverhampton. He was a person of respectable position and character. He was a member of a body styled as the Protestant Electoral Union. His work was put out to put Romish forces to flight. It was not suggested that he did this for obscene purposes. Nevertheless, all the judges held the work to be obscene.

para.tab: Mr Justice Mellor had this to say in the report:

speech.para: The nature of the subject itself, if it may be discussed at all (and I think it undoubtedly may)—
in other words, there has to be discussion about the issues that Mr Scott raised—

is such that it cannot be discussed without to a certain extent producing authorities for the assertion that the confessional would be a mischievous thing to be introduced into this kingdom; and therefore it appears to me very much a question of degree, and if the matter were left to the jury it would depend very much on the opinion which the jury might form of that degree in such a publication as the present. Now, I take it for granted that the magistrates themselves were perfectly satisfied that this work went far beyond anything which was necessary or legitimate for the purpose of attacking the confessional.

The point is that somebody has to make that decision in the context where emotions run high. It seems to me that the people who make those decisions are often unjustly criticised for doing a job that somebody has to do. Nobody for one minute disagrees that there ought to be some sort of censorship and system which distinguishes those matters that may be shown, heard, listened to or felt from those that should not.

para.tab:
Senator Harradine interjecting
—

talk.start.para: —No. I am directing this short talk to the issue of the way that we treat those who make the decisions. My proposition is that they perform a very difficult task in carrying out an essential function. If people are going to be appointed to positions where they have to make these decisions, we should, as it were, give them a fair go.

para.tab:
An illustration of how decision makers can be criticised unfairly appears in an editorial in the
Sydney Morning Herald
. It talks about Mr Frederick Glen Many who has been released according to the law and whose release people are now criticising in the context of an election campaign. It is all very good to run law and order campaigns, but if those law and order campaigns start reducing our civil rights and the respect we should have for institutions, then I think that is a case for alarm.

The editorial on page 14 of the
Sydney Morning Herald
goes through some of these arguments for and against. The article concludes:

speech.para: These, however, are small points compared with the courts' failure to deal with this case in a way that sees the punishment fit the crime.

I think it is proper to make criticism of decision makers. But, on the other hand, when we do that, we start reducing, in my view, the strength that those decision makers might have and the force with which they might go about their task.

para.tab: There is always a great problem in deciding what is right and what is wrong. What are community values to some groups are community prejudices to others. The question we have to ask ourselves is: are these decision makers being given a fair go to distinguish what are community values to be upheld and what are community prejudices which should not be given way to even if they are held by a considerable number of people in the community?

The debate in this chamber often come down to finding a mistake that particular people or groups have made and then saying that they are evil, wrong, corrupt or not up to the task. St James's epistle in the
Bible
reads:

speech.para: Brothers, don't be too eager to tell others their faults. We all make many mistakes.

That quote could be read again and again. It was not only St James who had something to say about it. So did William Shakespeare in the play
The Winter's Tale
, which I know you, Madam Acting Deputy President, have read on many an occasion. Leontes was berating his servant Camillo. Leontes got a bit upset because he thought his wife was unfaithful to him, which was a wrong perception. Nevertheless, he went off and did some awful things. But, in answer to Leontes's taxing him for what he had done wrong, Camillo said:
I may be negligent, foolish and fearful;
In every one of these no man is free . . .
Even women would be that way. But, in those days, even with the liberal mind of William Shakespeare, equality of sexes had not found its way to the fore. Camillo went on to say:
These—
he was talking about the various faults he had—
my lord,
Are such allow'd infirmities that honesty
Is never free of.

With all the changes to be made in this area, we should remember the people who have to make this system and any system work. We have been very well served up until now, and I hope into the future, by the people who run our censorship system. I have heard some films mentioned in this chamber. Senator Harradine mentioned
Salo
. I have not seen it; perhaps I should. I am willing to concede for the purpose of argument that it is a very nasty film. I am willing to concede for the purpose of this argument that it should not have been released.

para.tab:
In fact I noticed that the Film Censorship Board did not release
Salo
. It was released on appeal. I am willing to admit that the Film and Literature Board of Review members should not have released it. I then say: so what? What do you conclude from that? Do you conclude that they made a mistake? And they very well may have made a mistake. One film or even six films hardly show a course of conduct that ought to be brought against the people who fill these boards to show that they should be driven, as it were, into eternal darkness.

I would suggest that everybody who has had anything to do with Mr Dickie, for example, who is our chief censor, would regard him as having done outstanding work in this area. I notice there is nobody presently in the chamber who would disagree with that—Senator Harradine, Senator O'Chee, Senator Ian Macdonald and Senator Herron. Ms Wright has nobly done the task we set her and so has Peter Mackay and so on. I think Senator Harradine no doubt would agree with me that to err is human and that is the condition we are all in.

talk.start.para: —Very rarely in your case, senator.
—Very rarely but even members of this chamber can make the odd mistake. Given the fact—

—They were on different sides on the
Salo
issue—the chief censor and Ms Wright.

—That is what I am saying. I am willing to concede for the purpose of this argument that the people who let
Salo
in were wrong.
—One of whom was not Mr Dickie.

—I know. As I said before, Mr Dickie did not want to let it in. I think he is probably anti-Italian but, leaving that aside, he did not want to let it in. All I am saying is, even if there are one or two instances where films were let in, so what? All that says is that mistakes can be made. I was reading from the
Bible
and Shakespeare to show that you cannot condemn a particular group or a particular person on the basis of even a dozen errors. They do not say that in those terms but that is the thrust of it. You have to look at the course of conduct.

para.tab: When you get into this area, which is a very emotional area, and so it should be because it is a very emotional subject, there is a tendency for people who make the decisions to oftentimes most unfairly be in the firing line. I am sorry for hitting the microphone with a piece of paper and making a terrible noise. That is a mistake I have made, but I should not be thrown out of the Senate for making that mistake.

talk.start.para: —That is the first one you've made this sitting.

—And I should not be thrown out of the Senate because I made it. We should remember the situation in which we put people who have to censor these things. I want to put on the record that it is my belief that the Film Censorship Board, so ably led by Mr Dickie, has performed an outstanding function over the years and I think it needs praise. The Film and Literature Board of Review—
—Did you say they needed prayer?

—No, needed praise. We all need prayer. I went to the ceremonies yesterday—I hope you went to the ceremonies yesterday, Senator Harradine; I did not notice any ashes on your forehead this morning. The Film Censorship Board needs praise and so does the Film and Literature Board of Review. Poor Mr Dickie. I have known him for many years now. He has suffered with the stress of having to make these decisions. I just want to say that Mr Dickie has done a good job. I see Mr Reaburn in the advisers' area, too. He has done an excellent job in the Attorney-General's Department.

para.tab: I see the Minister representing the Attorney-General (Senator Bolkus) is in the chamber, and I want to know why we are letting so much of the work which was formerly done by the Attorney-General's Department go out to private practitioners. But I think that is straying from the topic, so I will conclude on that point.

talk.start.para: —Mr Acting Deputy President, may I at the outset thank you for occupying the chair at such short notice. I was supposed to be there, but I wish to speak on the Classification (Publications, Films and Computer Games) Bill 1994. I want to bring to the notice of the Senate an official government publication that is not covered by the Classification (Publications, Films and Computer Games) Bill.

para.tab: Where do we go when we get an X-rated, pornographic government publication that is put out by the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) which advocates deviant sexual practices and is not, as she says in the preamble to it, a non-judgmental resource. This so-called safe sex guide is an official government publication, endorsed by the government, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the health minister. It is X-rated and pornographic, and any right-minded person—even Mr Dickie, as I know—would classify it as unsuitable for publication, but it is on the bookstands of this country and can be bought by any 13-year-old child. As the Minister for Family Service (Senator Crowley), who represents the Minister for Human Services and Health, said in debate, it is read by 13-year-olds, although it is aimed at those aged 18 years and above. There are nearly five million females aged 13 years and over in this country.

I have spoken out about this. It is interesting that, since I have spoken about it and my telephone number was published in Saturday's
Courier-Mail
, I received 2,500 telephone calls on Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday asking me to submit petitions. I have on record the names and addresses of people who want to speak out because they are so enraged at this attack on the morals, as well as the health aspects, of this publication. This is an official government publication. It is full of lies. The publication states that between 40 and 60 per cent of women in this country have anal sex. This is an official government publication.

Mr Acting Deputy President, you may not be aware that for 35 years I have been a colorectal surgeon and a member of the Colorectal Society of Australia of the Royal Australasian College of Surgeons. My practice has been in colorectal surgery. I have treated many AIDS patients. I have treated many active homosexual patients.

The damage that occurs through this deviant practice is unimaginable, and we have the government advocating it as normal heterosexual behaviour. I know that you, Mr Acting Deputy President, would be appalled at this interpretation, but it is a correct interpretation. If you do not believe me, I will send you a copy of that guide. I am happy to send a copy to anybody who is here and wants to see it. I am, in fact, working for the department of health and its minister, Dr Lawrence. I am spreading that publication throughout Australia so that citizens can read it for themselves and form their own opinion.

I have received support. I have also written to the churches on this because it is not my place as a politician to speak about morals. That is another aspect. I am not resiling from speaking about morals. I have taken moral positions on many occasions throughout my life. But somewhere in one's life one has to draw the line in the sand—and this is it. I can tell you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that that Minister for Human Services and Health, who endorsed this guide, is going to feel the wrath of the Australian population on this particular aspect. I have received 2,500 calls in the three days since my number has been published.

The Minister for Human Services and Health yesterday misled the House of Representatives: she said that 10 to 15 per cent of women at some stage have anal sex. I do not like talking on these topics, but when a deliberate untruth is told in another chamber I think it must be nailed. I have researched this aspect for over 12 months because I am also a member of the Parliamentary AIDS Liaison Committee. The only research that we on the Parliamentary AIDS Liaison Committee have been able to find which has been carried out in Australia is an Australian Family Planning Association questionnaire. That questionnaire was answered by 1,162 women out of a total of 7,000 women who attended the Australian Family Association clinics in 1993. It was obviously a skewed sample because it is not the average suburban housewife who goes to the Australian Family Planning Association. But, given that, 1,162 women answered this questionnaire.

The questionnaire was devised to ask, `Have you had anal sex with your most recent steady'—not your spouse but your most recent steady—`or with a non-steady male?' Of these 1,162 women, 66 said that they had; 70 per cent said that no condom had been used; 13 per cent said that they had used a condom; and the rest—surprise—did not know. The point I make is that that is roughly about five per cent of a skewed sample.

That was the only piece of Australian research that had been done, apart from that in another publication where the AIDS organisation had come out and said that 30 per cent of women had had anal sex. To get on to that piece of research, a person had to reply to an advertisement in the
Kings Cross Whisper
. Sixty-three women replied to that advertisement, of which one-third had had four separate partners in the previous week—so they had been promiscuous in their behaviour. Another third who replied were actually `sex workers'. That was your 15 to 30 per cent.

The minister came out yesterday and said it is between 10 and 15 per cent. I put out a public challenge to her to justify those figures. Also in the endorsement of this publication she said that it was done on a non-judgemental resource and that the reason the AIDS epidemic had been stemmed in Australia was because of public knowledge of practices.

But anyone who knows anything about the AIDS epidemic will know that the reason it has been stemmed in Australia is because AIDS did not get into the intravenous drug using community in this country, as it has in every other country in the world—but I repeat: it has not in Australia. Most commentators believe that is due to the needle exchange program. It was a very good act on the part of the government to institute that first in the world. I have examined other countries where drug use is common, and we have led the world in that needle exchange program. That is the reason for the stemming of the AIDS epidemic. It has also been stemmed through behaviour modification of homosexuals who indulge in anal sex.

Ninety-five per cent of AIDS in this country is due to anal sex between homosexuals—and nobody would doubt that at all. What this publication does is advocate it as a normal heterosexual activity. That in turn can do nothing but increase not only the infectious diseases but also damages to things such as the anus, the anal sphincter, the rectum and the anatomical parts.

I am appalled. I put the minister on notice that there is a wave of revulsion about an official government publication which is not covered by classification. I have learnt something from my friend and colleague Senator Baume: for three years he has been pursuing a subject, and I will pursue this subject. It will not go away. I have already mentioned to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that I have written to the church leaders in this country. I am already getting replies of support. Three bodies shortly are going to come out publicly: the Jewish board of deputies, the Baptist church and the Lutheran church. I have also had a letter of support from the Catholic Archbishop in Queensland.

The Labor Party stands condemned on this—and it will know it. I have been approached by some of my Labor colleagues and friends in the government who support me in this. But the Labor Party will have to resile from this publication because there will be an enormous backlash. Do not underestimate it. It will occur. I will make it occur, if nobody else does, and in that I have powerful support.

Another aspect is that the Prime Minister has come out and said that he wants another television station for family matters. This publication is the most anti-family document we will ever read. If people doubt me, they should read it. Read it, Senator Cook, and form your own opinion. It is anti-family. It destroys the basis of what we are promoting in our community as a whole.

I know that many of my Labor colleagues support me on this. So a backlash will occur. The official government publication is not covered by this bill, and there is a defect in it. Certainly, if this classification bill were correct that X-rated, pornographic, sadomasochistic publication would not be on this country's bookstands today.

talk.start.para: —I share Senator Herron's concerns about the publication in question, and I commend him for the good work he has done. However, I rise to speak on a different issue in relation to the Classification (Publications, Films and Computer Games) Bill 1994, and it relates to violence in films, on television and in computer games.

para.tab: I know that the bill does not deal with television. However, I have some concerns about equal treatment of material on television compared with material which is in videos, in films or in computer material. It is a shame that my friend on the other side of the chamber, Senator Cooney, is not here at this moment because Senator Cooney and I sat through some hearings last year in relation to the broadcasting of material on television, particularly on news and current affairs programs, and I know Senator Cooney shares my concerns about the sort of material which is broadcast on news programs and on current affairs programs.

I give two examples of my concern. I think you, Mr Acting Deputy President, would understand what I mean when I say that there needs to be some sort of consistency. Last year—in fact, I think it was the night before a hearing of the Senate legal and constitutional committee in Sydney on this matter—I watched a program on Channel 10 entitled
Cops
. It was a quite entertaining program. I have seen it on a number of occasions. It involved people with cameras riding around in police cars in the United States filming police officers going about their work.

As I said, normally this program is quite entertaining. However, on this particular evening in question what was shown was the body of a man who was discovered murdered in New Mexico. There were some fairly detailed close-up pictures of the man's body and of his face. From recollection, the man had been killed by being beaten over the head three times with a concrete block, having a glass bottle broken over his head and then being run over whilst he was lying on the ground. His whole body, including the tyre marks and abrasions about the head, were shown. His face was also shown.

That was a program from the United States which was broadcast here. I am concerned that that program was broadcast as it was because I do not believe that that was satisfactory viewing, even at that hour of night. But I would have been even more concerned if it had been an Australian program which was broadcast because of course there would have been a greater likelihood of family and friends being offended by the broadcast. No effort was made to block out the man's face or obscure it in any fashion whatsoever.

There is an interesting end to that story. A week or two after that program went to air, I remember discussing it with Mr George Chapman of Channel 10. I told him that I felt that that program was a little beyond the pale and that maybe some efforts ought to be taken to ensure that that sort of program does not go to air again. I was very pleased to see that the program was removed straightaway from Channel 10's screenings. I do not know whether or not that was due to Mr Chapman's efforts. If it was, I congratulate him because it really was unsatisfactory. As I said, most of the episodes of that program were not terribly offensive but that one quite clearly was.

On Tuesday night ABC television showed a program in which there was some detailed examination of an assassination which occurred in Mexico some time ago in which a politician was shot at close range. It showed film footage of the assassination taking place. The ABC highlighted the gun being placed to the man's head by a person in the crowd, the gun being fired and the man's brains being blown out the other side of his head. I do not feel that is satisfactory either, particularly as the program was going to air at, I think, about 8:30 at night. That sort of depiction of violence is unsatisfactory.

The problem is that there is not the same regulatory regime applying to television that applies to film, video and computer games. The answer is not to ease the restrictions on video, film, computer games and publications. I believe, as you do, Mr Acting Deputy President, that there needs to be greater supervision in relation to some of these areas. But we have to have consistent control over what goes on television as well. In the television arena we have split supervision. The ABC answers to the Australian Broadcasting Authority and the commercial stations answer to FACTS, the Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations. It is necessary that we have one body that oversees television and that the standards that are applied are consistent to the standards that apply to videos and films, especially as a television program can have a much wider audience than many films, videos or books. So there is need for consistency there to safeguard the public.

I understand the difficulty in saying, `We're going to require all television programs to go before the film and literature classification body.' The difficulty is that there are four or five channels and regional channels, they are not all showing the same thing, even within a network, and they are each showing 24 hours of programming. So it is very difficult. But it is necessary that there be some supervision and care taken by the people who select programs for screening and by the people who produce programs.

We have to be extremely careful, because there is increasingly an ability for people to take a television program or a video program and convert it into a computer file. It is very easy to do that by having the right hardware on your computer. You can take a live video signal and convert it in compressed format, in short pieces. We are going to see compression of longer pieces and we are going to see that material go onto computer disk and then circulated in an uncontrolled fashion.

When material comes on television or on video there is some opportunity for parental control. But once that material gets taken from video or television and gets placed on computer format, it is possible, especially with young children, for those computer discs to be swapped at school and to be passed from one young person to the next young person with no control. Frequently the parents may well think that the children in question are doing their homework on the computer. Instead, the children are playing games or watching material which may have originally come from video, film or television and has been transferred into computer format.
Unless we have strict control of film, video and television they will be the gateway for this unsatisfactory material to be transferred onto computer. At that point it is very difficult for parents to exercise parental control. That is my concern in relation to these matters. I hope the government will recognise that there is a very real need for careful, ongoing supervision to make sure that we can protect community standards and protect those who are not old enough to exercise discretion in these matters themselves.

talker.name: Senator COOK
talker.role: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

talk.start.para: —I have heard some of the debate on this bill, the Classification (Publications, Films and Computer Games) Bill, although not all of it. Some of the debate disturbs me in the sense that I earnestly believe that the debate has been used, as is often the case, not necessarily to debate the precise nature of the legislation before the chamber, but to debate tangential matters related to that legislation. Therefore, the legislation itself does not come under the same type of parliamentary scrutiny; rather the broad field does. It is for me to acknowledge and thank the speakers who have contributed to this debate, which will hopefully then move to the committee stage. One item that has been referred to here in my presence is the publication the Department of Health has put out on sexual practice in Australia.
—This is Mrs Lawrence?
—That's right; Dr Lawrence is the responsible minister.
—She signed it, didn't she?

—She is the responsible minister for the department. I know Carmen Lawrence extremely well. She is a very honest person of great integrity. I do not think anyone has ever made an accusation in public that the facts are otherwise. She has assured the Australian people that this publication is non-judgmental. I think that has to be recorded.
—What has that got to do with whether it is accurate, whether it is good, or whether it is right?

—The difference is that it is not promoting or encouraging sexual practice or what might be held to be deviant sexual practice. Rather it takes the view that, if people are going to engage in that, they ought to do it in a healthy way and protect themselves. It does not proselytise promote, argue or advocate. That was a key element in the government's campaign on AIDS—educating the community about the best way of exercising their own private choices but not advocating those private choices. It is a fine line to draw but it is a very important line in this debate. The honest reporter here can be misrepresented entirely. I believe that has happened on this occasion. However, that is not the issue before the chamber; the issue before the chamber is the Classification (Publications, Films and Computer Games) Bill 1994. I only mentioned that matter because it arose in the chamber in my presence. On the bill before the chamber, I acknowledge and thank the speakers who have participated in this debate. I commend the bill for a second reading.

para.tab: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The bill.

talk.start.para: —I want to ask a number of questions. They relate particularly to the recommendations of the Senate legislation committee which considered this legislation. I think it would be appropriate now if I asked those questions of the minister. In its report, which was tabled in 1 November 1994, in relation to this matter, the Senate made certain recommendations. The minister has the recommendations before him and can respond. I point out that they are contained on page 7 of the committee's report.

para.tab:
The committee recommended that the Attorney-General call for the classification guidelines and amendments to the national classification code and classification guidelines to be tabled in both houses as soon as practicable after their publication in the
Gazette
. It also recommended that the Attorney-General call for any governmental agreements in relation to the classification scheme to be tabled in both houses as soon as practicable after their signing.

That is important because the national classification code is one of the three key elements in this legislation. This legislation has arisen, firstly, from the consideration that was given by the Australian Law Reform Commission to censorship procedures. Secondly, it has emerged from agreements that have been reached between the relevant state ministers and the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch).

One of the difficulties that has been identified in respect of this matter is the impotence of the parliament, the highest representative group of the people in the nation, to have any say over the national classification code. You might say that this is a matter for the ministers of the various states. However, I inform honourable senators that I have, at times, asked certain ministers what they have been doing in respect of the classifications, standards and guidelines. The answers that I have got have led me to conclude that a number of them are too busy and preoccupied with other areas of their portfolios that they do not really know what is going on in this particular area. Much of this work is left to the public servants and the officers who meet from time to time to fix up all of these matters.

The governments of the various states and the Commonwealth government will need to be aware of the fact that the public will not tolerate that any further. The public is getting a bit concerned about it. Where do members of the public go to express their concerns? Members of the public can complain and express concerns to the particular ministers. We need to have a bit of representative democracy about this. The state and federal parliaments need to have a greater say over what might or might not be contained in the classification code. You might say that that is possibly unworkable on two counts. Firstly, you might have a situation whereby the parliament adopts particular codes which are then found to be inadequate. How will they be overturned? Of course, if they can be made they can be overturned.

That is not without precedent because, under the Broadcasting Services Act, the parliament can reach into the codes of practice that are established for the various programs—television, radio, et cetera—and amend them. It is going to be a very difficult job because you have to get the vote of both houses of parliament. So the government, in that particular case, would have a fairly substantial say over the matter since it commands the majority in the House of Represen tatives.

The second count on which it may be said that it is unworkable is that this is a federal approach to the problem. If the national parliament were to have its say about the national code, it would require the states to concur with that. That is not an impossible resolution. It happens all the time, does it not?

talk.start.para: —Come on, give us a break!
—I heard about the board yesterday and what you said about that. You are a bit of a centralist there.
—It's one of a million examples.

—No. You are probably on my side. You are a bit of a centralist. I am just suggesting in this particular case that surely the national parliament should not just go along with what the states may say. Presumably what is happening in this particular situation is that the states are really running this. But, as I indicated, many of the state cabinets would not know what was going on, to be quite frank.

para.tab:
I come back to the specific questions which deal with our recommendations. Firstly, we are asking that the Attorney-General cause the classification guidelines and amendments to the national classification code to be tabled in both houses of parliament as soon as practicable after their publication in the
Gazette
; and, secondly, that the Attorney-General cause any intergovernmental agreements in relation to the classification scheme to be tabled in both houses as soon as practicable after their signing. That is not much to ask. Frankly, I would have gone further and said that they ought to be disallowable instruments. That is what the committee says, and I am just asking what the government's response to that is.

talker.name: Senator BOLKUS
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

talk.start.para: —The advice I have from the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) is that he supports both recommendations 2(i) and 2(ii). In respect of the first one, the attorney's advice is that, as noted in the committee's report, the requirement you embody in recommendation 2(i) would also be a requirement under the Legislative Instruments Bill 1994 which is currently before the parliament. Under that bill, the amendments to the code and the guidelines would also be registered on the register of legislative instruments and would need to be accompanied by an explanatory statement. I think the recommendation that the committee has made there is going to be picked up in the context of the Legislative Instruments Bill.

para.tab: Recommendation 2(ii) of the committee states that the Attorney-General cause any intergovernmental agreements in relation to the classification scheme to be tabled in both houses as soon as practicable after their signing. The response from the Attorney-General there also is that he supports this recommendation. It is proposed that an intergovernmental agreement be drawn up before this bill commences. My most recent advice is that that expectation is still one the Attorney-General aims to realise.

talk.start.para: —I thank the minister. I know this is not in the minister's area of responsibility, but he will understand that I need to ask this because it is a cooperative. I go to recommendation 2(iii). Do you know whether the Attorney-General has been able to obtain from the states' and territories' censorship ministers their agreement to comply with recommendations 2(i) and 2(ii) within their specific parliaments?

talker.name: Senator BOLKUS
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

talk.start.para: —With respect to recommendation 2(iii), that the committee recommend agreement, the advice I have is that not only does the Attorney-General support the recommendation but he also obtained the agreement of state and territory colleagues to the proposal at the meeting of ministers on 3 February 1995.

para.tab: With respect to recommendation 2(iv), which I think you were alluding to as well, the recommendation that regulation 4A of the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations should be amended to accord with the criteria for the refused classification in the national classification code, my advice is that the Attorney-General has already agreed in principle to amend regulation 4A of the customs regulations in accordance with the recommendation of the Australian Law Reform Commission in its report on censorship procedure and in the report of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material.

My further advice is that in principle support has also been obtained from the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction, Senator Schacht. It is proposed that steps be taken to amend the regulations following enactment of the bill when the final form of the refused classification criteria is in fact confirmed.

talk.start.para: —I thank the minister for his comment. In respect of recommendation 2(iii), what stage have we reached with each and every one of the states and both of the territories as to the complementary legislation? I know there has been draft complementary legislation. What stage has been reached in respect of each of the states and territories on that particular legislation? Will the effect of recommendation 2(iii) be included in the legislation?

talker.name: Senator BOLKUS
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

talk.start.para: —My advice is that they are actually waiting for this bill to go through before they act. No state as yet has introduced legislation, but it is complementary legislation and they are waiting for the federal legislation to go through. That is as much information as I can give you at this stage, but if there is any further information as to individual states that we can elicit for you, then we will do that as well. I think much of it hangs on this legislation going through and the form in which it goes through. Once the form in which this legislation goes through is established, the states and territories then have a basis on which to introduce their complementary legislation.

—In respect of the response you gave to me in relation to recommendation 2(iv), the final refused classification criteria, if the bill goes through and the national classification code does not cover blasphemy, will it to that extent relax the existing customs controls in respect of blasphemy? The Law Reform Commission actually pointed out that to remove a barrier to the importation of films for public exhibition that are blasphemous there is no prohibition on the importation of blasphemous videos.

para.tab: The code at the present moment does not provide for classification on the grounds of blasphemy unless blasphemy is an element in the classification criteria for MA, M, or PG. Is it not a fact that to that extent this bill would relax existing customs controls because existing customs controls do have an element in respect of films for public exhibition, which goes to this question of blasphemy?

I know that we could discuss this concept of blasphemy at length—we have done so in our committees and so on—and discuss what blasphemy actually means, but it is pertinent when you are talking about films for public exhibition. We are talking about films for public exhibition and under regulation 4A of the existing films regulations films for public exhibition can come under the prohibitions relating to blasphemy.

What I am really saying is that if we pass this legislation as it is to what extent does it relax the existing customs control? One thing that you did say gave me a bit of hope, and that is that it depends ultimately on what are the refused classification criteria. Is there some suggestion that this matter of blasphemy may be further considered by the Attorney-General? He is the ultimate authority on it.

talker.name: Senator BOLKUS
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

talk.start.para: —I can say with respect to this that when we are talking about the current prohibitions on the importation of blasphemous films the current prohibitions are in fact limited to films for public exhibition and do not apply to films or videos for sale or hire. The government has no plans to amend the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations to ban the importation of blasphemous films that would otherwise be covered by the current prohibition. We are doing so because we feel that the law as it now stands is inconsistent and of narrow compass in its application.

para.tab: One source of advice that the government has received with respect to this, of course, is the advice from the Law Reform Commission in its report on multiculturalism and the law. In essence, what we are talking about here is blasphemy being an old common law offence concerning the Christian religion, with particular reference to the rituals and documents of the Church of England. The advice from the commission was very clearly that because of the inconsistent protection of religion, because it had narrow, inconsistent and discriminatory coverage, we should remove the offence from federal legislation because the protection given to minority religions—let us face it, we have all of them in this country—is not the same as that given to the religion protected.

The commission also did not favour extending the law of blasphemy to cover faiths other than Christianity as it considered it would be very difficult to devise a satisfactory definition of religion and would have left open-ended legislation. This, of course, also comes with the advice from the Law Reform Commission of New South Wales in its 1992 discussion papers on the same issue. It also favoured the express abolition of the common law offence of blasphemy without specific replacement.

Though Senator Harradine's premise is right, we deviate on the question of policy, if that is the position he is pursuing. The government is choosing to not amend the customs regulations to cover the situation that Senator Harradine may very well want us to cover.

speech.speaker: Harradine Sen B.

talk.start.para: —I am a little unclear. As the minister says, the customs regulations at present have a prohibition in respect of films for public exhibition. Over time the common law has related to the Christian religion and, in particular, its Anglican adherents. But that is not to say that there could not be a provision adopted in statute law which deals with the matter. The minister referred to what the Law Reform Commission said and did not say. The Law Reform Commission, in report No. 95, referred to this matter in these terms:

speech.para: If the commission recommends in its report on multiculturalism and the law that references to blasphemy and federal customs law be retained, consideration should be given to including blasphemy in the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations 4A in relation only to films for public exhibition.

Subsequently, as the minister indicated, the Law Reform Commission, in its report on multiculturalism and the law, appeared to put it in the too-hard basket. I do not think it ought to go in the too-hard basket. This matter will have to be addressed.

para.tab: Surely the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs knows that this matter will have to be addressed at some stage, particularly in respect of the fairly large number of Muslim citizens in Australia. While we are talking about only films for public exhibition, we should be aware that the minister is really excluding and relaxing the current provisions of the legislation, albeit that they would only apply under common law to one group.

Why can we as a parliament not grasp this nettle, look at it and see whether the statute law can cover the situation? Ultimately, people will be so offended that there will be action or a public disturbance. It is no good saying then that we should have listened to Senator Harradine; it will be too late. We should look at what might occur, particularly as we are talking about the public exhibition of films.

It would be grossly offensive to, for example, the Muslim community. I am talking about grossly offensive in strict terms. I am not talking about people getting a chip on their shoulders, getting hot under the collar or becoming very offended. I am talking about material that is of such an offensive and obscene character that it would possibly cause a public disturbance. I feel that this matter should be revisited by the Attorney-General and the state ministers responsible for it.

talker.name: Senator BOLKUS
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

talk.start.para: —I restate that what we have here is a divergence of policy. In terms of the outcome, I am not so sure that your concerns, as limited to this area as they may be, are that great. Keep in mind that we do not have a federal offence for blasphemy. I think you acknowledge that. We are talking about the operation of the common law. Its operation is limited to films for public exhibition, but it will not apply to films or videos for hire.

para.tab:
The last film to be refused registration on the grounds of blasphemy was in 1952. It was the Roberto Rossellini film
The Miracle
. Over the last 50 years only a handful of films have caused concern about blasphemy. They include
The Last Temptation of Christ
and
Hail Mary
. But only one, in 1952, has ever been refused registration on that ground.

You mentioned concerns about the Islamic religion. I am probably more aware than most about the prevalence of religions in our community. It is not just the Islamic religion that is prevalent in our community. I think we have every conceivable religion in Australia thriving and living in an environment of religious tolerance and respect. That is the way it should be. I do not think our objective is all that different. To the extent that there are acts of racially based hatred, we anticipate that our racial hatred legislation will pick up that sort of offensive behaviour.

I come back to the issue of blasphemy. The inconsistency and the advice based on the inconsistency is such that you, Senator Harradine, and the government deviate on the question of policy. But I ask you to keep in mind that one deregistration in a good 50 years or so ensures that the concerns that you might have will not be realised.

talk.start.para: —I want to mention that no film exhibitor in their right mind would be seeking to purchase a film which that exhibitor knows would not get through the customs barrier, the customs legislation test. That may well be one of the reasons that you have not had the type of material that has been publicly exhibited with drastic results in some other countries.

para.tab: I would like to go to the question of how this measure will impact on the customs control of importation of material covered by the bill. It seems to me that this federalist cooperative approach, if you like to put it that way, imposes primary control over classified and objectionable material in state and territory governments. I am wondering how this will affect and impact upon the customs cinematograph films regs and customs prohibited imports reg 4A.

What is the situation with regard to the customs barrier? We have had problems in Victoria, for example, where the material is coming into this country. This material would be refused classification. Obviously, there is a breakdown in the operation of the compliance area in the customs department if this material is coming into the country. It is obviously coming into the country. What is the government doing about making sure there is compliance at the customs barrier?

I know it is a difficult situation, but it is not beyond the wit of members of the Customs Service to have intelligence units operating and to ensure that material is detected, particularly in those areas where people are known importers of the material and the customs department is devoting some time and expenditure in this particular area on detection for the protection of the public.

We are talking about material that is absolutely beyond the pale. It is such that it would be refused classification by any reasonable person. We are talking about sadomasochism. We are talking about extreme violent, sexual material, including material that again, unfortunately, I have had to view in the course of my work on these committees—material that involves rape, torture and the gloating over this by others. It includes other materials as well which can be used by paedophiles. What I am asking the minister is this: has there been more or less money provided to the Customs Service for the purposes of preventing material that would be refused classification and entry into the country?

talker.name: Senator BOLKUS
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

talk.start.para: —I think some time ago Senator Harradine started his questioning by acknowledging that as I was not the Attorney-General I may not be able to give him all the answers, but in so far as the Attorney-General's area is concerned we have done that. He has now acknowledged that I am also not the minister for customs, so I will give him an answer to the last set of questions in so far as I can.

para.tab: I think there are two aspects to your question. One is in terms of the regulations. I can say in respect of those regulations that they will be addressed in a way that will use this bill as a benchmark in terms of how they evolve. But in that consideration of the regulations we would take your views into account and we will pass them on to both relevant ministers.

In terms of enforcement, which I think is the bigger part of your recent contribution, the best thing I can say here is let me take that on notice as to the specific nature of the questioning. As to the generality, I am sure that the customs office does provide enough work to occupy the censor in terms of the material that it seizes at the border. In terms of actual resources and so on, I do not know whether there is any quantification of resources spent on this particular area as opposed to other customs surveillance when people come in at airports, but let me take that on board and come back to you.

speech.speaker: Harradine Sen B.

talk.start.para: —I go to recommendations Nos 2(v), (vi) and (vii), which state:

speech.para: (v)that the current Chief Censor [now Director] be the only ex officio member of the restructured Board;

(vi)that there be new positions of Chief Censor and Deputy Chief Censor, to be appointed from the community representatives on the Board by the Attorney-General for a three year term, with one possible extension; and
(vii)that a community committee be established, representing major interest groups such as parents, teachers, churches, academics, women, youth, Aboriginal and ethic representatives;

para.tab: (a)that the community committee would be asked to consider:
.any decisions of the Film Censorship Board in relation to the release of a film or video with an MA or R rating about which the Board was not unanimous; and
.any decision of the Review Board to vary a Board decision to refuse to release, or release a film or video with a recommended R or MA rating at a lower classification, than recommended by the Board.
(b)that the Review Board be required to take the community committee's recommendations into account in its deliberations, and

(c)that the Attorney-General be required to make a determination on any decision of the Review Board to release a film or video at a lower classification than approved by the unanimous decision of the Board, and be required to take into account the community committee's recommendations.

speech.para: They are very serious recommendations. They go to this question of public confidence in the classification system in Australia. It has been said that potentially Australia's system is a good one; it is probably one of the better ones in the world, as has been said previously in debate.

para.tab: What is needed is confidence in the decisions of the various boards. Senator Cooney was talking about giving them a fair go; he said that people were criticising them. I do not think, from memory, I have personally criticised any members of the Film Censorship Board or the Film Board of Review. I have had plenty of disagreements and discussions with them, but I have not personally denigrated them, nor would I. I think they have a very onerous job, a thankless task, and I appreciate that. I appreciate that each and every one of them would be coming to the job with goodwill and various expertise. That goes for the people within the department as well who also have somewhat of a thankless task.

I have to say on my own behalf and on behalf of the committee that workers in the department, the Film Censorship Board and the Film Board of Review have been very generous with their time. I suppose they are required to be, but they have gone beyond the call of duty. They have provided whatever information was required in a timely fashion, such that it made the work of the committee upon which I serve much easier than it would otherwise be.

There is no question about my feelings: they do not deserve to be denigrated, and I repeat this wherever I go. People ask me, `What are we going to do about the board?' Members of the board are trying to do their job against criteria which we are looking at right here and now. This is the whole point of it all.
