We had a very strong discussion and debate about the film
Salo
being given an R classification. It must be said that it was not given an R classification by the Film Censorship Board, because the Film Censorship Board refused to classify that film and, therefore, it was not available for public exhibition. It then went to the Film Board of Review, and the Film Board of Review overturned the decision that was taken by the Film Censorship Board, and it did so in a rather strange way.

At one particular stage we had Mr Williams, the Chairman of the Film Board of Review, before us. He came to give an explanation, and I understood the erudite nature of his explanation. There was some intellectual sense in it, and one could appreciate that. I am not trying to denigrate Mr Williams because he would be far more intelligent and far more of a film buff than I am—although I very much like going to films and have seen some very good ones over the last six months, and some which have been not all that crash hot.

But I do say this: yes, this is a problem though. Here we have a situation whereby decisions like this on criteria that we are establishing do not properly reflect what the public itself would consider to be a proper application of those criteria. That is the problem. The public itself does not even have standing when it comes to appealing a decision made by the Film Censorship Board. That is another question.

In this particular case of
Salo
, the Film Censorship Board refused it a classification. The importers—I think it was the importers, I may be wrong here; certainly persons with `an interest', and in this case a monetary interest—had standing to appeal to the Film Board of Review. That is how the film got there.

The whole point about this is that, if the Film Censorship Board, for example, had placed this film into the R category and the public itself became appalled at that, the public under the previous legislation did not even have standing to appeal that decision; and under this legislation, the public itself still does not have standing, as I understand it—and correct me if I am wrong; I would like you to answer that—to appeal a decision of the Film Censorship Board. That is of some considerable concern.

I know the arguments that might be used as to the general issue of standing in respect of administrative decisions. But what we as a committee were concerned about was this very question of how the public, the ordinary people living in suburban or rural Australia, would consider that the criteria should be applied in respect of a particular film or video. That is why we have vindicated here these propositions in 2, 5, 6 and 7. They are, I suppose, the community recommendations which we as a committee suggested ought to be part and parcel of this whole package of legislation which includes this bill in the federal sphere and other legislation in the state sphere.

speech.speaker: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

talker.name: Senator BOLKUS
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

talk.start.para: —There are probably a number of ways of answering this question. I think, instead of reading out a six-page letter from the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) to the chair of the Senate select committee on community standards and so on, probably the most productive way would be to seek leave to incorporate it. I think in that letter we have the substance of the answers to Senator Harradine's questions, and I think those answers go for a few pages.

para.tab: In essence, what they say is that the government has confidence in the existing system—and I am glad to see that Senator Harradine has expressed that confidence as well in so far as the existing system operates. We believe that it is working well. We believe that a system, for instance, which allows 30 people to be involved in decision making is one that can accommodate wide views. We also believe that with the standards set, for instance, in this particular bill in clauses 48 and 74 as to appointments, we can maintain a system which can, in turn, maintain continuing confidence from the community as to its operation.

But, as I say, the detail of these answers is in this correspondence. I am sure Senator Harradine would not want me to read it out. I seek leave to incorporate the letter in
Hansard
.
Leave granted.

The letter read as follows
—

speech.para: 6 February 1995
Senator the Hon. Margaret Reynolds
Chair
Senate Select Committee on Community
Standards Relevant to the Supply of
Services Utilising Electronic Technologies
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Reynolds

I refer to your Committee's report titled:
Report on the Consideration of the Provisions of the Classification (Publications, Films and Computer Games) Bill 1994
which was tabled in the Senate on 29 November 1994.
I support the majority of the recommendations made in the Committee's report. State and Territory Censorship Ministers have been consulted about this response and support it.
My specific comments on each of the recommendations are as follows:

para.emphasis: Recommendation 1: The Committee recommends that the Classification (Publications, Films and Computer Games) Bill 1994 be agreed to.

speech.para: Response: I am pleased to note that the Committee recommends that the Bill be agreed to.

para.emphasis: Recommendation 2(i): The Committee also recommends that the Attorney-General cause the classification guidelines and amendments to the National Classification Code and classification guidelines to be tabled in both Houses as soon as practicable after their publication in the Gazette.

speech.para: Response: I support this recommendation. As noted in the Committee's Report this will also be a requirement under the Legislative Instruments Bill 1994 which is currently before the Parliament. Under that Bill the guidelines and amendments to the Code and guidelines will also be registered on the Register of Legislative Instruments and need to be accompanied by an Explanatory Statement.

para.emphasis: Recommendation 2(ii): The Committee also recommends that the Attorney-General cause any intergovernmental agreements in relation to the classification scheme to be tabled in both Houses as soon as practicable after their signing.
Response: I support this recommendation. It is proposed that a intergovernmental agreement be drawn up before the Bill commences.

Recommendation 2(iii): The Committee also recommends that the Attorney-General urge the State and Territory Censorship Ministers to comply with recommendations (i) and (ii) within their respective parliaments.

speech.para: Response: I support this recommendation and I obtained the agreement of my State and Territory colleagues to the proposal at our meeting on 3 February 1995.

para.emphasis: Recommendation 2(iv): The Committee also recommends that regulation 4A of the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations should be amended to accord with the criteria for RC (Refused Classification) in the National Classification Code.

speech.para:
Response: I have already agreed, in principle, to amend regulation 4A of the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations to accord with the criteria for RC (Refused Classification) in the National Classification Code as recommended by the Australian Law Reform Commission (ALRC) in its Report on
Censorship Procedure
and in the Report of the Joint Select Committee on
Video Material
. In principle support has also been obtained from my colleague, the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction, Senator the Hon. Chris Schacht.
It is proposed that steps be taken to amend the Regulations following enactment of the Bill when the final form of the refused classification criteria is confirmed.

para.emphasis: Recommendation 2(v): The Committee also recommends that the current Chief Censor [now Director] be the only ex officio member of the restructured Board.

speech.para: Recommendation 2(vi): The Committee also recommends that there be new positions of Chief Censor and Deputy Chief Censor, to be appointed from the community representatives on the Board by the Attorney-General for a three year term, with one possible extension.

Response: Under the Bill, as is the case with the current Censorship Board and the Film and Literature Board of Review, all members of the Classification Board and Classification Review Board hold statutory appointments.

Under the Bill the statutory positions of Director and Deputy Director will be subject to the same appointment processes as other Board members i.e. the need to ensure that appointees are broadly representative of the Australian community and the requirement to consult about the appointments with State and Territory Ministers (clause 48 of the Bill).

Further, under the Bill they will be subject to the same tenure provisions (a maximum appointment of 5 years with a total period of appointment of no more than 7 years) as other members of the Boards. This is in contrast with the potentially open-ended reappointment arrangements under the existing legislative provisions.

At present the Chief Censor and Deputy Chief Censor also have a senior executive policy and managerial role in relation to the Office of Film and Literature Classification, its personnel and its work. This is in addition to their normal classification functions and responsibilities for managing the work of the Board and for community consultation. These responsibilities will continue under the structure to be established by the Bill.

It follows from this that in the selection of appointees to fill the position of Director and Deputy Director regard would be had not only to their suitability as representatives of the community in performing classification functions and as representing the public face of the Board but also to their managerial experience.

In the Government's view the structure provided in the Bill is the most desirable model. The Office of Film and Literature Classification is a small office (there are only 24 public servants employed in the Office) and it is quite appropriate and cost effective for the Chief Censor to also be the Chief Executive Officer of the Office. I note that this structure is consistent with other statutory bodies which have, in recent years, been given greater autonomy, for example, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

Finally, by way of clarification, I note that the Committee in discussing this recommendation in its October 1993 Report on
Video and Computer Games and Classification Issues
refers to `[t]he situation of the three senior career public servants of the OFLC being the senior members of the Film Censorship Board . . . ' (para 3.62).

I mention that it has not been the general practice in the past to appoint public servants to the statutory positions referred to. Of the incumbents of those positions at the time of the 1993 Report only the Chief Censor was drawn from the public service. Further, the statutory appointees to the Board hold no concurrent public service positions in the OFLC.

para.emphasis: Recommendations 2(vii): The Committee also recommends that a community committee be established, representing major interest groups such as parents, teachers, churches, academics, women, youth, aboriginal and ethnic representatives;

para.tab: (a) that the community committee would be asked to consider:
any decisions of the Film Censorship Board in relation to the release of a film or video with an MA or R rating about which the Board was not unanimous; and
any decision of the Review Board to vary a Board decision to refuse to release, or release a film or video with a recommended R or MA rating at a lower classification, than recommended by the Board.

speech.para: (b) that the Review Board be required to take the community committee's recommendations into account in its deliberations, and

(c) that the Attorney-General be required to make a determination on any decision of the Review Board to release a film or video at a lower classification than approved by the unanimous decision of the Board, and be required to take into account the community committee's recommendations.

para.emphasis: Response: The Committee's proposal seeks, in effect, to place a `community committee' between the Classification Board and the Classification Review Board in respect of certain decisions relating to restricted material and between the Classification Review Board and the Attorney-General in respect of certain other decisions also involving restricted material.

speech.para: The first problem with this proposal is that it is directed solely to material in the restricted classification categories whereas some of the most difficult classification decisions are in relation to the borderline of the `G' and `PG' categories.

Secondly, it would be unfortunate if an additional, and potentially cumbersome and costly structure were to put in place merely to safeguard against the possibility that the classification of a contentious film may be unacceptable to some sections of the community. There is ample evidence available to indicate that the Government's intention is that both
Boards should be representative of the community and, after extensive consultation with the States and Territories, provisions have been added to the Bill to ensure that occurs.

In terms of censorship matters it has often been stated that every individual has a view, and that those views may be diverse. Accordingly, it is a significant achievement that the majority of the community appears to support the classification process and to rely upon the decisions that result. (eg, in the 1992 joint ABT/OFLC research project 70% of respondents with dependant children used the classification system; in the 1994 Australian Bureau of Statistics survey commissioned by the OFLC it was found that 90% of households with children 12 years and under were involved in their children's choice of films; it was also found that adults living in families with children 12 years or under were more aware of the classification system than adults in other households.)

It is not the Attorney-General's role to comment on particular classification decisions made by independent Boards established for this purpose. However, it is appropriate to observe in the context of this recommendation that the particular decision that concerned the Committee in its October 1993 Report on
Video and Computer Games and Classification Issues
was made not by the Censorship Board but by the Film and Literature Board of Review as then constituted.

Although raised in a different context, the question of greater community involvement in classification decisions has already been addressed by my Department in some detail in an earlier submission to the Committee on the Bill. Nevertheless, the issues are similar and they are repeated here in response to this particular recommendation with some supplementary comments from a Ministerial perspective.

The current legislation provides for Censorship Board decisions on the merits and, on appeal, a review on the merits by the Board of Review. Review on questions of law goes to the Federal Court or the High Court. A similar structure is found in the Bill.

A primary decision on the merits with full merits review on appeal is the standard Commonwealth structure for administrative decisions. As the ALRC in its Report on Censorship Procedure noted, where it differs from other reviews of administrative decisions is that it is not a review of an administrator's decision by an independent body but the reconsideration of a decision of one independent body by another.

This difference means that the current decision making process can potentially involve up to 21 individual decision makers (15 on the Censorship Board and 6 on the Board of Review) who can, in appropriate cases, reach the decision by a majority vote. Under the Bill the potential numbers are 20 on the Classification Board and 10 on the Classification Review Board. This gives the opportunity for a very wide diversity of views to be brought to bear in the decision making process.

The proposed community committee would probably add a least a further 10 views to the process if the range of interest groups to be satisfied is taken into account. No doubt the views of this group will be just as divergent as can be the case with the members of the two current Boards and the new Boards. The wide diversity of views that exist within the community are reflected in the results of the on-going public consultation process referred to below.

Quite apart from the undesirability of the Attorney-General having to make classification decisions in the manner proposed in the recommendation, questions relating to whether Board decisions reflect community attitudes, as my Department has previously indicated, are best addressed by ensuring that the Boards:

para.tab: (a) truly represents a cross section of the community; and
(b) remain abreast of community attitudes.

speech.para: The representative nature of the Boards is being addressed by the new process of consultation with State and Territory Ministers and the requirement to look at the representative nature of proposed appointments, both of which are now reflected legislatively in the Bill (cl. 48 and 74). You may be assured that this aspect is treated seriously by myself and my State and Territory colleagues. This is reflected in the recent appointments that have been made to the Censorship Board and the Film and Literature Board of Review.

Further, appointments to the current Censorship Board follow public advertisements, interviews and recommendations on the basis of merit. Of recent times there has also been a State and Territory representative on the interviewing panel. This will continue with the new Classification Board.

As to keeping abreast of community attitudes, the ALRC's recommendation for an on-going public consultation program has already commenced. This consultation process takes the form of special screenings of classified, but as yet unreleased, films to groups of people assembled by a market research recruitment agency. An independent market research consultant supervises the completion of a questionnaire and leads a discussion aimed at comparing the issues of concern, the range of intensity of concern about those issues, the recommended age, and appropriate consumer advice with those considered by the Censorship Board when making the classification decision. The results are made available to Board members.

The initial Australian Bureau of Statistics survey on Films, Videos and Computer Games commissioned by the Office of Film and Literature Classification (OFLC) has been completed and copies have been provided to the Committee. Further surveys and research flowing from the results of that survey are planned or underway. These include another joint exercise with the OFLC and the ABA.

In the light of the above I do not consider the proposal put forward by the Committee to be justified in the current circumstances. The perceived dissatisfaction with certain classification decisions should be addressed by examining any deficiencies in the current decision making process and taking steps to rectify any problems that are found and not by seeking to impose another potentially unwieldy structure on top of the structure that already exists.
The Committee may be assured, however, that I will be closely monitoring the operation and performance of the two new Boards, in conjunction with my State and Territory colleagues.
Yours sincerely
MICHAEL LAVARCH

talk.start.para: —Before the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Bolkus) arrived in the chamber, I spoke on the pornographic, government so-called safe sex guide. When I was in the chair the minister said to me, `I'm sorry to distract you from the pornography that you're reading.' The pornography that I was reading was the Lawrence-Keating so-called safe sex guide.

—Madam Temporary Chairman, I raise a point of order. That sort of provocative intervention by me probably deserves the answer I am getting, just as Senator Herron will deserve the answer I am about to give him. I did not know what Senator Herron was reading. I could not even see from here what it was, but I knew he was distracted. It could have in fact been the next set of advertisements from Mr Robb for all I knew. I did not have Senator Herron's attention. I very quickly grabbed it by using the word `pornography'.

para.tab:
The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator West)
—There is no point of order.

talk.start.para: —I explain to the minister that when I was doing my surgical training at the Royal College of Surgeons in England—
—This, of course, relates to the bill.

—It relates to the bill because it brings in the very matter that we are discussing. It is relevant. If you, Madam Temporary Chairman, were able to read my mind you would have known that it was relevant.
—The chair is capable of many things but not mind-reading.

—That is beyond even the chair, I suspect. When I was at the Royal College of Surgeons, the lecturer on neurophysiology lectured us on the connections between hearing and vision, the effect that that had and how one superimposed itself on the other. While he was speaking, he put up on the screen a photograph of a young lady in a diaphanous negligee and kept speaking to a room full of people. Dare I say it, that was in 1960 and, out of the 300 who were there, five were females. He then said he wanted us to write down what he had said in the last three minutes. This story is to illustrate that vision overcomes sound in all cases. I say to the minister that in essence that was what was occurring when I was looking at the Keating-Lawrence pornographic safe-sex guide.
—My sound overcame your vision.

—Sound penetrated and ultimately I was distracted. The deputy clerk got my attention—she had heard the minister because she was closer to him than I was. I reinforce my remarks because film does have an enormous effect—just as television does. That is the relevance here about vision overcoming sound. Film and television are far more dominant than radio.

para.tab: I do not agree entirely with some of Senator Harradine's remarks because I firmly believe that desensitisation occurs. We had evidence before our committee that work has been done on that particular aspect and that desensitisation occurs.

talk.start.para: —I agree.

—I am sorry; Senator Harradine does agree with me. Desensitisation needs to be considered in this whole thing. With due respect to Mr Dickie and the members of his board, I think it is important that that board change because, inevitably, whatever people think, including even the minister, they become desensitised over matters—not these matters that I am referring to but in whatever we deal with—just as I am desensitised by my clinical career. We become hardened. We become hardened by—
—By your colleagues.

—Not at all. We become hardened. We become desensitised to an activity if we are dealing with it over a prolonged period. Of course, the converse of it is that we become more expert in that particular field. But in matters of this nature, in terms of publications, films and computer games—I know that we have debated this and questioned it in the committee—none of us are experts. No matter how widely read we are or how active we are in our fields, ultimately we cannot live long enough to know everything with this changing scene that is occurring.

para.tab: In relation to Internet, how do you control and how do you classify pornographic publications that come through Internet? I have no doubt that under this bill the Keating-Lawrence pornographic so-called sex guide will be on Internet, available and officially sanctioned—in fact, officially published on Internet. How are you going to control that? Then this Keating-Lawrence pornographic so-called sex guide becomes available to eight-year-olds, because it is an official government publication. That is the point I wanted to make.

talk.start.para: —Whilst we are on that subject, under what part of the national code would such material gain unrestricted classification?

talker.name: Senator BOLKUS
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

talk.start.para: —I think that is one where I can come back to Senator Harradine with a specific reference to the section.

—It is an interesting thought. We are dealing with material that was not given an unrestricted classification; it was never submitted for classification. This is material signed by a minister of the Crown which is promoting anal sex, and it is wrong to say that it just describes it. For crying out loud, any reasonable person would say that this should be restricted. It should not have been allowed to have been in stores and to have been freely picked up by children, particularly by the readership of
Cleo
, which many young girls read.

para.tab: This is unrestricted. It is promoting anal sex and all sorts of other material which Senator Herron has described in clinical detail, and he is by far better qualified medically than I am. But it is not described in clinical detail in the particular publication; it is described in a salacious manner and approved by Minister Carmen Lawrence. We are dealing with something that has got into the hands of children. I defy anybody in this chamber to say that this material should be in the hands of children—any one of you to stand up and say that this should be in the hands of children. But it is in the hands of children.

Did the minister submit it for classification under any of the state laws? If this particular legislation goes through, under what section of this legislation will this material be able to have unrestricted circulation amongst the children of our country? That is what you have to ask yourself and that is what this chamber must ask itself. We do need a response to that and we need it now.

I had not even thought of bringing up this issue, but I am glad that Senator Herron brought it up because it does require an answer. So I ask the minister: could he say in what state or territory, if any, did the minister submit this material for classification and, if it was not submitted, what action is to be taken? The second question I want answered is: if this legislation is adopted, and complementary legislation by the departments is adopted, under what provision in that legislation will this material be restricted from being circulated amongst children?

talker.name: Senator BOLKUS
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

talk.start.para: —My advice is that—as the Senate might know—this written material attaches to it no obligation for submission. So it does not have to be submitted as written material. That is a reflection of the legal situation both in terms of the present and the future legislation. I am advised that there will be some minor changes to that prevailing situation in terms of whether the written material has to be submitted. Despite there being no obligation for submission, as to whether this document had been submitted, that is probably a question best asked of the health minister. I do not think Mr Dickie has any record of it being submitted for classification, but there is no obligation to so submit.

—Obviously I know that there is a voluntary program operating for publications. I have been involved in this for many years; of course I know that. What I am saying is that any responsible person would have submitted this material to the relevant authorities for classification, and that is not what the minister did. She did not do that, but any responsible person would have done so. After all, what are we doing here? We have a bill which relates to the classification of publications, films and computer games. One would think under those circumstances that it is all about the classification of that material for the purposes of ensuring compliance with the principles.

para.tab: What are the principles in this legislation? They are that `adults should have the right to view and read what they wish, provided that others are not subject to offensive material and that children are protected'. That is what it says here. That is misstated, as was said by the Joint Select Committee on Video Materials. It really is the balance between the freedom of speech of the pornographer and the portrayal of violent material and the common good. That is the balance we are talking about.

The question that I am asking now is predicated on the fact that, in respect of publications, it is a voluntary scheme. One would have thought that the scheme is designed for the purpose of protecting children from this material. Senator Herron could assist me if he wishes by relaying to the committee what this material is, then the committee can decide whether this material should have gone out in an unrestricted way. What is in this legislation to prevent this material going out to children in an unrestricted way? The minister's response says absolutely nothing. That indicates to me a failing in the legislation that we are dealing with. The minister says that there will be a slight change, presumably in state legislation in relation to publications. What is that slight change going to be and how will it operate?

talker.name: Senator BOLKUS
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

talk.start.para: —We could all get upset about this and have a very emotional debate about it, but there are one or two things that we cannot get away from. Firstly, the minister acted in accordance with the law. Secondly, the minister acted in a responsible way in view of the problem at hand. Let us not hide from that.

para.tab:
The reality is that young people are indulging in sex. No matter how we talk about other things in this place, that is starting point number one. Starting point number two is that they are probably doing it at a younger age and engaging in a wide variety of sexual activities. You cannot get away from that either. The responsibility of the minister and the government in these circumstances is to get a message to kids about safety. In some respects, our campaigns over the years have been world leading. They have been world leading because they have in many ways been at the cutting edge of getting into people's minds and people's psyches. It is not easy to educate young kids about safe sex—it is not easy for parents, it is not easy for the schools and it is not easy for the community. At a time when kids are engaging in a wide variety of sexual practices—
(Quorum formed)

The point I am making is that there is a problem there. We have been at the cutting edge of campaigns, and I think our campaigns have been recognised as being successful in the past. It does not mean that the minister personally endorses either the sexual behaviour discussed or the style in which the articles were written. Any responsible person in her position, or any minister, has to look at ways of getting messages through, and that is what is being done here.

I will come back to the law and try to bring us back to what the legal situation is. As I said at the start, there is no question as to whether the minister acted in accordance with the law or not. She did not have to submit, and she did not. She acted very much in accordance with the law.

Senator Harradine, you asked me, in your final question, about what would be the change in the law. Clause 23 is to the effect that in the Australian Capital Territory—because of constitutional limitation—the censor will be able to look at material that is submittable material under the definition clause of the bill; basically, material that may go into the restrictive category. There will be authority within the censor to be able to call that material and to make an assessment, if it fits that definition of `submittable' and is material that may be in that category of being restricted. That is the minor modification I refer to.

speech.speaker: Herron Sen J.

talk.start.para:
—Minister, in relation to this material, you questioned whether it should be classified or not and you said that it was a non-judgmental resource. I would like to refer you—and this is your guide and a non-judgmental resource—to this. It is entitled
Making Anal Sex Safe
. It is impossible to make anal sex safe because inevitably there is trauma to the anus, the skin and the anal sphincter. They are anatomical facts. It is impossible to make it safe. This has the endorsement of your minister.

para.tab: You then questioned Senator Harradine and Senator Harradine said that he did not have it with him. You questioned the pornographic nature of it. I do not like reading things out of publications that I consider should not be on the bookstands, and these are on the bookstands. If you want something pornographic, I will give it to you. One document states:

speech.para: SPIT OR SWALLOW?
You've just performed fellatio on your partner and he's come in your mouth. Should you:
a) hold the semen in your mouth, then spit it out?
b) swallow the semen as quickly as possible?
c) never allow someone to come in your mouth.

There is a page on that. It is full of pornography under the classifications of pornography. I will give you a little more if you want a little more. I will keep reading if you want demonstrations of pornography under this legislation. This is your publication. That is an example of what I am referring to. Let us have a little more, if you wish. I do not want to read this, but this is what is in your publication. It states:
Fist insertion, fisting, fist fucking. A person inserts their fist into their partner's anus or vagina. Can cause trauma to the rectum—
Minister, I have operated on people and done colostomies on them for that very practice. It continues:
leading to possible contact with blood. The vagina is more elastic but care must still be taken. Risk reduced if lubricant and latex gloves used. Same risks as finger insertion.

Do you want more? I will give it to you. It is in your publication. I am not going to go through it. I have placed all those yellow stickers on pornographic material. You have this on the bookstands of this country, available to anybody who goes in and is prepared to pay the price.

para.tab: How are you going to control this? You, minister, and your `health' minister are promoting these practices. As I say, I will invite anybody in this chamber—and Mr Dickie, too, if you wish—to get a copy of this and make a judgment on it. I would ask anybody in Australia to get a copy and make a judgment on it.

It is not me. I must say that I cannot recall ever taking a stand on a matter of this nature, but when this was brought to my attention I was appalled. Here is a publication put out by the government, available on the bookstands of this country, that is pornographic. As I said, if you want more examples I am happy to give them. If you do not think what I have read out to you is pornographic, then you have a problem.

This publication advocates lesbian behaviour. I will read another portion. This is not pornographic but it is straight advocacy. The next point I want to make is about advocacy of practices. It states:
When it comes to sex, lesbians can throw away their home pregnancy kits, poke holes in their diaphragms and forget about fellatio and faking orgasms.
It's no wonder most lesbians feel sexually liberated. Firstly, they get to enjoy the extra kisses, cuddles and communication that come from being with another woman.

speech.para: Minister, this is what you are promoting. You are advocating lesbianism. There may be people in the community who believe that enhances family values. I am being non-judgmental, minister. It is advocating heterosexual anal sex. Another article is entitled `Making anal sex safe and enjoyable'. Page 52 states:
The truth is, for women who desire it, anal penetration can radically enhance sexual sensation.
Advocacy. I turn to page 50, which contains an article entitled `The agony and the ecstasy'. At least it has the decency to say there is a bit of agony in it. It states:

The truth is, a lot of women
do
get off on anal sex, when it is done sensitively—and safely.
This is your minister's publication. I now talk about accuracy. It says here:
Others enjoy the act of anal penetration itself. Studies suggest that anywhere between 40 and 60 per cent of women have tried anal sex.

This is your publication, minister—non-judgmental. It is totally untrue. I have researched the studies on this through the parliamentary library and other sources. It is totally untrue. The figure of between 40 and 60 per cent is totally untrue. It is advocating not only deviancy. I have not gone onto the bit about urinating on your sexual partner as being pleasurable—safe providing you do not urinate into cuts on their skin after whipping them. That is in it too, minister: advocacy of the enjoyment of sado-masochism. That is in your publication. This is pornographic material. It has the imprimatur of your minister. I will read the imprimatur if you do not believe me. It states:
While most people are aware of the seriousness of HIV/AIDS and its links with unsafe sexual practices, not enough is known . . .

para.tab:
In an effort to further inform young women and men about STDs and HIV/AIDS, the Federal Government has collaborated with
CLEO
to produce the Safe Sex booklet. It deals with sexual health-

speech.para: What a laugh! Sexual health?—
in a factual and non-judgmental way and is a resource that everyone should read.

At least the minister and I agree that everyone should read this publication. Your government, your health minister and your Prime Minister (Mr Keating) will stand condemned when everyone reads it. I am talking only about the health aspects of it. I am talking about the classification of this pornographic material in this context.

para.tab: In reality, the vast majority of Australians—90 per cent at least; probably 95 per cent—believe in a family life, in the virtue of the family, the education of their children and the protection of their children from pornography. You, minister, and your government are going to be taken to account for the promotion of this pornographic material.

How can one classify material under these regulations if it is put out by government? That is the question that Senator Harradine was asking the minister. When it is officially sanctioned pornography—I have given enough examples; there are many more in the booklet—how does one classify officially sanctioned government pornography?

talker.name: Senator BOLKUS
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

talk.start.para: —I think once again Senator Harradine's question went very much to the point in the legislation and whether this document was submitted, and I have answered that. In terms of the performance we have just heard from Senator Herron, I do not want to interrupt his acts of self-gratification here or all over the country. He is on the radio every day reading bits and pieces—

—Madam Temporary Chairman, I raise a point of order. I regard that as a slur on my character and I ask the minister to withdraw. He said an act of self-gratification, as if I was getting some enjoyment. Does he really think I get enjoyment from bringing up this subject and talking about it in the parliament? Does he really think that? That is what he has just alleged.

para.tab:
The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator West)
—Order! Minister, would you kindly withdraw, please?

talk.start.para:
—I will withdraw unreservedly. But let me say that I did not enjoy hearing Senator Herron and nor does his performance across the country show a balanced approach to this. A balanced approach in this particular area is an approach that recognises that no matter how Senator Herron or others may not want certain acts to be performed they are being performed. No matter how much he or others do not want certain acts to be talked about, they are being talked about.
The reality is that I as a parent of a teenager am concerned about sexual activity and also the awareness that kids have and the diversity of the range of their activities. The reality is that whether we want to admit it or not sexual practices go on. For instance, most people acknowledge that the degree of sexually transmitted diseases amongst young people in this country and elsewhere is at a level that we should not be tolerating. We have to get into their psyches, and that is what has driven this particular project. Getting back to the legality of it, the minister has acted in accordance with her obligations under the legislation.

speech.speaker: Harradine Sen B.

talk.start.para: —I think it is a bit rich for the minister to talk of Senator Herron like that. Senator Herron has a wealth of medical knowledge and practice which he has brought to bear on the problems of the spread of AIDS in the community. I have been on the parliamentary committee on AIDS ever since it started. It does not meet regularly at all now. The government is going its own way.

para.tab: We were very pleased to see Senator Herron come on that committee and he brought a great deal of commonsense and understanding of the problem to the committee. In fact, as he said quite correctly, 95 per cent of the deaths from AIDS are due to homosexual anal sex. That is a fact. We all know that the danger is that if this practice is spread amongst the heterosexual community that creates an enormous problem.

Incidentally, Senator Herron this morning gave one major reason why we have contained the disease and not had it spread as it has in some other countries. I personally know of one instance where it has spread to the drug scene. Largely, it has been controlled, as Senator Herron said, because of the needle exchange program. We do not want it to be spread amongst the heterosexual community.
As Senator Herron said, the minister has falsely painted a picture that anal sex is widespread amongst the heterosexual community. What does this say?

talk.start.para: —Forty to 60 per cent.
—It says 40 to 60 per cent. Even the most outrageously skewed research suggests a figure of around—
—Around five per cent, according to family planning figures.

—It is around five per cent. That figures comes from people reporting to family planning clinics for one thing or another, presumably including STDs. I ask the chairman of the Film Censorship Board whether he has seen this report. Page 50 outlines the story of Julie, who is 23:

speech.para: I have only had anal sex about 10 times, but each time the sense of forbidden fruit makes it so exciting. You can get a similar buzz from dressing up in black suspenders. But with anal sex the vibe is more primeval, more erotic, kind of like losing your virginity all over again. It is not something I go in for all the time, but if I am in the right mood my partner will stick—
It continues. The Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) says that that should be read by everybody, including children. It is unrestricted to children.

para.tab: We are dealing with the Classification (Publications, Films and Computer Games) Bill 1994. I am telling the chief censor to look at it and let us know whether, if it were submitted to him, it would have been given an unrestricted category. Amongst other things, category 1, which is a restricted category, refers to publications unsuitable for a minor to see and read. A lot of other things are included. Is this unsuitable for a minor to read and see? Please answer that question, because I want to know. The Senate is entitled to know whether this material is unsuitable for a minor to see or read. Please answer that question. It has to be answered because it is a Film Classification Board document.

Senator Herron has raised the document in this parliament. We want to know how this is going to operate. Having heard that, can the minister say whether the government would say that that publication should be unrestricted. It is a fair question, and I want an answer to it.

talker.name: Senator BOLKUS
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

talk.start.para: —We are going over this ground time and time again. I could very easily point to answers that the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) has already given in answer to questions like that. She has been keen to have information about sexual practices easily available for young people in an endeavour to reduce our incidence of the spread of HIV and other sexually transmittable diseases. You have to acknowledge, as people do, that our campaigns in this country have been successful, even though they have been innovative. As I said earlier on, the minister does not personally endorse either the sexual behaviour—neither do I—or the style in which the articles are written.
—She says it should be read by everyone.

—This is the point I was trying to make to Senator Herron earlier. If you talked to a group of teenagers these days about sexual practices, they would not only talk about practices in
Cleo
but also would shock you with a broader diversity—
—That is because of stuff like this.

—This is before stuff like this, Senator. Don't fool yourself into thinking that they do not know about it and that they do not talk about it. We have to get it into their minds that they either do not do it or they get their practices right. That is what this is about. When it comes back to the legislation, the very clear point—we will keep coming back to it—is that it has not been submitted and there was no obligation on the minister to so submit. We can keep on going through this at different angles for the next day and a half, but we will come back to that conclusion.
—I am not going to go on about it at all. You have a bit of a hide to tell me about teenagers; my goodness me!
—I know you know.
—I have heaps of them. I discussed it with them and they said it is all—

para.tab:
The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator West)
—Don't use the language, thank you, Senator.

talk.start.para: —No, they did not say that. They thought it was weird and way-out. It is certainly not consistent with their understanding of what other people practise. However, I have tried my best to get a clarification of what is meant by an unrestricted publication, but I have failed.

para.tab: I wish to raise a couple of other matters. I refer to the section which deals with standing for appeals against decisions of the board. It lists the persons who have standing for the purposes of those appeals. From memory, I think it lists the Attorney-General, the film producer or somebody with an interest, and a person who is aggrieved by the decision. Could you outline to the chamber who would fit into that latter category? Would it exclude a mother who may be concerned that a film is unsuitable for viewing by persons under the age of, say, 18?

In the case of PG and G—I admit that they are sometimes the most difficult of classifications for the Film Censorship Board to consider—parents are very concerned about keeping those classifications with the greatest degree of integrity. I think the bill says that a person aggrieved by the decision can appeal. Would that include a parent who is concerned about the particular classification?

talker.name: Senator BOLKUS
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

talk.start.para: —I am sure Senator Harradine, once again, knows that I cannot give legal opinions as to how the law applies on a specific set of facts. The range of people he talks about as to whether they do or do not is, once again, best left for interpretation of law.

para.tab:
The concept of a person aggrieved is a concept which is found in other legislation, including the customs regulations for an appeal against the decision not to register a film and the ADJR, and it is a subject of judicial authority as to its meaning. It is currently interpreted to cover at least a person who has an interest in the matter but that interest has to be beyond that which he or she may have as an ordinary member of the public. For example, the advice I get from the Attorney-General is that standing would go to, for instance, two priests who may have sought judicial review of the censorship board's decision to register the film
Hail Mary
. So an aggrieved person has to have an interest over and above any interest that he or she may have as an ordinary member of the public.

talk.start.para: —I am aware of that previous case. That is why I posed my question in the terms that I did. In my view, that person, that parent, could well be aggrieved. My understanding of the ADJR decisions has been that they would exclude a parent under those circumstances. That is my reading of it. You have incorporated the letter from the Attorney-General to the minister in respect of the recommendations from the committee but that, in a way, wipes off the community involvement. One thing I would like to see at some stage is a provision which enables persons, not just persons aggrieved in the strict legal sense of that word aggrieved, to be able to appeal against a particular classification of a film.

para.tab: Unless you have something like that—unless a situation where those who are able to have standing for the purpose of appeal is extended somewhat—you are going to deny the public from having a say about the matter. Parliament does not have the say that we thought it ought to have on the national classification code. The public does not have a say in the area that we recommended—and we recommended that a particular community committee be established to advise the board but that has not been included in here.

So where do the public go? Where does a parent or a group of parents or, for example, a school parents and friends group, go to appeal against a particular classification? They cannot go anywhere. If they come to us, we cannot do anything about it because there is nothing in the legislation which enables the parliament to have any say about the national code much less about the application of the code by the Film Censorship Board. So where can they go? Now that the government has denied the recommendation that the committee made, that a community group be established to advise the board, where do we go? That goes to the question of standing.

That is why I am raising this matter here as a matter of great importance. Unfortunately, the government is not prepared to go on along with that. I know the question of frivolous appeals has to be dealt with but that is dealt with in other jurisdictions quite easily. Those issues in respect of frivolousness are well-defined in the courts.

Finally, I want to make the comment that when Senator Herron suggested that I was saying that the whole system is working well and I have great confidence in the system he slightly misunderstood what I said. What I was saying was that I do not envy the job of the members of the board. As a member of the committee, I felt I had to go and see the film
Salo
. I did not consider that entertainment, and I kept my ticket for taxation purposes.

talk.start.para: —They will still knock you back, Brian!

—No, it is against my electoral allowance. It was certainly not entertaining, and I sympathise with the members of the Film Censorship Board. I did say that I felt that each of them comes with a genuine community spirit to their obligations and sees things in the best way that they can but, as Senator Cooney said, we all err.

para.tab:
One big thing that I would like to see is the turnover of the board to save the problem of desensitisation. There is no risk about desensitisation. I look at films now—for example,
Salo
—and I suppose I was desensitised, because I did not walk out feeling sick and I wondered afterwards why the heck I did not. The reason was that I had one half of my mind on the actual screen—the depictions and so forth—while the other half was thinking, `How could it possibly fit into the R category,' et cetera. It does depend very much on who is involved in the decision making. That goes for the Attorney-General, each of the state ministers, the Film Censorship Board and the boards that are established under this legislation.

talker.name: Senator BOLKUS
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

talk.start.para: —I will be very brief as well. Senator Harradine raised two points. One is as to the tenure of the board. I think he realises for the first time that there will be a time limit on the term of members of the board, so that is an advance that he would welcome.

para.tab: The other point is on the standing of an aggrieved person. I can say—and it may not once again satisfy Senator Harradine—that the same law applies here as applies in other aspects of federal jurisdiction. It is not as if we are making a difference in terms of the definition of `aggrieved person'.
Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

debate.title:
CUSTOMS TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1994
EXCISE TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1994

para.tab:
Debate resumed from 1 March, on motion by
Senator Crowley
, and 6 February, on motion by
Senator Collins
:
That these bills be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —The Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994 and the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994 are straightforward bills that would enact minor modifications to the customs and excise tariffs. The two bills are very similar, with identical provisions adjusting the duty on a number of petroleum products, including fuel oil and aviation fuel. The provisions are identical because tariff modifications in customs bills apply only to imports, whereas tariff modifications in excise bills apply to domestically produced goods.

para.tab: With the petroleum duty, the bills would reduce the duty on topped crude oil by 2.977c per litre and the duty on fuel oil, heating oil and kerosene by 1.977c per litre. The reductions took effect on 11 May 1994 and were originally announced in the 1994-95 budget. The reductions partially offset the 3c per litre petrol duty increase that followed the 1993-94 budget.

On budget day 1993, the then Treasurer, Mr Dawkins, announced that the duty on petroleum products would immediately increase by 3c per litre. This government never changes: it is always hell-bent on collecting more revenue from the poor consumers in society. There would be a further 1c increase in February and August 1994. The 5c per litre increase represented a massive 96 per cent increase in the duty on fuel oil. It would have had a savage effect on the Australian mining industry.

One of the worst affected companies would have been Nabalco, which manages a bauxite mining and alumina refining operation at Gove in the Northern Territory. Nabalco, I might point out, is Australia's largest user of fuel oil. It consumes about 45 per cent of all dutiable oil sold in Australia; that is, 1,250 tonnes a day. The 5c per litre duty increase would have cost the company $25 million per year—one of those so-called unintended consequences that we have so much come to expect from this government.

Let me just mention this position with regard to Nabalco. It is a discriminatory tax, as Nabalco is the only alumina producer which is dependent on fuel oil. It has no choice; there is no alternative choice of either coal-fired electricity or gas. There have been attempts, I understand, to get a gas pipeline through, but because of either lack of resources or cost that has not occurred.

The imposition of the tax is contrary to the Gove agreement—that is, that the Commonwealth will do its best to ensure that discriminatory taxes are not applied. As a result of what the company claims, this agreement being violated, a sovereign risk question is raised, an issue of special concern to the mining industry—particularly because of all the other silly things we have seen done by this government with regard to sovereign risk.

Nabalco does not have the ability to convert to using gas or other alternative fuels, as I mentioned earlier. Of course, Nabalco finds itself in world markets. It has no option. It is a highly competitive business and does not have the ability to pass on additional costs. This is something that this government or a future government sooner or later will have to address.

In the to-ing and fro-ing and negotiating in the budget, the government abandoned the two duty increases scheduled for 1994. As a result, the duty on fuel oil increased by a mere 54 per cent, instead of 96 per cent. In other words, it was supposed to be good for you that it was only a 54 per cent increase rather than a 96 per cent increase.

But the increase was still a massive impost on some of our more important export industries. It wiped out the benefits of the final stage of the shipping industry reform package. That was another unintended consequence. The industry and maritime unions had signed an agreement in August 1993 that reduced the average crewing level on Australian ships from 20.5 to 18. The agreement saved $270,000 per ship. The effect of the decision to increase the fuel oil duty by 3c was to add an extra two phantom crew members to each ship—a constant ghostly reminder of the government's failure to consider properly the effects of its policies.

Savage River Mines, which my colleague Senator Watson would be well aware of, in Tasmania is another example. With a very marginal profit—in fact, I think it runs at a loss—it operates an open-cut iron ore mine in north-west Tasmania. It uses about 18 million litres of fuel oil a year to bake iron ore into pellets—a bit of value adding, I might say, in the iron ore industry.

The 3c per litre increase costs this struggling company an extra $550,000—$550,000 it cannot afford and cannot recover because it cannot increase its prices. Prices are determined on the world markets. The government clearly forgot that Australian commodity exporters cannot influence the prices they receive. They cannot pass tax rises on to their customers. Instead, cost increases directly affect their profitability and their ability to continue their operations, which is a real problem for Savage River Mines. The coalition welcomes the decision to reduce the duty on these petroleum products.

As regards aviation gasoline and kerosene, the bill will increase the air safety regulation duties on avgas and avtur by 1.194c per litre. It would also enact a 7.521c per litre decrease in the component of the avgas excise that is associated with the Civil Aviation Authority's airways services. The duty on avgas would therefore decrease 6.327c per litre in all—that is, a net decrease. Avgas, or aviation gasoline, is the fuel used in piston-driven propeller aircraft. Avtur is used in jet aeroplanes and turbine-powered propeller aircraft.

The air safety regulation duty originated in the government's aviation safety cost recovery program, which progressed—fitfully, I might say—through the 1980s. The government announced in the 1992-93 budget that the cost of setting and enforcing safety standards would be shared between the industry and the government, with the government meeting 50 per cent of the cost up to a limit of $22.8 million.

In 1993 the government increased the duty on avgas by 0.264c per litre and introduced a similar duty on avtur as an interim cost recovery measure. This bill is the next step in the cost recovery program. The 7.521c per litre decrease in avgas is due to a reduction in the cost of providing services such as air traffic control and flight information. Over the last few years the Civil Aviation Authority has substantially reduced its expenditure on delivering those services. The reduction in duty on avgas passes some of these savings on to the general aviation sector, which largely uses avgas-powered aircraft.

The Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) contains a number of other amendments. This bill will enact one further alteration to the duty on petroleum products. In 1993 the government legislated to prevent producers and consumers avoiding excise by substituting stabilised crude oil for diesel and condensate for petrol. The legislation inadvertently imposed excise duty on stabilised crude oil and condensate used as a fuel in the recovery, production, transportation and refining of those products. This bill eliminates that anomaly.

The Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994 will enact a number of other minor modifications to the customs tariff. Most importantly, it will implement the continued phasing out of developing country preferences. In February 1993 the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) announced the government would modify the tariff preference arrangements applying to 42 of the more advanced developing countries. The government accordingly phased out the preferential tariffs applying to a number of products imported from those countries. In Working Nation, the government announced it intended to extend the phase-out even further. Accordingly, the bill proposes to extend it to cover all of those countries' exports to Australia, except cheese, unmanufactured tobacco, sugar and replacement components for passenger motor vehicles.

Eighty-seven countries will still be subject to preferential tariff arrangements. They include some of the poorest countries on earth—such as Chad, with a per capita gross national product of $200 per year, and Burkina Faso, with a per capita GNP of $300 per year. The coalition does not oppose these bills.

talk.start.para: —I rise briefly to say that, while the Greens accept that the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) and the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) will pass, we have problems with them. We see no real reason to make aviation fuel cheaper. It is not an efficient form of transport in most cases and the greenhouse response—
—Do you want to catch the train here every week to parliament or go by boat from Perth?

—The interjection by the minister was, `Do you want to catch the train here?' There are quite a lot of occasions, especially in non-sitting times, when there are committee meetings. We should have the intelligence in this place to be able to work out some form of teleconferencing instead of, in our case, coming all the way from Western Australia or missing out on the committee altogether. Especially in non-sitting weeks there is quite a lot of air travel that could be avoided.

para.tab: I also think that a better train service from places such as Sydney and perhaps even Melbourne—but especially Sydney—might mean that more parliamentarians would use a train option rather than an airline option. I think a lot of people would do that. That might create fewer problems for the government in relation to airport noise. I see no real reason for making aviation fuel cheaper. Air travel is not an efficient form of transport in most cases. The greenhouse response strategy, which requires some reflection of damage to be included in price, should at least dictate that air transport does not get any extra advantages.

Likewise, I understand that the reduction of fuel oil tax which we support in relation to shipping will also be applicable to mining generators, something that also seems counter to energy use and environmental considerations. This is another example of the lack of integration of the supposed objectives of government and one of the reasons greenhouse strategies have little credibility. It seems that whenever there is conflict, the environment and environment policy loses.

This is not major legislation and I realise that these measures are meant to complete already passed legislation that was in the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill and the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill last year. In any case, we see the remediation action for shipping to be worth while. So we will not formally oppose the bills but will note that this bill is spoiled by not considering energy use in a bill that will affect it. If I thought an amendment on this bill would have any chance of support, we would have put one to target the benefits to shipping and to exclude air travel and mining.

talker.name: Senator SCHACHT
talker.role: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

talk.start.para: —The government's reasons for the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) and the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) are clear in the second reading speech. I thank senators for their contributions. I say to Senator Parer, who made a number of comments about fuel oil and the impact on Nabalco, that I sat through the estimates committee hearing and at the very least he could have given us some credit for adjusting the rates subsequently in view of the evidence put forward. I appreciate his general support for the bill.

para.tab: As far as Senator Margetts is concerned, it is government policy, and it has been for a long time, in relation to avgas. I would like to see Senator Margetts put the argument to the aviation industry in Australia that it is energy inefficient, et cetera. It would not be something that would be readily received. I accept the fact that the excise rate on avgas is about half the excise rate on petroleum. But, in a country such as Australia, aviation is a most efficient form of travel—the only form of travel for many.

In excise terms, though it may be getting a cheaper rate, in relation to the overall cost to the community, the impact of having an efficient, effective aviation industry provides wider social benefits as well as economic benefits to the community. I do not think you can ignore that impact. So I do not think you can automatically take a pure environmentalist view about saving fuel consumption, given the broader social impact of not having an efficient aviation industry in Australia. Nevertheless, I am sure that from time to time you will continue to put that viewpoint. I commend the bills to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time, and passed through their remaining stages without amendment or debate.
