:
That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on behalf of the opposition and its veterans' affairs spokesman, Mr Wilson Tuckey, on the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3). I am pleased to be able to speak on the bill because the provision of services for our veterans and their families has always been an area of great concern to me' going back to the years I spent as the opposition spokesman on veterans' affairs. It is especially appropriate this year, marking 50 years since the end of the Second World War with the Australia Remembers commemoration, although part of this bill deals with matters going back to the end of the First World War. It also deals with more contemporary issues such as service in Cambodia under the auspices of the UN peacekeeping efforts over the last few years.

para.tab: This bill amply demonstrates the range of issues we have to consider when legislating on matters affecting the veteran community. It is a reflection of the length of time over which Australian service people have been putting their own lives on the line for this country. It is a reminder of the duty we have to ensure that those people who gave so much for their country are suitably catered for in the period following their active service. The provision of care and services through departments such as Veterans' Affairs is the very least we can do to repay our debt of gratitude to our fellow countrymen.

I turn my attention first to the Anzac hostel. Under this bill, the legal and beneficial ownership of a property is vested in the Repatriation Commission. The hostel, located in Brighton in Melbourne, has an interesting history. It was established in 1918 through a gift of #25,000 from the Baillieu family to the Australian Soldiers Repatriation Fund. The purpose of the gift was to provide a hostel for totally and permanently incapacitated ex-servicemen from the First World War, which was a terrible conflict in terms of the numbers of casualties suffered by our country and by others. It is always a moment for reflection on Anzac Day when the surviving veterans, fewer each year, take their place in Anzac Day marches around the country. The Brighton hostel was one of many Anzac hostels spread across the different states. I understand it is now the only remaining one. It has been described as a showpiece of Anzac hostels. So it is an important part of our heritage, not only for its physical qualities but also as a reminder of the Australian soldiers who have been housed and cared for there.

The proposed amendment in this bill gives the legal and beneficial ownership of the property to the Repatriation Commission. It removes the trust covering use of the hostel which has restricted the options available to the Repatriation Commission for the provision of aged care facilities for veterans. It gives the commission more room to move over whether to retain or sell the hostel and, if the hostel is sold, how the proceeds of the sale can be applied. The original trust specified the way in which the sale proceeds must be disbursed in accordance with the original intentions of the donors back in 1918.

This amendment will allow the commission to sell the hostel and do as it deems best with the proceeds. I understand that the intention of the Repatriation Commission is to seek the preservation of the heritage value of the building and to allow the continued use of the site for the provision of care for ex-service men and women. The opposition has no problem with that. Obviously, circumstances have changed since the original gift was made and the donors could not have foreseen the needs of ex-service people further down the track. Indeed, the notion of a second world war two decades later would have been a complete surprise. After all, the war that these First World War soldiers fought was described as `the war to end all wars'.

It is intended that the Repatriation Commission will consult with ex-service organisations and health groups for the continued use of the Anzac hostel as a care facility. Again, the opposition has no problem with that. The Repatriation Commission must have the ability to manage the hostel in the best way possible and, if this amendment gives the commission that ability, well and good. However, I would add a note of caution. Whatever course of action the commission decides to follow, it must keep the best interests of veterans in mind. This amendment gives the commission the ability to exercise its own judgment on the future of the hostel, and it must do so wisely.

The bill also makes a number of other amendments to the 1986 act. They include obligations on recipients to provide information or to request the person to appear before a DVA officer. This information can be requested under existing law, but it only provides for criminal penalties if there is a failure to do so.

The new clause, which will duplicate the existing clause, replaces the previous criminal penalties with an authority to cancel or suspend pensions for failure to comply with an order to supply information. That is a welcome change. It is highly inappropriate for a department such as Veterans' Affairs, given the nature of its constituency, to have the power to resort to criminal sanctions to get information from benefit recipients. Dealing with any government department can be an intimidating experience for those of us unaccustomed to the workings of bureaucracy, and the old and frail are particularly vulnerable. The threat of a criminal penalty only worsens the situation.

There are amendments also which maintain the `voluntary quotation' status of the tax file number scheme. The amendments change the way in which the provisions affect a person who does not have a tax file number. If a person who applies for a service pension or allowance—which are dependent upon an income test—does not have a tax file number, the secretary to the department will, in future, have the power to request that person to apply to the Commissioner of Taxation to get one. The secretary may not compel the production of a tax file number. However, the reality is that a person who fails to comply with such a request will have their pension or benefits cancelled.

There is also an amendment which will align the Department of Veterans' Affairs with what happens in Social Security in terms of the use of documents as evidence. The amendments will provide that a signed official departmental document is prima facie evidence of the facts and will allow the Repatriation Commission to prepare a statement of the total benefits paid to a person for any given period. That replaces the previous time consuming process which required that any statement concerning the amount of pension, benefit or allowance paid to a person must contain an itemised list of the payments made each fortnight before it can be accepted.

I would like to spend some time now addressing one amendment which has caused some concern. This is the amendment which sets out the final date for Cambodia as an operational area. It is an important issue, because it is the category of operational area which affects the level of entitlements to which any member of the ADF who went to Cambodia might be entitled.

An operational area is a warlike situation. This bill sets the cessation date for Cambodian service as an operational area, or warlike situation, as 7 October 1993. That date is the official date of the UN cease-fire, but, as anyone who has paid even the slightest attention to the Cambodian situation over the last 12 months would be well aware, that does not mean peace has finally broken out in Cambodia.

In fact, the dangers to Australians in Cambodia, both service personnel and civilians, are in many ways as great as ever. The Khmer Rouge, in particular, has continued its campaign against the Cambodian government and foreigners in the country. There have been a couple of tragic cases involving Australians in Cambodia. We all know of Kelly Wilkinson and David Wilson who were kidnapped and killed along with other foreigners.

The Khmer Rouge was making ransom demands to help it continue fighting the Cambodian government, and has issued chilling threats against foreign military personnel providing non-lethal military assistance to the Cambodian armed forces.
Australians have been threatened, and only a few days ago the Khmer Rouge was telling US military advisers to get out of the country or face retribution. The warning was to the effect that, `If America does not abide by this warning, the Cambodian people will crush your heads. This is a right of self-defence of Cambodian people.' So the message went, as monitored on Khmer Rouge radio. It was almost identical to the threat issued earlier against Australians.

These were issues that I raised late last year, when I called on the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) to spell out clearly the government's strategy for dealing with Cambodia. That followed comments by the Thai military chief that the provision of non-lethal aid to Cambodia would increase the risk of escalating the fighting between Khmer Rouge and government forces. These matters are highly relevant to the bill under consideration.

As it stands, any Australian personnel serving in Cambodia now or in the future are deemed to be in a `hazardous' area rather than an `operational' or warlike area. I would suggest, on the basis of the nature of the threats made against Australians and the obvious willingness of Khmer Rouge members to carry them out, even against innocent and unarmed civilians like Kelly Wilkinson and David Wilson, that Cambodia is more than just a hazardous situation.

It is something we will have to monitor very closely, especially given the fluid state of affairs and the sudden changes that can occur in that part of the world. I remind the Senate of the masses and masses of landmines that are still spread indiscriminately around that country, by which any of our servicemen as well as civilian visitors could be injured.

It is essential that this amendment ensures that service personnel who do go to Cambodia are entitled to the kind of assistance which reflects the dangerousness of the situation in which they serve. We should not let the overly confident judgments of the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Evans, obscure the reality of the military situation in Cambodia and, as a result, diminish the entitlements to which service people would be eligible further down the track.

The coalition supports this bill, which is mostly composed of housekeeping measures which we hope will result in better outcomes for our veteran community. I close, however, with a warning to the government. We in the opposition, as always, will be watching carefully how they deliver for veterans, who have every right to expect to be treated with respect, dignity and fairness by the government on behalf of the rest of the nation.

talker.name: Senator SCHACHT
talker.role: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

talk.start.para: —I thank the opposition for its support of the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1994 [1995] and I thank Senator Newman for her contribution. I take this opportunity to speak on one part of the bill. The second reading speech has been tabled and explains all the detail of the various aspects of the bill, about which Senator Newman has also spoken. But I cannot let go this opportunity to make some mention of the Cambodian provision of the declaration of the operational service period. I do so because, during the 1980s and early 1990s, I visited Cambodia on three occasions on a private trip. The situation in Cambodia has always been of interest to me and like most Australians I wish for a peace settlement in that country.

para.tab: When I visited in 1992 I had the opportunity to see the Australian soldiers, as part of the UN peacekeeping force, operating in the country. It was a very proud moment for me to see the Australian soldiers operating in Cambodia from their base in Phnom Penh; to visit Battambang and see the large base they had there; to see the role they had taken, in very difficult circumstances; and to realise that most of our soldiers were communications experts who were operating in small groups of one or two spread through the country, in isolated positions with very little security of numbers around them. They took on that job and that ensured that the UN force had effective communications across the country, and made the task of carrying out the UN mandate so much easier.

I was also impressed by a number of the soldiers I met in Battambang who had gone further than their normal duties by carrying out, in their own way, programs of support for local villagers, particularly children. I was very pleased to note that one supporter of the great Australian football game was teaching Cambodian kids how to play Aussie rules football. I arranged to send some football gear from South Australia, so I hope that in some obscure village of Cambodia there is some kid wearing an Adelaide Crows jumper today.

talk.start.para: —I sent them netballs.

—Senator Newman said that she sent netballs. These actions show Australians at their best. I am not talking about my contribution as a politician, but about the contribution of the service people, because what they did is beyond the normal call of duty. I was very proud to be able to visit Cambodia and to see the recognition, by the ordinary people of Cambodia, of Australia's contribution: the role not only of our soldiers but also of our aid agencies who operated in Cambodia under very trying circumstances in the 1980s. The agencies were often under great threat, but they provided humanitarian and developmental aid to the Cambodian people. Although all of us are disappointed that there is still a reluctance and a recalcitrance on the part of the Khmer Rouge to accept the peace outcome and the election result, and although there is killing going on, the situation certainly is better than it was in the 1980s.

para.tab: From a personal point of view and from my point of view as a minister of the Australian government, I put on record my personal appreciation and the government's appreciation of the Australian servicemen and servicewomen who served with such distinction in Cambodia.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

:
That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —The Asian Development Bank started functioning in December 1966 with its headquarters in Manila in the Philippines. The bank is actually owned by 37 countries from the Asian region and by 16 countries from outside the Asian region. It is a development finance institution and it has principal responsibility for promoting the economic and social progress of its developing member countries in the Asian and Pacific regions.

para.tab: One of its difficulties is that the ADB's geographic boundaries are expanding all the time. For example, membership stretches from tiny Pacific states such as the Marshall Islands, to Micronesia and Indonesia; also to China, India, Afghanistan and Mongolia, to name a select few.

There have always been tensions in the bank. Its current philosophy is tending to promote development that not only alleviates poverty but also lays the groundwork for market forces to operate within Asian regions. The bank is now developing much more of a social consciousness than it did in the past. It is true to say that there is less agreement today on whether the bank should remain as a big spender in physical terms, or whether the issues of health, environmental resources and human resources will take a more prominent role.

The point of the Asian Development Bank (Additional Subscription) Bill 1994 which is before us is that this bill sends a clear and positive message to the rest of the world, and particularly to the region, that Australia is shouldering its share of responsibilities for lifting the living standards of the people of Asia and of the Pacific region.

On the other hand, we must acknowledge that the bank's contribution, in the overall terms of meeting the demand, is a very small one. The fact that Australia does hold 102,370 shares in the Asian Development Bank is important. Although the holding represents only six per cent of the total subscribed capital, it is nevertheless the fourth largest regional shareholder of the Asian Development Bank and it is an important part of Australia's multilateral development program.

This bill is not a very long one, merely a couple of pages. However, within those pages, it allows the Treasurer—who, incidentally, is a member of the Board of Governors—to make the necessary agreement with the Asian Development Bank for Australia to purchase its further entitlement of 2,047 additional paid-up shares and 100,323 additional callable shares of its capital stock in the market. This purchase will enable the bank to develop programs and to assist in improving the standard of living in many countries of the Asia-Pacific region.

I wish to name a few of the bank's achievements since 1966. It has had 173 irrigation and rural development projects; 89 fisheries, livestock and forestry projects; 118 projects for industrial crops; and 169 power projects. It has been heavily involved in the production of gas and coal. In the social infrastructure, there have been 82 water supply and sanitation projects which have benefited something like 100 million people. There have been 71 education projects which have rehabilitated people. They are just a few of the very positive things that the bank has done.

To bring it more up to date, the Asian Development Bank gave a high priority to a highway project which was estimated to cost $US18.6 million, linking Bangkok via Phnom Penh to Vung Tau just north of Ho Chi Minh City in Vietnam. Furthermore, the bank initiated the cooperation between Thailand, Burma, Cambodia, Laos and Vietnam in 1993 and coordinated meetings up to the most recent undertaking. The Asian Development Bank's goal is to use existing infrastructure and to upgrade it instead of building new roads. Other upgrade projects earmarked for early implementation include the east-west corridor project from Thailand through Laos to Vietnam, estimated to cost almost $US50 million.

By purchasing these shares, the benefits will not only be seen in the Asia-Pacific region but also in our country. Australia will benefit from the activities of the Asian Development Bank as major procurements from Australia by the Asian Development Bank cover goods, related services, civil works and consultancy services, which benefit Australian farmers, Australian workers and, most importantly, Australian jobs. The ability to provide a reciprocal benefit to Australia as well as to foreign aid projects is undoubtedly a move in the right direction.

The bank is governed by a board of governors which only meets once a year. However, its day-to-day activities are actually governed by a board of 12 directors who are full time in that area. The opposition does not oppose the bill but we wish to bring to the government's attention the 102,370 shares that Australia owns in the Asian Development Bank. The amount that has already been paid is $168.8 million and the remaining $1.237 billion is subject to call. As yet, a call on the balance of those funds has not been made due to the bank's prudent financial policies and heavy levels of reserves. Some people have criticised that its lending policy has not been liberal enough given the adequacy of those reserves.

As a major player in the Asian Development Bank, Australia should take up the opportunity to increase its shareholdings at this stage. However, even though there are good reasons for being involved in the Asian Development Bank, the Asian Development Bank has been seen to be using a considerable amount of its funds on administration. Perhaps the greatest benefit that Australia could provide to this bank is to seek the assistance of some of the major Australian banks such as the National Australia Bank or a consortium of Australian banks which have world class expertise in cost minimisation programs through the use of electronic facilities. The cost of administration is a major concern to the coalition and to a number of other member contributors from the west. We believe not enough attention has been focused on getting on top of cost containment. There has been a degree of lavishness in the construction of the headquarters of the Manila bank. In fact, it was reported by the Hyundai company—the major contractor on that headquarters—that at one stage it received on average something like seven major changes to the design plans of that bank each working week which added considerably to the blow-out of the cost and also to the time that it took to construct the new headquarters.

We do have to acknowledge that during the 1980s in some ways the Asian Development Bank really did lose its way. Its methods and its missions were frequently called into question. So the challenges of the 1990s are really going to be in mediating what I term a balance between public and private sector development and developing more of a social conscience.

To be fair, and a lot of its critics do not acknowledge this, the bank does have a soft lending sector. The bank, with its headquarters in Manila, is at the centre of the fastest growing region of the world, where both west and east have major strategic and economic and other interests. With this scenario, it is not surprising that amongst the various members there is a bit of a push-pull type of mentality. There is some concern in some quarters about the influence of Japan on the bank's activities, particularly with the previous head who was seen to be surrounding himself too much with Japanese advisers to the exclusion of people from the rest of the region.

The question also has to be asked as to whether a number of the other—what I might term—economic Asian tigers that have had very high rates of growth in recent times are actually pulling their weight sufficiently in relation to the bank's activities. Some of the critics have said that because of Japan's involvement it has been a major beneficiary, perhaps more so than a number of the other contributing countries, in terms of the consequences or flow-on effects of its particular programs.

One of the difficulties that is going to be facing many of these countries that are emerging from difficulties—and I refer to Vietnam and Mongolia, and even Afghanistan, India and China—is that the reason for the success of some of the so-called Asian tigers of the past has been that the rest of the world has given these countries fairly open access for their exports. The question remains: are we tending to move to blocs which may tend to restrict access to the goods of some of these newly emerging countries that really do need to export to raise the standard of living of their people? The challenge will really be whether the rest of the world will provide the degree of open access that in the past enabled the success of countries like Taiwan, Korea and Japan.

A lot of the criticism of the bank has surrounded its lending policies. For many years there was a difficulty in terms of China, India and Vietnam. It does not seem to be any coincidence that the opening up of lending by the bank to those particular countries coincided with or followed very closely behind Japan's policy of lending directly to those particular countries. That initially met some resistance from countries such as the United States of America, but fortunately that has tended to pass in more recent times. Some of the bank's Western donors, particularly the United States, have questioned the value of some of its loans. As I have said, they seemed to benefit principally the Japanese contractors more than the borrowers.

A further criticism is that the bank is not nearly tough enough in linking loans policy to policy reforms. If one compares the Asian Development Bank with the World Bank, then clearly the Asian Development Bank falls well behind in this regard. It is a sensitive point, but on the other hand we have got to acknowledge that the Asian Development Bank does not have the financial or political clout of some of the bigger lenders like the IMF or the World Bank.

Further doubts surround the quality of the project management ability of the Asian Development Bank, in terms of its ability to properly evaluate the project loans it makes and to oversee the project management. In recent times, of the 54 projects which the bank's in-house team evaluated in one particular year, only 18 were deemed to be a success. I mentioned earlier the mismanagement of the construction of its own headquarters a number of years ago.

There has also been argument about the bank's lending policies and whether it should really be attaching conditions to loans, particularly to countries such as China and India. Some of the shareholders of the bank have believed that the bank should have stipulations that the lending should be directed more towards social problems, and that has not always been well received by some of the recipient countries such as India and, in particular, China. But there are other associated problems, because the Chinese wanted access to soft loans which were available from the Asian development fund, which is controlled by the bank. Such a request is also complicated by the fact that when China gets soft loans, India wants the same access.

It is not an easy area for management, because it is continually beset by problems. There are some notorious failures, and I think it would be remiss of us not to draw attention to those, too. For example, in Nepal there was a paper mill in an area where there was no pulp available. The success rate of projects is perhaps not increasing. In fact, according to a number of observers it might even be going in the other direction.

I have mentioned the scope of the problem in terms of geographical dimension, but increasingly the bank is venturing into more difficult terrain. Mention has been made of Cambodia or Kurdistan and it is certainly harder to work there than, for example, in relatively developed places like Indonesia and Thailand. But at the same time, the private sector capital flows are increasingly into infrastructure, so the bank's philosophies are tending to change.

Perhaps, given the limited amount of time available, I should indicate that the bank is supposed to be about developing and about alleviating and overcoming poverty. The question is frequently asked in Australia: is the Asian Development Bank a worthwhile recipient of part of our aid budget? I think we have got to be somewhat careful because currently circulating within the parliament is a letter directed to the IMF and other institutional lenders requesting a greater priority on social issues. We have got to approach such letters with some degree of caution, because while this might be desirable we must not jeopardise the economic wellbeing of such banks. In many areas the bank has been regarded as a soft touch. When we look at their record of bad debts or slow payments, the question of bringing those to account is a further worry. Despite economic factors there is undoubtedly a need for proper projects directed to health, education, environment and enhancing the role of women as part of a development bank.

The social needs are great but the problem that I am raising is that it is often very hard to make such lending profitable. Whether we should be developing other arms or other institutions to fulfil grand social objectives does need to be asked. What I am saying is this: let us not have an uncritical approach to this lending, particularly at a time of economic stringency in Australia. The Opposition supports the bill.
(Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Before I briefly give the Greens' position on the Asian Development Bank (Additional Subscription) Bill 1994, I wish to mention a couple of points that Senator Watson has brought up. He mentioned that we have got to be concerned, if we look at the social values that we apply to our support or otherwise of the Asian Development Bank, not to jeopardise the economic viability of the region. I really do not think there is any evidence at all, from looking at projects which are regionally based or community based, or from looking at the benefits to women in the community, that those kinds of projects are less viable or are going to bring fewer economic benefits to the region than projects which are largely imposed from on high. In fact, there is quite clear evidence that the ability of people to pay back loans is much greater when the proposals are community based than when they are imposed from on high in sometimes unaffordable projects.

para.tab: While I recognise that the Asian Development Bank (Additional Subscription) Bill is non-controversial in this place, because it has the support of at least both major parties, I would like it to be noted on record that the Greens (WA) oppose this bill. The reason we oppose this is that the Asian Development Bank, the ADB, operates on the pretext of being foreign development aid. It is included in the foreign aid budget as `multilateral aid'. Yet it is one of the fairly suspect aid agencies that appear to be imposing social and economic policies on other nations in the interest of supposedly improving their economic environment.

I am horrified by Senator Watson's comments that the Asian Development Bank is a soft touch, is not tough enough and is falling behind the IMF and the World Bank in enforcing such things as structural development. There is a huge amount of growing criticism of the IMF and the World Bank and, if the Asian Development Bank were to get any worse in that direction, I would be even more horrified that Australian money was being used.

Many of these structural adjustment programs do not work for the people of a nation, but, instead, work to make them poorer, reduce access to education and health, and often open them to international exploitation. If senators do not think that is true, ask some of the people in New Guinea who have had their so-called free education increased 400 per cent and are now required to pay 400 kina. This is a requirement of an international aid agency such as the IMF, the World Bank and the Asian Development Bank.

In this respect, the Asian Development Bank is very similar to, and works in conjunction with, the World Bank and the IMF. It is not foreign aid. The fact that Australian interests in the ADB are represented by Treasury rather than Foreign Affairs and Trade or the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Islander Affairs (Mr Bilney) is indicative of the real agenda of this organisation. We suspect it also means that Australia, through the Treasury, is pushing for just the sort of structural adjustment regimes that are creating the mounting criticisms of these organisations.

The Asian Development Bank is also strongly involved in several specific projects to which we object. Among the worst is support for major dams, such as the Thuen Hinban Dam, to be built in Laos across the Mekong, the Sekong and their tributaries. Most people who have studied even casually the record of international development will have some understanding of why we are questioning these projects. The record on dam projects has generally been atrocious. Often projects are poorly conceived, having huge technical problems within years. It is no wonder money cannot always be paid back.

Dams often have huge biological impacts, not only in terms of general ecological considerations but also through things like the spread of schistosomiasis to human populations and other unforeseen health impacts. Then there are the well-documented impacts on communities, on occasions relocated at gunpoint to shanty towns, if they are lucky, or simply abandoned to make their way as landless poor to the slums around big cities. While awareness of these problems has raised them to international prominence, it has not stopped international development banks from supporting them directly and indirectly, with devastating consequences.

In Laos over a dozen large dams are proposed for the Mekong-Sekong area. Virtually all of them are to provide power for Thailand. The Mekong-Sekong river system is, to freshwater biologists, what the Amazon is for terrestrial biologists. For example, while there are only 27 freshwater fish species in Australia, the Mekong River Basin is estimated to have over 1,000 species. It is an incredibly diverse aquatic and jungle ecology. The rainforest there is a largely pristine habitat for the largest populations of wildlife in Indochina, including tigers, leopards, elephants, guar, bantang, Asiatic black bears, gibbons, and other rare mammal species, as well as tens or hundreds of thousands of plants, insect, bird and reptile species, many of which are rare or endangered. Yet the plan is to fill the area with dams, with 12 on the Sekong alone.

The Thuen Hinban Dam has been identified as having a serious impact on important wildlife habitat immediately upstream. The Nam Kading forest, in the most important of 17 identified forest reserves, is immediately downstream. I understand that the Asian Development Bank has already given a $60 million subloan to this project. While the Asian Development Bank is not always directly contributing to all of the dams, neither has it considered the total impact of so many dam projects in such a small area. These include the Nam Cham project and the already heavily criticised Nam Theun 2 Dam.

Not only is the power from the dams mainly going to Thailand rather than Laos, but so are the trees. An entire industrial estate is being built in Thailand to process the logs from the operation. Coincidentally, this is just across the wonderful new bridge we built, and, also coincidentally, many of the dams are being built by Australian companies such as John Holland, Transfield, and HEC Enterprises, the company that was to have built the Franklin Dam in Tasmania. Of course, Thailand needs the trees now that it is not so easy to get access to Cambodian forests.

The Asian Development Bank is also involved with support of various sorts for the Salween Dam in Burma, again to supply Thailand with power; and the Martaban Gas pipeline between Thailand and Burma. It thus continues to assist Thai de facto support for SLORC. The deal is basically that Thailand gets Burmese teak, gas and power, while SLORC gets much needed capital.

In our opinion, the Asian Development Bank is neither a socially nor an environmentally responsible organisation. Therefore, to commit $A33 million or $US24.7 million in paid-up shares, and another $A1,614 million or $US1,210 million in callable shares cannot be justified.

Whilst I will not be calling for a division on the Asian Development Bank (Additional Subscription) Bill 1994, because it is a lunchtime bill, I ask that the opposition of myself and Senator Chamarette be noted.

talk.start.para: —The purpose of the Asian Development Bank (Additional Subscription) Bill 1994 is to authorise the Treasurer (Mr Willis) to enter into an agreement with the Asian Development Bank for the provision of additional capital to the bank. The agreement will allow Australia to purchase its entitlement of 2,047 additional paid-up shares and 100,323 additional callable shares in the capital stock of the bank. It also empowers the Treasurer, where appropriate, to issue promissory notes to the bank in payment and appropriates the funds necessary.

para.tab: The Asian Development Bank was established in 1966 to provide multilateral development finance and to encourage social and economic development in the Asia-Pacific region. Australia played a very important role in the development of the bank, and it is one of the major shareholders. The bank has always been one of those world regional banks with which we have had, as a country, the closest association. The bank has grown over time and it now has 55 member countries, of which 37 are members from the region. Of its members, 33 were classified as developing countries in 1993.

I support very much the remarks of my colleague Senator Watson in the debate today in saying that the ADB has had a bit of a mixed track record. There have been some projects that have not gone as well as we would have liked. There has been disputation, from time to time, over the prioritisation of its funds, the determination of the projects with which it should be associated, and which of those projects it should fund.

It seems to me that, in the comments made by Senator Margetts, she was placing a little too much reliance on just one aspect of the bank's project work; in particular, she paid attention to the development of dams. The ADB is, of course, a much more broadly based bank in terms of its activities than that.

Overall, the ADB has been a success, but there is room for improvement. It can be fairly criticised—as Senator Watson did—in terms of top heaviness in some of its administrative structures, and there is certainly scope for improvement. Australia has a very important role in the bank. We are an important player in the region, and we have a very positive opportunity to play an increasing part there.

The bank is, of course, in that sense, a major institution in Australia's multilateral development program. We hold six per cent of the bank's capital, which is valued at $US1.4 billion. Of that amount, $US168.8 million has been paid to the bank and the remainder is subject to call. We are the fifth largest shareholder in the bank after the United States, Germany, Japan and Canada, although there may be one other shareholder.

In May 1994, the ADB Board of Governors approved the resolution to double the general capital of the bank to $US48.8 billion. That is what this bill is about. Under that arrangement Australia will be entitled to another 102,370 shares. Only two per cent of those will be paid up. The remainder are callable, in line with our pre-existing situation. Australia has supported the increased ADB capital proposal. We on the coalition side support that expansion in the capital of the bank. So far as the financial aspects for Australia are concerned, the $US24.69 million required under the paid-up arrangement will be payable over a 10-year period, and it is envisaged that this will occur in six equal instalments beginning this year.

The coalition supports the bill, though I would draw to the government's attention the comments that have been made about the scope for possible improvement in the operations of the bank and the role that Australia may be able to play in fulfilling that.

talker.name: Senator SCHACHT
talker.role: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

talk.start.para: —I appreciate the comments made by senators in the debate. In 1989 I was a member of the subcommittee of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade looking at Australia's overseas aid program. We took extensive evidence from Australians who previously worked at the Asian Development Bank, and to say that we received a sorry tale of maladministration would be an understatement. I think our report reflected that at the time when it was tabled. As a member of that subcommittee I was one of those people who expressed strong comments and criticism similar to what other senators have expressed here today.

para.tab: There is no doubt that in those days the bank was top-heavy in administration, and though there has been considerable improvement I think it still is. The issue of salaries, conditions and perks paid to the permanent staff is somewhat obscene compared with the issues they are trying to address in helping the very poorest in developing countries get a better deal in the world. I want to point out to senators that the government is aware of this criticism. Recently Australia voted against salary increases for the staff and executive directors of the ADB and the World Bank, and abstained from a recent ADB vote on the administrative budget to demonstrate our displeasure at the salary decisions previously approved.

The appointment as our representative at the Asian Development Bank of Peter McCawley, the former deputy head of AIDAB—a man with a development background—was a very welcome move indeed. Again, one of the criticisms of our 1988 report was that we had always been appointing people from Treasury. Commendable and as experienced as they were in Treasury matters and matters of international finance, their experience in development matters was much more limited. I support strongly the view of the committee that the ADB is a development organisation and not a banking institution, and our representatives should reflect those skills on the development side. As I understand it, Peter McCawley was the first non-Treasury officer to be appointed as our permanent representative for a term of office, and as such I think his appointment was welcome indeed. As one who knows Peter personally, I suspect he would have taken some pleasure in voting against the salary increases and the perks that go with it at the Asian Development Bank.

It is interesting to note that from 1989 to 1993 Australian procurement from the ADB exceeded the contribution by Australia to the ADB by $170 million. One of the criticisms that we had in the late 1980s was that Australian organisations were not getting a proportionate share of the contracts compared with our contribution. Most people believe the ratio should basically be one to one. I think we have seen a big improvement since then. Australian organisations are now getting a higher proportion, not because we are rigging the process but because we have actually got the skills in our organisations—the business community, aid agencies and so on—to know how to put forward the best proposals to meet the changing needs for aid in the developing world.

I have always—and I think others have too—had a view that the organisations of the Asian Development Bank can be easily criticised. I have made it clear that the government has accepted that. It is reflected by some of the things we have done recently. However, the Asian Development Bank is a multilateral aid agency where governments are represented. It is the best we have got going in the region in conjunction with the World Bank and it is therefore supported. We have always taken up every demand on a call since 1966 and that means we are now the sixth biggest shareholder. We have always accepted that responsibility. Though, at times, there have been criticisms that the money could have been better spent elsewhere in the aid budget, we have stuck with the Asian Development Bank. We have called consistently for reform and improvement and will continue to do so.

We note that the Asian Development Bank is slowly moving, probably not as fast as some of us would like, towards programs of social benefit for communities. That is very necessary. I have always felt that the bank should get closer to programs such as the success, for example, of the Grameen Bank in Bangladesh. It is a bank that is aimed at providing small loans to very poor women in villages in particular. It gives them access to very small amounts of money, maybe no more than $200 or $300, to start a small business. The bank has had an extraordinary success rate at that sort of level of contribution. I think the repayment rate has been over 90 per cent. It has empowered women in the very poorest of circumstances to break through the poverty barrier. Those are the sorts of programs I think the Asian Development Bank has got to support. It must provide the funds for such national institutions as the Grameen Bank in Bangladesh.

I appreciate the comments and the interest of all senators who have spoken in this debate. On behalf of the government, I can assure the senators present that we will continue to keep the pressure up on the performance of this bank, particularly on its management terms, its conditions, the salaries that are paid to its staff and also the evaluation of its projects to make sure there is proper transparency. Every year we have a chance to debate annual reports in estimates committee hearings and so on and I am sure the interest of senators will continue in those forums. I commend the bill to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: —I seek leave for it to be noted that Senator Chamarette and I would like to register a `no' vote on this bill.

para.tab: Leave granted.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

talk.start.para: —by leave—I inform the Senate that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Senator Collins, will be absent from question time today. He is in Western Australia for discussions with the state government on issues related to the forest assessment process set in train by the government. During his absence, Senator Cook will take questions relating to the primary industries and energy portfolio, Senator Ray will represent the Minister for Transport and I will take questions on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer the minister to yesterday's appalling current account deficit of $2.3 billion and to many market economists' prediction that Australia is heading towards a current account deficit a further $2 billion higher at $28 billion than the government's already $8 billion higher revised forecast of $26 billion or six per cent of GDP. In light of the higher revisions to earlier months deficits and the new market forecast, does the minister support the need for the government to review its recent forecast? Does the minister concur with the sentiments of the chief economist of Schroders, Mr Brett Allender, that `If we're not worried about that'—that is, a 6 per cent of GDP deficit in the balance of payments—`I'm sure international investors will start worrying about it as the year goes on'? What action does the government propose to take to correct this appalling situation?

—It is the case that the net income deficit component of the current account is expected to rise in line with increases in world interest rates and increased profitability of foreign firms that are operating in Australia. The balance of payments figures released yesterday, including the upward revisions to the net income deficit component, are consistent with the government's revised forecasts that were released by the Treasurer on 31 January 1995. That much was said yesterday by Treasurer Willis and I am certainly comfortable in confirming that today. The improving international economic outlook—there is no question that it is improving—is expected to increase demand for our exports which, combined with higher commodity prices and, of course, the breaking of the drought, will help offset the impact of a rising net income deficit on the current account deficit in the year ahead.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. For the second day in a row the Leader of the Government in the Senate has shown not one clue as to the underlying problems facing us as a result of this balance of payments crisis. In pointing out that the government has made much of its policy measures to improve our external prospects, is the minister aware of the fact that over the past year the trend in exports has been almost flat whilst during the 1993 election campaign Prime Minister Keating said that exports were going gangbusters. What happened?

—Senator Short does not listen; he just repeats the parrot cries of the rest of his mob, which is all they are capable of. As I said, the improving international economic outlook is expected to increase the demand for our exports right across the spectrum. That is to be combined with higher commodity prices—not just volumes, but prices—and also higher rural returns obviously as a result of the breaking of the drought. All of that gives us plenty of grounds for encouragement—
—Has it broken through yet?

—Something else is broken, but it has nothing to do with the drought in your case. That combination of circumstances does give us grounds for plenty of optimism that there will be a capacity to offset the impact of the rising net income deficit.

para.tab:
Nobody is pretending anywhere that we are comfortable with the size of the current account deficit, but it is a manageable problem for this economy given that every other dimension of the economy, which you utterly fail to acknowledge, is doing so well. Growth is in terrific shape; investment is in terrific shape; inflation is in terrific shape; and employment—and every parrot in the pet shop was talking about unemployment last year, but we cannot get you to talk about that any more—is in good shape. That is the reason we have plenty of grounds for confidence.
(Time expired)

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology. Minister, you would be aware of media reports of a survey by Fleet Systems which shows that fleet maintenance costs and fuel consumption for the latest models of Australian cars are falling. Australian models, in fact, appear to compare favourably with similar imported vehicles. Can the minister advise what the implications are for the Australian industry and this improved quality and cost competitiveness?

—Yes, I am aware of the improvements in fuel economy, efficiency and price in the Australian automotive industry. It is a good reason why Australians should buy Australian when it comes to motor vehicles and any other manufactured goods or services that this country produces.

para.tab: These days, Australia is increasingly recognised as producing goods and services which are invariably better than foreign imports. As a nation we are competitive on cost, on the quality of the products that we produce and on the design input that we insert into those products, and we are better, too, in services and backup. While that is a trend that many Australians recognise—and increasingly that is the case; I think some 73 per cent recognise that buying Australian is buying quality—there are, nonetheless, some who still think that buying foreign is good. Of course, that is not so.

A manufacturer of washing machines in Australia tells me that their product in Taiwan is regarded by the consumers in Taiwan as high quality—better than Scandinavian, better than European and better than North American products. They look for the `Australian Made' logo when they try to assess quality and make the choice. Of course, while some Australians think that buying foreign goods might be more exotic, the truth is that a lot of foreigners think buying Australian goods is best. What goes around comes around and, of course, if you buy Australian goods, you create work in Australia, you help Australian companies grow and you help secure long-term job prospects for the next generation of young Australians.

This question was about the view of the car fleet industry on the fuel efficiency and quality of Australian cars. Fleet Systems is one of Australia's largest car fleet management companies. It has in its stables some 93,000 cars. Its chief executive officer, speaking about the quality of the Australian-made Ford Falcon and the Australian-made Commodore, said, `They are both'—that is, the Falcon and the Commodore—`really fantastic motor cars and I guess we could rightly claim they are world class.' He is in a position, of course, to know. You could equally say that is true of the Australian-built Toyotas and the Australian-built Mitsubishi cars. They, too, are equally fantastic motor vehicles and are of world class.

I think the challenge for all of us is to encourage Australian consumers to recognise the inherent qualities of the Australian product. The government does this through its support of the Australian made campaign. The campaign encourages Australian consumers to take into account the great advances in quality and competitiveness made by Australian manufacturers in recent years.

Since the campaign started, the government has contributed $15 million and the private sector has supported the campaign with funding of $22 million, and this includes licence fees. The campaign, according to a recent consumer survey, means that 73 per cent of customers in this country consider that locally made products are generally better quality than comparable imported products, and the 2,600 licensees who use the `Australian Made' logo employ over half a million Australians and generate $4 billion in sales annually. The research commissioned by the government indicates that an additional $185 million to $350 million per year in sales is generated as a consequence. I commend the buy Australian campaign to the Senate and to Australia.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to Minister Crean's announcement yesterday of ongoing funding for 500 extra higher education places in Queensland. Whilst of course welcoming that announcement, we note that it has taken Labor 12 years to address the problem and that Queensland is still well behind all other states. How does the government intend to fund this expansion when the Department of Finance in its leaked budget document has called for a cut in operating grants to all Australian universities amounting to $131 million, a proposal which is supported by the Treasury and the Prime Minister's department? Will the government be paying for this decision by ripping places out of South Australia and Victoria, as earlier foreshadowed, or by increasing HECS, or by a further overall reduction in the quality of education?

—The government does not support up-front fees for domestic undergraduate students. First-time entrants to university or to a particular university course should not be hindered by their financial circumstance.
—What about HECS?

—Those are fees for a service, not fees in the sense in which we are talking about here and you know it, despite your notorious obsessions. During our term in office we have overseen a dramatic expansion in the number of higher education places. If the opposition were a little more gracious and a little less churlish, it would acknowledge that. Between 1983 and 1993, the number of students in higher education has grown by over 65 per cent.
—Could you try answering the question?
—This is the answer I have got and you will just have to enjoy it. The number has grown from nearly 350,000 in 1983 to over 575,000 last year.
—Mr President, I rise on a point of order of relevance. If the minister missed the question because he turned away, the question was, of course—
—You can't repeat it. That is not a point of order.

—It is. If the answer is not relevant and the minister needs to hear the question again, that is a point of order. The point of order is: how is the government going to fund increased places when it plans to actually reduce expenditure in higher education?

—I am responding to what was clearly implicit in Senator Hill's question about the proposal to charge fees or in some other way increase the returns available to the government from the sector in order to be able to spend the money in the way he is suggesting. I am responding, as I have already, to that particular proposal. We have given institutions greater flexibility and responsibility in managing their financial affairs, including allowing charging of fees for postgraduate students.
—Order! There was a point of order. Have you finished speaking to the point of order?
—I have almost finished answering the question.

—Allow me to rule on the point of order first. On the question of relevance, as I have said I am not in a position to direct a minister how to answer if he is being generally relevant, and I judge the minister to be generally relevant.

—It is as close to the question as you are going to get by way of an answer, so just let me finish. I just wanted to complete making the point that we are prepared to allow institutions themselves to increase their potential for offering further places by getting returns, for example by charging fees for postgraduate students not receiving scholarships and allowing fees for non-award and professional extension courses. In that way there will be a bit more flexibility in the system and a bit more capacity to support more places being made available. If there is anything else I have not responded to, I will do my best to give you a further and better answer. That is perfectly possible and I am happy to respond.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. Will the minister inform the Senate as to whether or not he will be prepared to support the Clean Up Australia Day campaign? Is there any value in raising community awareness of environmental issues by such campaigns?

—The answer to the first part of Senator Carr's question is yes. I might say that that question was all Senator Carr's own work. That will teach him to re-write the questions that are prepared by me! The second part of the question that Senator Carr has asked is very important. This Sunday will be the sixth national Clean Up Australia Day. As the federal environment minister, I take this opportunity to congratulate Ian Kiernan and the organisers of Clean Up Australia Day for the important contribution that they continue to make to changing people's attitudes to the environment. Clean Up Australia Day really does bring the community together. It encourages positive action for the environment, and it also obviously improves environmental awareness in this country.

para.tab: Since its inception in 1989, Clean Up Australia Day has grown enormously. From a clean-up of Sydney Harbour which involved 40,000 people, Clean Up Australia Day 1994 was an event with half a million people participating from 700 towns and cities across Australia. In the past six years, more than two million Australians have dedicated the first Sunday in March to retrieving rubbish from the country's streets, roadsides and waterways. This is evidence that individuals can make a huge contribution towards protecting the environment, starting with their own immediate environment, their own local area.

Protection of the environment is now a very important long-term issue on our nation's agenda, and I believe it is becoming a more important priority for Australians every day. There are a large number of Australians who recognise that the state of our environment directly impacts on our quality of life as well as on the quality of life of future generations. Clean Up Australia Day is one of those occasions that really does offer Australians an opportunity to demonstrate the commitment to the environment that is broadly held in the community, and hopefully many others will join in.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Consumer Affairs. I refer to a Federal Court judgment of 16 December last year which rejected the definition of `Made in Australia' in the government's origin labelling bill, which I note has disappeared without trace after being passed by the House of Representatives. Firstly, does the minister now admit that this is the third Federal Court judgment since 1988 which calls for a stronger definition of `Made in Australia' than the one in the bill? Secondly, will the minister now admit that the Minister for Consumer Affairs misled parliament in claiming that her definition of `Made in Australia' was the same as the Federal Court's? Finally, has the Minister for Consumer Affairs abandoned the bill altogether because it is too hard or is she finally redrafting it so that `Made in Australia' means what consumers and the Federal Court believe it should mean?

—I say at the outset that it is a bit rich for Senator Lees to be raising this issue in this way. I also say that she is wrong. She is wrong about the initial statement she made that the Federal Court has rejected the definition. The Federal Court did not reject the definition. It stuck with the definition. I am saying this in the context that the Federal Court is still hearing this matter on appeal and I cannot go into the facts in great depth.

para.tab: There is no disputing that the Federal Court accepted the public understanding of the term `Made in Australia' as meaning that the product had its essential quality of character made in Australia. That comes out in Justice Davies' decision. Justice Davies went on to find that the koalas in question actually acquired their essential characteristic here, whereas the contention was that they acquired that characteristic overseas. So the definition is not rejected, and our understanding is not rejected; it is just an interpretation of the facts in respect of that legal definition. I suppose that in this sort of area we are used to a degree of a campaign of misinformation, particularly by those on the other side.

I do not often agree with Senator Vanstone, but she understands the morass to which Senator Lees and other Democrats, Senator Boswell and others in the opposition have led themselves into in this area. When one starts to play with definitions and words in this area, it becomes senseless and confusing. I share those words with Senator Vanstone. Her description of the behaviour of the Democrats and some of her colleagues is senseless and confusing. It is senseless and confusing because we are trying to stick to a term that is acknowledged and understood here and internationally as part of the world trade situation that we are operating within.

The proposition of Senator Lees, Senator Boswell and some other mavericks on the opposition leads to nothing but confusion for consumers and the trade in question. She talks about time delays. There have been time delays in this area. Many, if not all, of those time delays have occurred because it has taken so long to get a consistent line from the other side. Changing shadow ministers and positions are reasons for this. The shifting sands of the other side cannot really give us a solid position to basically respond to. But the bottom line of the question is whether the Federal Court rejected the definition. The answer is no.

question.speaker: Lees Sen M.H.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. If it will help the minister, I will quote from the findings in the J Davies, Trade Practices Commission v ODSV Holdings Pty Ltd 1994 decision:

question.para:
I therefore approach this issue by giving to the words used on the label their meaning in ordinary parlance, not the meaning which would be given by the application of the substantial transformation test, or its equivalent, the essential character test which appears in the
Trade Practices Amendment (Origin Labelling) Bill
—

which is the government's bill, which has been through the House of Representatives. I suggest that the minister check not only that but also the previous three decisions in 1986, 1988 and 1990. When will that legislation be here for us to openly discuss and debate these issues?

talk.start.para: —Senator Lees may very well say that, but if she looks at the decision and the objects in question she will find all sorts of other considerations as well. It is true that Justice Davies applied the essential character test and decided, in respect of that test, that the products acquired their characteristic within Australia.

para.tab: Senator Lees should also note in that respect, as I said earlier, that this matter is under appeal. It has been appealed by the particular company involved. The Trade Practices Commission has lodged a notice of contention on the following aspects of the judgment: that His Honour erred in failing to find that the essential character test should be applied; and that His Honour should have found that the koalas acquired their essential character in China and not in Australia. They are the essential questions of fact that are still being resolved in appeal. It is a matter that we really cannot go into.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer to the commission on human rights in East Timor. Can the minister comment on the findings of the Indonesian National Human Rights Commission that human rights abuses did occur in East Timor on 12 January this year when six civilians were shot by members of the Indonesian military. Further, how do these findings relate to the present situation in East Timor? Do the findings of this commission improve the prospects for reconciliation?

—The Australian government very warmly welcomes the Indonesian National Human Rights Commission findings on the 12 January killings in Liquica in East Timor. The full report of the commission has not yet been released, but it announced its basic findings yesterday. In short, the commission found that the six had been shot unlawfully, torture had been used and that they were unarmed civilians. It did not find conclusive evidence that the six were Fretilin supporters, as had been claimed.

para.tab: This is a very important recognition from inside Indonesia that the human rights situation in East Timor remains far from satisfactory. It lends support to the view that the overall situation there has deteriorated since late last year. The Liquica killings are also the subject of an investigation by a military investigative team, which has reportedly concluded that, while soldiers had violated procedures, two of those killed were Fretilin members and the other four were members of a network supporting Fretilin. A recently appointed Military Honour Council, as the terminology goes, is yet to consider the military team's findings. It is not known when it will announce its decisions.

More generally, the human rights commission role in relation to the Liquica killings is also welcome evidence that there is now greater scope within Indonesia for public expression of alternative views on sensitive issues. It has independently found common ground with some of the concerns that the Australian government has been expressing publicly and privately about the deteriorating situation in East Timor. It may take time for more liberal attitudes to prevail. But, as I have constantly said, Indonesia is a society in transition. We should acknowledge those positive trends as well as be quick to react to the less positive ones.

We obviously hope that the Indonesian government will take the commission's conclusions fully into account when it considers its response to the killings, in particular the issue of whether those killed were unarmed civilians.

Might I say again more generally that we hope these findings will encourage the Indonesian government to reconsider its whole approach in East Timor. As I said just a few days ago in Jakarta in my talks with Indonesian Foreign Minister Alatas, a process of reconciliation in East Timor is more necessary now than ever. That needs to involve a massive reduction in the military presence there, as has already been promised by the Indonesian government; recognition of East Timor's distinctive cultural identity; some sensitive economic development which has regard to the distinctive character of the place; and, hopefully, some greater degree of political autonomy as well. A `security approach' will not solve the problems in East Timor. The application of that kind of approach to date has quite an unenviable track record of human rights abuse.

The human rights situation in East Timor is currently under scrutiny at the annual session of the UN Commission on Human Rights in Geneva, which does afford an opportunity to highlight the continuing international concern about the situation there. I hope it may be possible for a consensus resolution to be produced out of the UNCHR meeting. We will just have to await the course of events there.

I repeat that the Indonesian National Human Rights Commission findings are encouraging. I think they ought to be given due recognition and acknowledgment by those people who are so quick to criticise everything that happens in the country. I think there is a current, a mood, of concern there. This is one very overt expression of that, and we ought to welcome it. I do.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Minister, will you rule out that your candidature as Chief Justice of the High Court is, or will be shortly, under consideration by the government?
—Yes.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction. I draw the minister's attention to a report in today's
Australian Financial Review
about a joint union-employer formed company receiving a government grant to finance training programs for the construction industry. Given the recently documented problems in the Australian construction industry over the past several years, how can the minister justify this level of funding?

—Yesterday Mr Free, the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training, and I were able to participate in a ceremony with the Australian construction industry; namely, the union—CFMEU—and the Master Builders Association of Australia. They had come together to form a joint company called Building Employment and Training Australia, or BETA, to look at ways of improving training opportunities for young people joining the construction industry.

para.tab: The objective of the joint company is to have 1,000 new traineeships by the end of 1995. As a result of its proposal, the government was able to provide by NETTFORCE $100,000 to fund the joint venture company. The government was very pleased to see this example of an industry which, despite the fact that only a few years ago it was bedevilled by confrontation and antagonism, can now have both employers and employees working together for the good of the industry itself and which, above all else, is creating employment opportunities for young people in Australia. This also reflects the general improvement in the construction industry in Australia in recent years and, in particular, the success of the reform strategy which this industry has entered into with the Australian government.

Since 1991, with the formation of the Construction Industry Development Agency, known as CIDA, and the operation of the Construction Industry Development Council, we have seen many improvements in the way this industry has been organised and run. There has been major commitment to reform and, as a result, industrial disputes have been substantially reduced—in many cases to almost negligible proportions. We have seen innovation, new techniques of management, new techniques of building itself—all to make our construction industry a much more competitive industry.

As a result, the industry is now a successful exporter of its services and its techniques, particularly in the Asia-Pacific region. That is why in the Working Nation statement of last year we funded the industry for the Asian consortium infrastructure program to a sum of $12 million to encourage Australian construction companies to form consortiums to bid for the big infrastructure programs of the Asia-Pacific region.

As a result of yesterday's meeting of the Construction Industry Development Council to look at the post-CIDA arrangements which will come into effect when CIDA goes out of existence under the sunset clause legislation in June of this year, the industry agreed to form a new National Construction Industry Council made up of about 15 representatives selected from across the industry—people who will have experience, expertise and eminence in the industry—to look at how we can further progress the reform program in a voluntary and cooperative way.

Yesterday was a major day in terms of the funding of BETA, the joint venture of the union and the Master Builders Association, and the creation of a new industry body, the National Construction Industry Council, and I will announce the members of that body in May of this year. This is another step forward in the improvement of what is now a major competitive industry in Australia, the construction industry, that will enable us to get a bigger share of export opportunities as well as providing real dynamic growth within Australia itself.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. Is the minister aware that last week the Prime Minister's piggery group deliberately manipulated the legal system to avoid being found guilty of an uncontested offence of polluting the upper reaches of the Scone water supply in August 1993 when Mr Keating was its half owner? Does the government condone this deceptive legal device of the Keating piggery deliberately not reporting for almost two years the secret transfer of the business to a related company it jointly owned with a Danish multinational company so that a prosecution of the real culprit cannot proceed because it is out of time? What can the government do to prevent such Skase-like activity?
—Just stick to the facts.

—No. I am not aware. Sticking to the facts, I am aware of the continual swill from Senator Baume on the other side. As with the rest of your question, this will be consigned to the bottom of the gutter.

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. It did not take long Senator Bolkus long to get into the gutter himself. The standing orders clearly preclude personal reflections on colleagues. To talk in the way that he did was clearly unparliamentary. If he refuses to answer the question, so be it, but at the very least you ought to tell him to behave himself in a parliamentary fashion.
—Order! I did not take him as referring to the person. He was talking about the question, as I understood it.

—Arising out of your ruling, if Senator Bolkus acknowledges that he was not referring to Senator Baume, then I do not have a quarrel with your ruling. Otherwise, it is quite clear that Senator Bolkus was referring adversely to Senator Baume.
—It is not a question of Senator Bolkus having to do anything. There was no point of order made. I made a ruling.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Ignoring the personal abuse, which I expect from Senator Bolkus, if you do not intend to do anything to stop this situation where there seems to be one law for Mr Keating and another law for the rest of us, will you at least ask the Prime Minister to condemn this conspiracy between his former company and a Danish multinational that perverted the course of justice, or is the Keating government happy to put up with this kind of dishonest manipulation of the legal process?

—Let me just say that out in the public we get judged on the policy initiatives we make, and you get judged on the swill that you throw around. You are notorious for throwing swill, whether it is at Mr Keating or anyone else. We let the court process run itself without interference. You are the one who comes in here time after time throwing unsubstantiated swill out of the gutter. If you want to keep on doing it, it is not just a reflection on you: it is a reflection on your leader in this place, and it is a reflection on your leader in the other place.

para.tab: It is just not on for you to treat private individuals in the way that you do—that is, by smearing them endlessly. You should not do it. Once again let me say something to Senator Baume directly: you are being judged on your performance, and your performance is straight out of the gutter.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. Following moves by your ministerial colleague Mr Tickner to bring one of Florida's most notorious and feared inmates—three-time lifer, murderer and rapist, James Savage—back to Australia to reportedly serve in the medium security prison at Swan Hill, Victoria, I ask: what justifies the enormous expense and sheer effort of the department to bring this killer to Australia? Given that the government is drafting international transfer of prisoners legislation, what criteria is to be used to determine the category of criminals to be brought back to Australia? Is it a possibility that James Savage could return to Australia under your proposed legislation?

—Once you take all the bumph from this question, what you have got is a process which has been agreed to by state and federal attorneys-general. Senator McGauran, what you say may very well be, but you have not provided any previous information to me in respect of Mr Savage. I would not know who he is.

para.tab: Let me say in respect of him and anyone else who may be Australian citizens in prisons overseas, the government has been working on—not on its own, but with state governments—and has achieved, through a cooperative arrangement with state governments, a transfer of prisoners scheme. It is something that has been called for from all sides in this place; that is, we want to put in place a transfer of prisoners scheme operating internationally. In fact, I answered a question about that just a few months ago.

I have got no idea whether any particular individual may or may not be included in the scheme. The scheme is, as yet, not in operation. So, do not run around throwing fear about a particular person coming in. Any person coming in would come in with the cooperation of, and under an agreement with, state governments, and that person would have to qualify under that scheme.

As I said, the scheme is still being developed and is not yet finalised, although we have achieved agreement from state authorities involved in terms of the international transfer of prisoners. I think all but the Northern Territory government have agreed to that. The scheme you are referring to is a cooperative arrangement. Senator McGauran, if you are talking about people coming in under that scheme—and as I say I would not know whether Mr Savage is or is not—you should acknowledge that we have a bipartisan approach on that issue.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Will the international transfer of prisoners legislation have as part of its criteria or as a threshold the return to Australia of murderers and rapists?
—Legislation has not been introduced. You can have a look at it then. You can make a decision as to what should go in it when it comes before the parliament.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. I refer the minister to the program of activities associated with the Australia Remembers celebrations. Can the minister advise the Senate what assistance is being provided by the Australian Defence Force to assist with these celebrations?

answer.speaker: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

talk.start.para: —The Department of Defence is working very closely with the Department of Veterans' Affairs as the Australia Remembers program evolves this year. It should be stressed at the outset that this is not a celebration of hostility or war, but a celebration of the end of an hostility. We will be providing ceremonial support in the various regional cities—bands and honour guards.

para.tab: Mr President, you will be interested to know that we will be providing special support for the celebration in Townsville, which will be one of the major celebrations this year.
