Where we can, we have organised fleet port visits—provided they do not in any way interfere with the fleet's normal operations—to coincide with such celebrations. We are also providing some assistance to those veterans who are going overseas as part of other countries' celebrations.

The major event will be a major celebration in Brisbane on the actual day, 15 August, and the Defence Force will be providing a variety of assets there as part of that particular activity. I should stress that 15 August will coincide with the Kangaroo 95 activities, and no resources or normal assets to be provided there will be diverted to the Australia Remembers program—and I think that is quite proper.
As most senators would know, their colleagues in the House of Representatives will be playing a major role in a whole series of

answer.para: regional celebrations. I believe that it is being done on an electorate basis—all 148 electorates will have their own celebration. This, of course, is prompting every one of those local members to write to me, insisting that we have a flyover, or something else.

para.tab: I have to say that it will be impossible to meet all the demands that are coming in. The meeting of those demands or requests will really depend on the normal operations of the armed forces. Where we can assist without diverting from normal activities we will, and then to others we will try to give a gracious refusal.

talk.start.para:
—My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. Is the minister aware of the editorial column of the
Reflections
newsletter, issued by the Lake Pedder Restoration Committee, in which it is claimed that the legal precedent set by any federal order to drain Lake Pedder will be used in campaigns, including the Murray-Darling river system and the Western Australian wheat belt? What assurances will the minister provide to the Senate that, given his government's willingness to countenance the draining of Lake Pedder, other waterways, irrigation systems, dams and farm lands will not also be subjected to so-called restoration, according to the agenda of some zealots of the Green movement?
—In the first instance, I am not aware of the editorial that Senator Newman refers to.
—I will send you a copy.
—I would appreciate that, Senator. It would have been very useful if I had had it before you asked the question.

para.tab: In relation to the other part of your question, given the complexity of the issue which is the restoration of Lake Pedder, the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts has been asked to inquire into this particular matter, and that inquiry is in progress at this particular time.

Senator Newman, if you would care to read the
Hansards
and follow the issue publicly, the committee is examining a range of issues relating to restoration of the lake. The issues that it is considering are the implications for the future management of the Tasmanian wilderness world heritage area, the potential economic or environmental opportunities and costs that might arise from any proposed drainage or restoration, the adequacy of information currently available to assess the proposal and the need for any further research. That is clearly on the public record.

The committee has called for submissions to its inquiry. I think its closing date has been extended to 8 March. I understand from press clippings I did read that the committee visited Lake Pedder and certainly it held a public hearing in—

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. This is all material which is readily available in the public press. We have all followed it closely. It is not anything to do with the question I asked, which went to the agenda of some of the zealots in the Green movement to move away to sending us back to caves rather than have irrigation.
—Why didn't you ask that question?
—Why didn't you listen to the question? It's there. If you forget, I'll repeat it for you.
—Order! Make your point of order, Senator.

—I asked you to answer: in countenancing the draining of Lake Pedder, are you prepared also to recognise the rest of their agenda, which is to drain the Murray-Darling Basin system, to restore the wheat growing areas of Western Australia, the Warragamba Dam? The list is very long, Minister. Is that what your government is on about?
—There is clearly no point of order.

—I am not countenancing anyone's suggestions or agenda, and I do not intend to. If Senator Newman has a question about what she describes as the so-called `zealots' in the green movement, she should ask them and not waste the time of the Senate.

para.tab: My position, which I have indicated very clearly time and again on the public record, is that I do not intend to comment on this particular matter. I do not feel able, and I am surprised Senator Newman does, to make a definitive view clear on these complex issues. I am quite sure that the inquiry that is being held at this time will assist in the resolution of what I believe are very complex issues.

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Is the minister aware that last night after close of business hours a fax was sent from the Prime Minister's office to the Tasmanian Conservation Trust informing it that cabinet was `disposed' towards releasing a further eight named forest coupes for logging? Is the minister aware that the fax requested a consideration of this proposition and a response by 4 p.m. today and that these coupes are widely dispersed across Tasmania? Is the minister aware that similar faxes regarding another six coupes were sent to conservation bodies in Western Australia, Victoria and New South Wales with respect to the coupes in their states? Why have these coupes been added to the 76 coupes that cabinet was already considering destroying? Does the minister consider that this is adequate consultation?

—As I indicated yesterday, there was some consideration in cabinet the other night of the woodchips issue. Indeed, we did hold initial discussions on some of these coupes on Tuesday evening and agreed to delay a decision on a further release of coupes to allow groups more time to provide comment. The process that has been undertaken is the most feasible available, given the government's desire, which we articulated some time ago, to release some coupes quickly to maintain continuity for the industry where that is environmentally possible.

para.tab: This is the second round of consultations in fact in relation to the particular coupes in question—the second round with the conservation, industry and union groups. While short response times have been provided for, useful comments have been received from all groups, and they have been incorporated into the advice that has been before cabinet and will be coming forward to us again. It is the case that Minister Faulkner and Minister Collins—in the case of Bob Collins, in WA today—are also undertaking personal discussions with interested parties. So I am not going to be any more specific than that in my response to Senator Bell's question.

There is further consultation. The lead times are sufficiently long, we believe, to enable a proper consultative process to take place. Of course, we are talking about a much more extended process over full eight-week periods in relation to the whole number of coupes that are in issue in this particular debate. We will again be engaging in proper process of the kind that has already been outlined by the Prime Minister in relation to those as well.

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I advise the minister, and he no doubt is aware of this, that on 5 February this year the United Arab Emirates Appeal Court ruled that Robert Bowra's sentence be reduced from 12 months to six months. Of course, by that time he had served his time and was due for release. Minister, it has now been over three weeks and Robert Bowra is still in prison, contrary to that ruling in his favour. I ask you, therefore: what is obstructing his release? What is your department doing to secure his immediate release?

—Our understanding is that the case involves what is known as the Diwan—the court of the President—and it was referred back to that court after the appeal hearing for ratification and for the formal issue of a release authority to the prison authorities. We are certainly concerned about the delay in the issue of the release authority. The Australian ambassador in Riyadh made representations to the Diwan, the relevant court, 10 days ago, on 21 February, seeking advice as to Mr Bowra's release date.

para.tab: We have been following the case, as Senator Ellison well knows, very closely. We have made representations of the kind that we have been asked to. I am not sure there is anything more that we can do other than to continue to do what we are doing and to make clear our interest in getting a quick and sensible resolution of the remaining formalities in this matter.

talk.start.para: —Obviously efforts so far are not succeeding. Is it possible, therefore, for the Prime Minister, when he is in Dubai on Monday, to do something by way of a representation to the government so that this Australian can be released from prison?
—I will see what it might be possible to do in that respect. It is our hope, of course, that the matter will be resolved before then. We will be doing our best to resolve this as soon as we can.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Trade. I note that the Minister today launched a report entitled
Trade in service, Australia, 1993-94
. Can the minister explain the importance of the service sector to our export performance both at present and over the long term? Does the report contain trends in our services trade? If so, to what extent might these contribute to the long-term solution to our balance of payments problems? Does the report contain any encouraging news on the trends of our services trade?

—This report is another in the series of reports on various sectors of our export performance. It marks, together with the report on manufacturing exports, which was released recently, a picture of the long-term change in the structure of the profile of our exports and of our economy. It is a slow process to change the structure of an economy, particularly one with such a strong and successful emphasis on commodities, as we have had over the last century or so of our economy and to which we have added recently, as this report shows, a successful tourism sector.

para.tab: What the two reports do reflect is that the structure of the Australian economy, and more particularly our export profile, is moving more towards the rapidly growing areas of world trade—that is, manufactures and services—and our reliance upon our traditional strengths in commodities is being reduced. It is not that we want to reduce our participation in that area, but we are trying to add this new element so that we can get closer to the areas of rapidly growing export. As our profile moves into that area we can take advantage of being, in geographic terms, in proximity to the fastest growing areas in world trade and also our economy will be participating in the fastest growing areas of economic activity. That is where the long-term solution to our serious balance of payments situation lies.

None of these events will turn it around overnight. But the opening up of Australia's economy to international competition in the early 1980s has had, over the succeeding period, dramatic impact upon our services sector, and services exports have been expanding at a greater rate than services imports. We have been improving our balance situation there and at a greater rate than global services exports—that is, our international market share in this areas has been improving.

In fact, for the first time in our history we had a trade surplus for services in the March quarter of 1992 and we are now still reflecting the fundamental change in the structure of our economy. We have dramatically reduced the deficit. It is down to $1.4 billion over the year 1993-94, as reflected in this report, which is down to less than half the size of the deficit of a decade earlier. More importantly, if the trends continue, and the expectation is that they will at this stage, the balance of the international services account will have shifted to surplus by 1995-96, contributing to a long-term solution to our balance of payments situation.

We need to move the goods and services element of our trade substantially into surplus because of the problem of significant net income deficit. Merely balancing our goods and services account will not be sufficient over the medium-term. That is why the emphasis is being shifted to these important areas of manufactures and services, so that when prices improve in our commodities—and, as Senator Evans indicated earlier, the expectations are that they will—we will have improving strengths in our traditional areas of economic activity but also capacity to add to them in elaborately transformed manufactures and services.

The improvement in services is widespread. The greatest strength comes from tourism, but there are some other significant areas to note which are important for jobs in Australia and for quality jobs in Australia—the boom in our education exports from virtually zero to $1.4 billion by 1992. The information technology and telecommunications sector, which has increased tenfold over the last decade in its exports, has set itself an ambitious target of improving fourfold again, to $10 billion by the year 2000. So this report is an important signpost along the road to restructuring the Australian economy and shows significant positive elements.
(Time expired)

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. I refer the minister to the Department of Employment, Education and Training decision, on advice from the Attorney-General, to ignore the decision of the Senate and still refuse to acknowledge married students under 22 years of age to be declared independent for Austudy purposes. I ask the minister: considering the Sex Discrimination Bill was passed in part to prevent discrimination against married people, why will he not seek further exemption from the Sex Discrimination Act so Austudy can be paid to the students in that category?
—Take it on notice.

—That is very good advice, Senator Abetz. I will take the question on notice and come back to you, Senator. I participated in the Senate debate at some length over the issues of Austudy, the Sex Discrimination Act—
—In one ear and out the other.
—Just get on with the answer. Don't get sidetracked.

—Because this is a complex area, I want to make sure I give a considered response in the detail of legal opinion. If I try to anticipate all these issues and the legal advice and I give incorrect advice on any aspect, you will be the first to criticise me. So I will take it on advice and come back next week.

question.speaker: Harradine Sen B.

talk.start.para: —I ask a question about a decision which I believe will cause great exploitation to workers. It may be the most massively problematic decision in the industrial history of Australia. I refer to a statement made by the Industrial Relations—
—Who is the question to, Brian?

—It is to the minister representing the industrial relations minister, Mr Brereton. I quote from the
Australian
this morning:

para.tab: The Industrial Commission yesterday did something entirely foreign in its 90-year history as an interventionist body: it formally abdicated its role as the central mechanism for workplace negotiations in this country.
By its own hand, the commission had redefined employer and employee relations in the labour market, ruling no legislative power exists to force parties to the negotiating table.

question.para:
I ask the minister: why did Mr Brereton this morning in the
Sydney Morning Herald
say that certainty was restored to the bargaining process and responsibility would lie with the parties concerned, when many non-union and union workers are unable to get their employer to negotiate? Is it not a fact that the decision means that it is a dead-set certainty that those workers will be kept trapped in the safety net well below the average wages and working conditions that are contained in the EFAs?
(Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I have not read Mr Brereton's comments in this morning's paper at this stage. One of the great difficulties in this case was the actual case taken by the union to the Industrial Relations Commission. The government found the decision quite confusing and therefore joined in an appeal against it. The government found that the way the decision was written was inconsistent, in its view, with the Industrial Relations Act. Therefore, it supported an appeal against that process. I have not personally had an opportunity to study the decision the commission handed down yesterday nor do I have a brief from the minister with regard to the analysis of it. You have referred to Mr Brereton's comments in the paper this morning, so I will refer the rest of your question to him, get a considered response and get it to you sometime next week.

—Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the
Notice Paper
.

—Yesterday I was asked a question by Senator Ferguson regarding the CSIRO and the International Wool Secretariat/Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation. CSIRO has provided me with an answer to that question. On 23 February 1995, CSIRO dispatched a proposed letter of agreement to the International Wool Secretariat/ Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation concerning CSIRO owned wool funded properties. The content of this proposal was drawn up after extensive negotiations between the CSIRO and the International Wool Secretariat/Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation.

para.tab: The members of the International Wool Secretariat/Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation board are considering this proposal at a meeting in Shanghai in the People's Republic of China this week. Ratification of the agreement is expected shortly. This issue has not affected in any way the normal payment of allocated research grants from the International Wool Secretariat/Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation to the CSIRO during the current financial year.

speech.speaker: Baume Sen M.E.

talk.start.para: —I move:

para.tab: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Bolkus), to a question without notice asked by Senator Baume this day, relating to investments of the Prime Minister.

speech.para: The government's continual condoning of the illegal and improper activities of the Prime Minister's piggery group while Mr Keating was a half owner seems to go on and on. I detailed the latest example in a notice of motion I gave this morning. There has not been one word of apology or admonition from the Prime Minister or his ministers about these repeated breaches of the law while the Prime Minister was a half owner of this piggery. There has not been any criticism by the Prime Minister of his former company's involvement in this latest conspiracy with a Danish multi-national. This has allowed the Prime Minister to escape the humiliation of his half owned piggery, at the time, being found guilty of polluting the upper reaches of the Scone water supply. The Prime Minister has already misled the parliament over his piggery's polluting practices which were admitted by the company during the New South Wales government's commission of inquiry into its expansion plans about 15 months ago.

para.tab: Is it too much to ask the Prime Minister to stop his hypocrisy and come out and condemn what this piggery has repeatedly done? Otherwise, Mr Keating's professed concerns about the environment will be exposed as simply dishonest. He will not allow pollution unless he is the polluter. That is the simple consequence of what has been happening now.

There is no doubt about the facts of this latest example of how the Prime Minister's former company has got around the law. There are plenty of instances where his companies did not get around the law. They were hit with penalties by the Australian Securities Commission for failure to meet the reporting requirements of the ASC. The fact that there were 13 penalties involved seemed to get very little attention in the media. I find that extraordinary. I bet if someone from the Liberal Party was involved in such a matter there would be volumes of headlines about it.

Anyway, there is no doubt about the facts of this present matter to which Senator Bolkus replied with his normal line of personal abuse of me. There was no attempt to address the issues of how the Corporations Law or its administration appear to be effectively got around by those people running the Prime Minister's companies, and about which the Prime Minister apparently feels totally content. He is not prepared to dissociate himself from those activities beyond saying, `Oh, I wasn't in charge of the running of it.' He was a half owner. He has condoned by his silence the dishonest and improper behaviour of this polluting piggery. There is no doubt about the facts.
Last week the New South Wales Environment Protection Authority released a statement entitled `Undisclosed Manoeuvres Frustrate EPA Prosecution'. It states:

speech.para: The New South Wales Environment Protection Authority has withdrawn two prosecutions against Brown and Hatton Group Pty Ltd, in relation to the Parkville Piggery in the Hunter Valley.
The statement refers to EPA Director-General, Neil Shepherd, and continues:
"No-one is denying that the water pollution incidents occurred, and it is extremely disappointing that Brown and Hatton Group Pty Ltd—
that is the company that was half owned by the Prime Minister at the time—
did not inform the EPA of the transfer, when the company received the summons in June 1994," said Dr Shepherd.
"At that point the EPA was still in a position to prosecute the real culprit.
"We will have to consider targeting our legal actions on individual site managers as well as companies if this sort of tactic—
a crooked, dishonest tactic—
is going to be employed."

Dr Shepherd said when the EPA was investigating reports of water pollution from the Parkville Piggery, it carried out the usual searches to ensure that any action was brought against the correct defendant.
"The Land Titles Register revealed that the piggery was still owned by the Brown and Hatton Group Pty Ltd.

"Throughout the Commission of Inquiry into the proposed expansion of the piggery, Brown and Hatton Group Pty Ltd consistently presented themselves as currently involved with the operation of the site.
"A development application for the site lodged with the local council reinforced this impression," said Dr Shepherd.
"The EPA even wrote to the company in August 1994, to confirm that Parkville Piggery was the business name of Brown and Hatton Group Pty Ltd.
"However, on the morning of the court case, Brown and Hatton's lawyers told the EPA that Brown and Hatton Group Pty Ltd had transferred the piggery and its assets—
The transfer was never lodged.

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

talk.start.para: —Senator Baume's obsession on this subject is getting to the point of paranoid extravagance. There is no foundation for any continued pursuit of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on this matter, as Senator Baume ought to be well aware. At the time of the events to which Senator Baume refers, the Prime Minister was at best a shareholder and a part owner of the company. He had no managerial responsibilities.

para.tab: You know that is the state of affairs, Senator Baume. You have known that from day one, but you have been obnoxiously, offensively, and maniacally pursuing this particular obsession of yours. It has not got you anywhere so far. It will not get you anywhere. It is simply a matter of trawling your snout through the muck trough hoping that something will turn up. It hasn't and it won't. You can sit in the courts of New South Wales all the days of your life, as you apparently were last week, waiting for something to turn up and fall into your hot little hands, but you are not going to get anything out of it. It is a total waste of time. Would you please recognise that you are only making a dill of yourself as you pursue this further. Give it away.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

speech.speaker: Newman Sen J.M.

talk.start.para: —I move:

para.tab: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner), to a question without notice asked by Senator Newman this day, relating to Lake Pedder.

speech.para:
I draw the Senate's attention to the answer given to the Senate today by Senator Faulkner in relation to the publication called
Reflections
, which is the journal of the Lake Pedder Restoration Committee. Senator Faulkner said that he was not aware of the editorial in this publication and I have no reason to doubt him. I will send him a copy of it so that he can read it.

para.tab: In that publication it is quite clearly claimed that the legal precedent set by any federal order to drain Lake Pedder will be used in campaigns which include the Murray-Darling river system and the Western Australian wheat belt. I asked for assurances from the minister that the government's willingness to countenance the draining of Lake Pedder would not mean that these other waterways, irrigation systems, et cetera, would also be subject to so-called restoration.

There is clearly an agenda. When you read this document you see that the agenda is not only Australian but also international. The sad thing is that the federal government, by sending the Lake Pedder issue to an inquiry, has in fact countenanced, in the true sense of the word, the draining. I hope that the government will decide in the end not to, but by sending it to an inquiry and not ruling it out it has in fact given comfort to those who would drain the lake. It should have ruled it out straightaway, instead of which it has put the member for Fraser, Mr Langmore, in charge of an inquiry, which is a bit like putting a child in charge of a lolly shop on an issue like this. His views on Lake Pedder have been put on the public record prior to the hearing and I would have thought this would have given him a conflict of interest.

This editorial has claimed that they have achieved a lot in a short time on the issue of the legal precedent, that it is an issue that is bigger than states rights and that they would intend to move on to places like the wheat belt in Western Australia and the river systems in the cities. In the document are letters from people such as David Suzuki. He stated that he believes Pedder 2000 is ushering in a remarkable new era where we seek to actually restore and heal systems that have been damaged by human activity. Milo Dunphy says that draining Lake Pedder is the best possible start to preventing a Welcome Reef Dam, the raising of the Warragamba Dam, the ecological disaster of the Tully Millstream project in Queensland and a dam in New Zealand. They are saying that after a five-year occupation of the Seve de la Fare Dam site on the upper Loire in France, they have managed to have two big dams, out of four originally planned, totally or partially abandoned.

This goes much further than south-west Tasmania. It is the first shot in a campaign by some zealots in the green movement to pull down man-made structures around the world, irrespective of the purposes they fulfil. For how many decades has this country, this dry continent, tried to focus on water storage? Yet they would prevent new projects for water conservation and they would try to pull down existing ones.

If we allow the first step to be taken over Lake Pedder, we will see the results in other parts of our country because the insatiable demands of some of these people will send us all back to the caves. They want to remake our nation to what it was before white settlement. I do not know how many Australians are prepared to countenance anything like that.

There are no substantial economic or environmental reasons for draining Lake Pedder. There are fantasies. In fact, there are substantial economic and environmental reasons for not draining it, which are being put to the committee. But the federal government, by giving the proposal a semblance of credibility, has unleashed a green monster which, unless it is contained, will affect the standard of living of all Australians.

talk.start.para: —I rise to support my colleague Senator Newman in the remarks she has made in response to an answer by the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner) to a question asked by her earlier. It would seem as though this is not the only example of incompetence in Senator Faulkner's department or the only example of incompetence on the part of the minister himself. We on this side always thought that perhaps we were under the misapprehension that Senator Faulkner's main problems lay with the forestry industry and woodchips. In fact, he seems to have a lot of problems also with lakes.

para.tab: A further example of the incompetence of Senator Faulkner as minister for the environment came to my attention only this morning; that is, a federal government world heritage branch has at the very last minute cancelled a planned visit to the Lake Eyre region to discuss with the local community the proposed world heritage listing. This comes after a local Uniting Church padre travelled some 3,500 kilometres in a week visiting station people to try to convince them that they should meet the Canberra bureaucrats.

As I said earlier, it seems that he has trouble in a lot of areas when it comes to lakes. It seems that these people checked local air strips, transferred personnel, organised accommodation and made arrangements to travel hundreds of kilometres, so the cost and disruption to the people living in these areas has been absolutely enormous. I find it hard to understand the disgraceful actions of this government agency which has put so many people to so much trouble and expense only to have the meeting called off at the very last minute.

It is two years since the people in this area first tried to have consultations with the world heritage agency after this government proposed the world heritage listing of Lake Eyre prior to the election in 1993. After two years, they eventually get the world heritage agency to come to the Lake Eyre region. The people there live in a very sparsely populated area. They get to the stage where they are going to meet these people and, at the very last minute and without any prior knowledge, the agency cancels the meeting, thus causing tremendous expense to the people involved.

The people in the area naturally wondered why, at the last minute, these consultations would not take place. The reason given was that it was considered inappropriate to visit the area at present in the light of recent violence between opposing Aboriginal groups in Marree and the lodgment of a native title claim for Lake Eyre Basin. That is the reason given as to why, after the proposed world heritage listing, the world heritage agency would not even consult with the people in the Lake Eyre catchment area. The people involved have said that, having put this much time and effort into trying to talk to people from Canberra and trying to talk to the agency, if this is the best that the agency—part of Senator Faulkner's department—can do, what is the point of their going to the expense that they have gone to to try to have the consultations over the three-day period? What is the point of trying to go on if things are going to be cancelled at this very late stage?

Senator Faulkner's answer today to Senator Newman and this other example of Lake Eyre serve to show that the minister's portfolio is a shambles and that he presides daily over issues which he is no longer in control of and in which he has no idea what is happening. I do not know what it will be next week, but I am quite sure that Senator Faulkner has reached the stage where the portfolio that he is in charge of is now in charge of him. Unless we get some sensible answers, there is not going to be any cooperation from or consultation with these people. They are so far removed from Canberra and they are having their lives disrupted by agreements and arrangements which, at the very last minute, are put aside by people who show no cause and no care for people who otherwise have no opportunity to have any influence over what is happening in their area.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

speech.speaker: Ellison Sen C.M.

talk.start.para: —I move:

para.tab: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans), to a question without notice asked by Senator Ellison this day, relating to the detention of Mr Eric Robert Bowra in the United Arab Emirates.

speech.para: I remind the Senate that I asked a question of Senator Evans on 7 December last year. At that stage, Senator Evans assured the Senate that the government was doing all it could to assist Mr Bowra. I must say that there was a letter written by Senator Evans, which I acknowledge and appreciate, on behalf of the government, seeking to assist Mr Robert Bowra. Of course, things have changed now. The court has upheld Mr Robert Bowra's appeal. His sentence has been reduced from 12 months to six months. That decision was given on 5 February this year. That date marked the period of exactly six months from the date that Mr Bowra had been arrested, so he had served six months straight and was due for release on that day.

para.tab: It is now over three weeks later, and Mr Bowra still remains in prison. Even if we apply the United Arab Emirates law, which we should really do in these situations—we cannot apply Australian law because it is not applicable—Mr Bowra should have been released three weeks ago. It remains totally unsatisfactory that this man, who has a wife and children in Australia and a business, all of which have suffered tremendously as a result of this, remains in prison. Three weeks might not seem long, but it is an extremely long time to be in a foreign prison without seeing those close to you and without being able to run your business, which I believe in this case has all but totally collapsed.

I therefore impress upon the government the need to do everything it can. I cannot understand why the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) cannot make a quick representation when he passes through Dubai on Monday. Communication could be made at the highest level. It is a golden opportunity. Why not pull out all stops to help this man and his family? It is not just a matter of concern for his family; it is a matter of concern for all Australians. We have an Australian national in a foreign gaol who should have been released over three weeks ago.

I appreciate Senator Gareth Evans's concern about this matter. As I say, I acknowledge the action he has taken previously. But the ante has now been upped. This man is in prison, despite a court ruling in his favour. It seems that what has been done to date is just not good enough. If the ambassador has to sit at the prison door to secure this man's release, he should do so. I therefore call upon the government to increase its efforts to help release Robert Bowra.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

speech.speaker: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

talker.name: Senator GARETH EVANS
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

talk.start.para: —On behalf of the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton), I seek leave to make a statement relating to environmental protection measures concerning shipping in the Great Barrier Reef and move a motion relating to the report.

para.tab: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —I move:

para.tab: That the Senate take note of the statement.

speech.para:
I seek leave to have the statement incorporated into
Hansard
.

para.tab: Leave granted.

The statement read as follows
—

speech.para: Mr President, I rise to make a statement on behalf of the Minister representing the Minister for Transport about shipping in and around our unique national treasure, the Great Barrier Reef.
Presently ships use two routes to traverse the Reef.
What is known as the inner route travels from the Torres Strait in the north, to Gladstone in the south.

The alternative route—the outer route, commences in the Prince of Wales Channel, leaves the Torres Strait at Bligh Entrance, and continues southwards through the Coral Sea to Sandy Cape, just south of Gladstone.
All ships entering and leaving the inner and outer routes have to cross the Torres Strait.

At present, pilotage is compulsory in the inner route between Cairns and the Torres Strait for all oil and chemical tankers and liquid natural gas carriers regardless of size and all other ships over 70 metres in length.
The most hazardous parts of the reef to navigate are in the Torres Strait, and in the northern section of the inner passage.
Narrow channels, strong tides and the presence of fishing boats all enhance the risk of a grounding.
Furthermore in the case of the outer route the process of skirting the reef, and the largely uncharted waters pose a similar risk of grounding.
With some 87 million tonnes of international trade—mostly Australian exports—shipped through the region annually, this ever present danger is a matter of great concern.

Altogether there are some 2100 local and international vessel movements annually, including 1700 through the inner route, 600 of which do not call at any Queensland port inside the reef. This leaves some 400 vessels using the outer route.

Whilst pilotage in the inner route is, as I said, mandatory for all oil and chemical tankers, liquid natural gas carriers and other ships over 70 metres in length, it is not compulsory in the international waters of the Torres Strait.

Each year 30 loaded oil tankers enter the Torres Strait and transit the inner route, while a similar number travel north along the inner route under ballast. Twenty tankers transit the outer route southward. The Government considers that there is no compelling reason for those 30 tankers to not join the 20 tankers using the outer route southward.

Few Australians would think of the Great Barrier Reef as a shipping lane. It is seen by most as a precious natural asset—and indeed it is. That is certainly the view of the Government, and that is why we are determined to take all reasonable steps to minimise the potential for shipping disaster. But in doing so we must strike a balance between protecting the natural environment, and maintaining viable shipping lanes.
Already the Government has taken a number of significant steps to safeguard the Reef and to improve safety in shipping.
Last September I announced new administrative procedures for issuing single voyage permits to foreign vessels.
This places an obligation on shippers to undertake thorough safety checks before chartering foreign vessels. This condition came into effect this week.
In addition, shippers applying for permits involving bulk carriers and all types of tankers must now certify vital information on the condition of the ship, as well as the qualifications of its crew.

As part of the Government's response to the House of Representative's "Ships of Shame" Report targeted inspections have doubled and now more than one in two foreign flagged vessels are subject to inspection when they call in Australian ports. This rigorous inspection regime has unquestionably deterred substandard shippers from calling in Australia. Today we can boast the toughest inspection regime in the world. One in which monthly ship detention reports are published to bring sub-standard shipping to worldwide attention.

In terms of the Reef itself, by introducing a regime of compulsory pilotage for the inner route in October 1991, Australia made this transit route one of the world's few recognised compulsory pilotage areas.

More recently in October 1993 the Government announced a detailed review of shipping in the Great Barrier Reef and Torres Strait. We did so to ensure that the management of shipping operations maximises environmental protection, and minimises the risk of accidents and pollution.
This review has been conducted in conjunction with the Queensland Government. A wide range of interested parties, including the shipping industry and environmental groups have been consulted.
The report is presently being finalised and will be released by the government soon.

Nevertheless today on behalf of the Minister representing the Minister for Transport I announce a number of initiatives that will improve the safety of shipping in the Great Barrier Reef and the Torres Strait.
The initiatives involve—

para.tab: minimising shipping pressure in the inner route,
additional steps to improve the safety of ships that use the inner route,
improving navigational safety in the Torres Strait, and
improving the safety and reliability of the outer route.

speech.para: We are undertaking these initiatives in the knowledge that many vessels use the Great Barrier Reef inner route because of a lack of suitable charting for the outer route through the Coral Sea.
In order to improve the charting of the outer reef the Government can today announce that the Australian Maritime Safety Authority (AMSA) will provide funding for the production of these charts.

This task will involve surveying that begins at Bramble Cay in the eastern approaches to the Torres Strait, and goes down the Queensland coast to the end of the reef just north of Fraser island, a total distance of some 2000 kilometres.
Once this charting is done, those vessels not calling at Queensland ports that currently use the inner route, will, unless there are exceptional circumstances, have absolutely no reason to do so.
Simultaneously with this charting, AMSA will proceed with the introduction of a mandatory ship reporting regime for the Great Barrier Reef and Torres Strait.
AMSA will also seek to implement a reporting system with the agreement of the International Maritime Organisation (IMO) and will aim to have the measures in place before the end of this year.

The Government can assure the Senate that the Queensland Government has been cooperating with the Commonwealth in moving toward the introduction of a vessel traffic system to cover both the North East Channel and the Torres Strait. The Commonwealth is very grateful for the Queensland Government's assistance with this task.
Together AMSA and the Queensland Government have been looking very closely at initiatives to improve maritime safety in northern waters.
Extensive studies by consultants of potential high-technology solutions to the navigational problems in the region have been completed.
AMSA and the Queensland Government are now negotiating joint ventures to ensure these initiatives can be introduced at the earliest time and in the most cost-effective way.

One of the first stages of this cooperative approach will be the introduction of a vessel traffic system to cover the Torres Strait, the Great North East Channel route near Cape York, and the inner route.

Extended coverage of this radar traffic system will provide accurate real time information and reduce the prospect of ship collisions and groundings. This will be a vast improvement on the present situation where authorities rely on positions radioed in from vessels.
It will provide cover of, and information relating to, the important `choke' points—where channels are narrow and the hazard to shipping is greatly increased.
Furthermore it will assist the Australian and Queensland agencies involved in vessel traffic to enhance safety by monitoring vessel movements more closely.

Extension of the compulsory pilotage area in the northern part of the great Barrier Reef to cover the Torres Strait area would further reduce the risk of groundings and collision. After all human error is the greatest risk to safe shipping.

The Torres Strait is an important and busy international shipping lane and Australia must be cognisant of the role of our neighbour, Papua New Guinea, and the international maritime community in seeking ways to improve safety
in this ecologically vulnerable region.

As the Torres Strait is a recognised international waterway, the extension of compulsory pilotage will involve comprehensive international negotiations. A successful outcome to those negotiations will be far more difficult to achieve than for the Barrier Reef which lies totally within Australian waters.

The Minister for Transport has asked AMSA to pursue the question of compulsory pilotage in the Torres Strait. Indeed it will now become AMSA's highest international priority in negotiations through the IMO.
It is pleasing to note that around 70 per cent of ships transiting Torres Strait already use marine pilots on a voluntary basis.

Yet there are a number of foreign flag vessels who place commercial considerations before their environmental conscience. We now intend to seek international acceptance of the need to carry pilots in these waters.

While insisting on the greater use of pilotage in the marine environments we recognise that technology is constantly offering new ways to improve safety. The latest Differential Global Positioning Systems (DGPS) offer improved navigational safety. With DGPS, positioning accuracy is better than 10 metres.
This technology is now available and is being trialled successfully by AMSA in Bass Strait and off the Pilbara.

Today the Government wants to announce the establishment of a new DGPS broadcasting station on Horn island in the Torres Strait. It will be opened by October this year and will greatly improve the accuracy of ship positioning and assist individual ships to navigate safely in these difficult waters.

With the establishment of this station AMSA will insist on the compulsory use by pilots of transportable global positioning equipment. This will ensure that all ships being piloted, do so with the benefit of the improved DGPS navigational services.

The next few years will see the introduction of computer-based charting systems that provide further improvements to all navigational systems, on all types of vessels. As of now, a large amount of work has already been completed on this tech nology.
The development of such a system can and should have implications beyond just the Reef. It has the capacity to extend to all of our precious Australian coast line. That makes it a huge undertaking.
Such technology is costly to develop but it is an investment that Australia must make in the interests of our marine environment, and the safety of shipping.

To this day shipping oil spills remain the greatest threat to our coast line. They are a constant threat over which we must be forever vigilant. Vigilance will help prevention, or in the event of an unavoidable spillage, the ability to minimise the damage to our marine environment.

The Australian Government is in the process of negotiating a Memorandum of Understanding with Papua New Guinea on cooperation and assistance in the event of a marine pollution incident affecting either country. This is of particular relevance to the Torres Strait.
There is already considerable co-operation with PNG involving AMSA providing significant assistance to the PNG Government.
Following a major review of NATPLAN in 1993, some 30 recommendations were made to improve planning and the capacity to respond to a major spill.
Twenty-six have now been implemented and the remaining four are to be completed by the end of 1995.
Actions relevant to the Great Barrier Reef include

para.tab: The positioning of additional equipment in north Queensland and training for its use,
Development of an MOU between AMSA, Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority (GBRMPA) and Queensland for safe havens for disabled or damaged ships,
Priority for research funding going to a bioremediation proposal to be managed by the GBRMPA;
Extension of the on scene spill model to cover the Ribbon Reefs area.

speech.para: REEFPLAN, the regional version of NATPLAN, is currently undergoing its own review, which will be completed in mid 1995. The emphasis will be on prevention, on planning and on a rapid response.

When taken together as a package, all these Federal Government measures enhance shipping safety in this most sensitive of areas. We have a great responsibility to current and future generations to protect what is the world's biggest and most beautiful reef, one of the world's great ecological treasures. It gives the Government great pleasure to detail these important initiatives aimed at protecting what we all hold dear. They are balanced initiatives, yet initiatives with foresight.
I commend the Statement to the statement to the Senate.

talk.start.para: —Unfortunately, I and the shadow minister, Mr Sharp, were unable to get a copy of this statement until quite late in the piece before the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) made the statement. We have not had a chance to look at it in detail. It seems that Mr Brereton has today announced some good initiatives for the protection of the Great Barrier Reef from shipping. In his statement, the minister has announced some initiatives that involve minimising shipping pressure in the inner route, additional steps to improve the safety of ships that use the inner route, improving navigational safety in the Torres Strait and improving the safety and reliability of the outer reef.

para.tab: The minister's statement contains a lot of very interesting statistics on the shipping use of both the inner and outer routes of the Great Barrier Reef. The minister has today made some announcements in relation to shipping in the reef. I and Senator Ferguson, amongst others, were on a Senate committee investigating major disasters in Australia that reported towards the middle of last year. That committee also highlighted problems with shipping incidents in the Great Barrier Reef area and made some recommendations, which the minister has dealt with in his statement today. Those recommendations of the committee dealt generally with better signage and better navigational aids in the reef area and generally looked at Australia's preparedness for any incident along the reef.

Our report entitled
Disaster management
, which is dated June 1994, did recommend that the funding be upgraded for the Australian Hydrographic Service sufficient to allow for identification of reefs and production of a series of accurate national charts and sailing directions suitable for modern navigation along them. Funding increases should be such as to allow for a production rate of at least 25 charts per annum.

The committee also recommended that the Commonwealth government work internationally towards the acceptance of compulsory pilotage in sensitive areas while establishing a register of such areas around Australia's coast with a view to their promotion for this service. Today Mr Brereton announced that he will be pursuing along those lines the question of compulsory pilotage in the Torres Strait area. The Torres Strait is an international waterway and does require some international acceptance. I am pleased to see that the government is pursuing that.

The minister announced in his statement today that the Australian Maritime Safety Authority will provide funding for the production of the charts. As I said, they are the charts which the Senate standing committee was calling for. That task will involve surveying that begins at Bramble Cay in the eastern approaches to the Torres Strait and goes down the Queensland coast to the end of the reef just north of Fraser Island, a total distance of some 2,000 kilometres. Simultaneously with the charting AMSA will proceed with the introduction of a mandatory ship reporting regime in the Great Barrier Reef and Torres Strait areas.

One of the first stages of the cooperative approach to these initiatives will be the introduction of a vessel traffic system to cover the Torres Strait, the great north-east channel route near Cape York and the inner route. Extension of compulsory pilotage in the northern part of the Great Barrier Reef to cover the Torres Strait area would further reduce the risk of groundings and collisions. As Mr Brereton points out, human error is the greatest risk to safe shipping.

We in the coalition are supportive of anything that is done to protect the Great Barrier Reef. We are pleased to see the government at last concentrating on these real problems and providing some money to address them. It is a bit sad to see that the government often gets itself tied up in the peripheral issues. We had the great furore over the Oyster Point proposal, one of the purposes of which, according to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner), was to protect the Great Barrier Reef. That development at Oyster Point posed no threat to the Great Barrier Reef. It is just a pity that some of the energy and enthusiasm that Senator Faulkner's department puts into those sorts of issues is not transferred into these real issues of concern to the Great Barrier Reef.

As I have lived in the area of the Great Barrier Reef for most of my life, I can assure the government that it is a part of Australia that all of those people living along the coastline feel very strongly about. They are very attached to it and have a very protective attitude towards that reef. It does provide recreation. It does provide by way of fishing a big economy to the North Queensland area. North Queenslanders would generally welcome any measures that go towards protection of that reef. We have been lucky that there have been no major disasters in the Great Barrier Reef area for many years. These new initiatives that the government has announced will hopefully make it even safer and put off further the prospect of any major disaster in that area.

I welcome the minister's statement. The coalition will generally support the initiatives proposed and any other initiatives which will, in effect, lead to a safer route through the Great Barrier Reef area and the long-term and lasting protection of one of the seven wonders of the world.

speech.speaker: MacGibbon D.J.

talk.start.para: —The statement made by Senator Gareth Evans on behalf of the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) on the Great Barrier Reef is a simple political document. It is very deceptive and it sets out to dupe a gullible Australian public into believing that the government is concerned and is trying to do something constructive about the use of the Barrier Reef waterway.

para.tab: The major recommendation of the report is highly dangerous; that is, that traffic prefer an eastern passage in the open ocean, rather than coming up the inner passageway between the Barrier Reef and the Australian coastline. The second major recommendation—that pilotage be compulsory in the Torres Strait area—is at best a pious hope and is at worst, again, a deception because you simply cannot enforce compulsory pilotage in an international waterway, which the Torres Strait is.

The provision of better navigation aids, principally the use of a differential GPS system, is well worth supporting but that is something for the future; it is something that will not come in straightaway. But the most glaring omission in this whole report is the protection of the achilles heel of AMSA; that is, the lowering of pilotage standards in the Barrier Reef waterway, which is a consequence of the AMSA administration. There is not a word in here about the professional standards of pilots.

Just looking at those points very briefly, the argument is superficially attractive. To say that it is a safer area east when you are going north or south around the Barrier Reef is really quite false because you are in the open ocean. You are beyond the continental shelf. If there is any problem with the ship at all, if there is any fault with the propulsion system or the steering system, the ship simply cannot anchor. It is in an open sea state.

We all remember some years ago when the bow fell off an oil tanker by the name of
Kirki
off the Western Australian coast. I think 30,000 tonnes of oil were adrift on the ocean as a consequence of the bow falling off. That is not likely to occur within sheltered waters if the inner passageway is used. If a ship is disabled east of the Barrier Reef, the certainty of it is that it will become a total loss when it is blown on to the reef itself, because in those waterways for at least 10 months of the year there is a 25-knot south-east or north-east trade wind blowing and any disabled ship must be washed up on the reef and become a total loss.

Conversely, if it is using the inner passageway between the Barrier Reef and the coastline, first of all, it will have a mandatory pilot service on board. Secondly, it can anchor anywhere if it is disabled and it may even be able to get into quite a safe anchorage. Thirdly, it is unlikely to be blown up on the shore. Fourthly, if the ship does break up, which again is unlikely because it is a sheltered waterway, the oil will go onto the beach and, tragic though that would be for places like Mission Beach and the many other excellent beaches in North Queensland, I think most people would agree it is better to have oil on a beach and on a coastline than on the reef structure itself.

Finally, all the oil containment and oil dispersion systems that we have—and it ought to be noted that those are really quite limited in extent and most of them are based in Brisbane, not where the Barrier Reef is—will only operate in the sheltered waters inside the reef. Once you get into the outer reef there is no way any of the oil pollution or containment systems will work in any way at all in the open ocean. So the strong and repeated exhortations in this statement, that the outer reef be preferred to the inner reef as a route, is based on a total misunderstanding of the marine conditions that apply in that area.

I was going through
Hansard
because I last spoke on this subject in 1991. The
Hansard
of 10 October 1991 shows that Senator Collins was the minister in the chamber at the time. We were talking about a marine freight bill, I think. Senator Collins said:

So far as the Great Barrier Reef is concerned, again I am forced into a position of agreeing with Senator MacGibbon—that is twice in one morning. Options were put to the Government to take ships outside the reef because it was asserted that this would be safer. In fact, it would be horrendously more dangerous to the reef to do so. As Senator MacGibbon has said, it is not only true that the weather conditions are atrocious outside the reef, but also the area outside the reef is largely uncharted and is therefore considerably more dangerous to shipping. The result, as Senator MacGibbon has pointed out, of a major accident outside the reef would be as disastrous to the reef as if it happened inside the reef because of prevailing winds and tides.

speech.para: Now I come to the business of compulsory pilotage in the Torres Strait area. It would be highly desirable that every ship that transits that waterway have a pilot on board. But the fact of life is that the Torres Strait area is an international waterway and while, in time, the International Maritime Organisation, the IMO, which is the governing body internationally in this area, can make a recommendation that pilots be carried by all ships transiting the Torres Strait, and most ships would, the point is the people we want to catch—the people who present a risk to the integrity of the reef—are the fly-by-night operators, the people with low capitalisation of their shipping lines and with old equipment. They are the very last people who will conform to any voluntary standard. So, while it is desirable that we negotiate towards compulsory pilotage in the Torres Strait area, it simply will not happen.

para.tab: I want to come to the major concern that I have with the reef at the present time, and that relates to the professional standards of the pilots who serve in the area. Once upon a time, the pilot service was provided by a company known, if my memory is correct, as the Queensland Coastal and Torres Strait Pilot Service. There was a popular misconception that this was a monopoly that charged high monopolistic fees. In actual fact, anyone could qualify for a licence from the Queensland Harbours and Marine Authority—which was the licensing authority at the time—so long as they met the standards. Those standards were a masters ticket, experience in command plus an intimate knowledge of the reef. The pilot licence was open to anyone who met those qualifications.

The difficulty in a practical sense was that you just cannot set up to be a pilot. You have to have a shore station, an office to accept the bookings, a communications and radio network to talk to ships that might be approaching, and launches and helicopters to get pilots on and off ships. In effect, it came down to only the Queensland Coastal and Torres Strait Pilot Service providing the service.

There was a lot of controversy about the charges. The charges were never set by the pilots themselves. The pilotage fees were always set by the Queensland government. When the legislation was changed to make pilotage compulsory from somewhere near Booby Island or Prince of Wales Island at the northern end in Torres Strait to a position about 100 nautical miles north of Cairns—that could be made compulsory because it was within Australian territorial waters—the Queensland government gave up its licensing of the pilots and it passed to AMSA.

The economic rationalists in the Labor Party believe that competition is good. They thought that, if they set-up a competitive system for the Torres Strait pilot service, fees would come down. The pilotage fee, from memory, would be about $6,000. Given the fact that, in the sum total of things, it probably costs close to $200,000 just to put a ship alongside at one of the major Queensland ports, a pilotage fee of $6,000 is really chickenfeed.

Anyway, they went ahead with the competition, and a competitive organisation was set up to compete with the old established pilot service. The competitive service could not get off the ground because no-one was ready to join it, apart from maybe five pilots who had fallen out with the old pilot company. The answer that AMSA adopted was to lower the professional standards. It reduced the requirements. We then had a price war erupting on the Queensland coast, and the pilotage fees fell to probably half what they were before.

It is true that the former pilots earned a good income. I do not know how much it was, but from the service they provided it was probably about $100,000 a year. They had an impeccable record of safety. They were really good professionals. The fact that over a period of about 100 years we did not have any ships lost in service with a pilot is testimony to their professional skills.

When competition came along, their salaries were cut by somewhere between 25 and 50 per cent and the standard of recruit dropped right off. The pilot service today, about 18 months into this competitive situation, faces the situation where it cannot attract pilots with the experience needed to provide a safe service. This is really at the heart of my concern about the minister's statement today.

There is need to regulate this service in some way so that we attract master mariners who are experienced, who have command experience, and who know the area and will enter the profession of providing pilots for the service. It is not happening at the present time. The standards have been lowered by AMSA. Unless this is corrected, we will find that we have accidents on that route.

The Auditor-General's report No. 9, which looked at the reef, made the statement that statistically there was a 37 per cent risk, over any five-year period, of a major oil spill as a consequence of a collision or grounding in the Barrier Reef waterways. Mr Deputy President, I can tell you that no minister, Liberal or Labor, has the courage to have a ship go up on the reef at any point and dump 10,000, 50,000 or 100,000 tonnes of oil into the Queensland coastal waters. It is a risk that we cannot accept.

The way to minimise that risk is to re-establish adequate standards within the pilot ranks, because they are at the heart of the problem. Without adequate professional pilots with proper professional standards, all the navaids in the world and all the talk of going east-about means nothing at all. The great majority of shipping will continue to use the inner waterway between the Great Barrier Reef and the coast. That is the most glaring deficiency in this report that is before us today from the minister. The deficiency is there because we have a policy that was set in place by AMSA—and it just will not admit that it made a major mistake in that area.
Debate interrupted.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I have some further information on the Bowra case which goes to the question I was asked by Senator Ellison today. This information, which I had been seeking about the current status of Mr Bowra's incarceration, came to hand after question time and, indeed, after Senator Ellison had sat down.

para.tab: The situation is this: Ambassador Weemas, who is based in Riyadh, has sought a call on the President of the Diwan in the presidential court on 7 March. It is to be hoped that he will be able to make that call and make the representations accordingly. The reason for that date is essentially that that is the end of the Ramadan period and the subsequent Eid holiday. It has been the general understanding that, whatever the fairness or otherwise of this, it has been wholly unlikely that there would be any action on this case until the end of the Ramadan and Eid periods. We are certainly hoping that action will take place very quickly. But the Ambassador will be there to add his voice to that, if he is able to get this appointment on 7 March—which is the first possible date in that respect.

As to the possible intervention of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in this, I advise the Senate that the Prime Minister will be making a transit stop only in Dubai on 6 March between 1.40 p.m. and 3.10 p.m.—in other words, just an hour and a half. Not only has this got a bit of a problem with the holiday period and the obvious shortness of time, but it also ought to be noted that the stop is in Dubai rather than Abu Dhabi, where the actual problem is. The United Arab Emirates is very much a federal, perhaps even a confederal, system where there are different systems of justice applicable in each emirate. So it is wholly unlikely, I think, that any representation the Prime Minister could possibly make in Dubai would be of utility in Abu Dhabi. I will check that point further, however, to make sure that that is so.

talk.start.para: —It would be good if you could.

—Yes, I understand that. I will bring this all to the attention of the Prime Minister or his office so that they can do what they can in the circumstance. I do acknowledge the obvious unfairness of a situation where an appeal decision has been made but no action has yet been taken to execute it. We will do the best we can to follow this one up. I thank the Senate for its indulgence.

speech.speaker: O'Chee Sen W.G.

talk.start.para: —The statement the government made today in relation to shipping transport on the Great Barrier Reef is useful and in some respects is to be welcomed. But I must make the point that this statement overlooks the most important threat to the ecology of the Great Barrier Reef—which surprisingly would not be through something dramatic like a ship running aground and spilling oil, which would be a catastrophe. The greatest threat to the ecology of the Great Barrier Reef, which is particularly fragile, lies in the discharge of ballast water.

para.tab: Ballast water can contain exotic species which could poison fish, introduce molluscs and maybe even destroy the reef itself because the reef is a very fragile ribbon of living organisms. If that reef is contaminated—for example, by exotic molluscs or by algae which are toxic to fish or toxic to the coral—what we will have is an ecological disaster which cannot be remedied. So, whilst I welcome some of the initiatives contained in this statement—I will get on to them later—it shocks me that this report is so half-hearted as to miss the importance of providing adequate protection for the Great Barrier Reef to prevent ballast water discharge damaging the ecology.

The important point is this: the Great Barrier Reef contains most of the ports in Queensland. Certainly, it contains some of the most busy ports in Queensland because it contains ports such as Gladstone, Hay Point, Abbot Point, Townsville, South Johnston, Mourilyan and places like that where bulk carriers come in every day to take away coal, to take away alumina and to take away sugar. In every case, those bulk carriers come in under ballast.

It is interesting to note that the government tabled a report earlier this week pursuant to return to order which stated that something in the vicinity of 121 million tonnes of ballast water was discharged in Australia from over 6,000 vessels in the 1991-92 period. That ballast water content has in fact increased in the two or three years since then, but nothing is being done. The government's own report—as I said, it was tabled earlier this week—is shocking in the admission of how little is being done to deal with the problem, for that report says:

speech.para: The Australian Government cannot unilaterally prescribe how and where non-Australian government flag ships may take on ballast water in foreign ports.
Correct. However, it goes on to say:

However, Australia, as a Port State, could impose conditions specifying how ships are to de-ballast when in Australian ports, particularly if the ships had taken on ballast water in certain overseas ports whose water contained an organism known to be harmful. The Government has not taken any such measures at this point in time because its policy on solving international shipping problems is to adopt a multilateral approach, by working through relevant organisations such as the IMO, and to avoid taking unilateral measures.

That would be fine if every other country had an environment that is like the Great Barrier Reef and is as fragile as ours. The ecological imperative on Australia is far higher than the ecological imperative on some other country which does not have that fragile environment.

para.tab: I sit here wondering why it is that a country like Singapore can prescribe very strict requirements on the de-ballasting of ships which come into its harbour—and Singapore's environment is nowhere near as fragile as ours—yet here we have ports on the eastern seaboard of Australia, ports in very close proximity to the Great Barrier Reef, which are visited daily by ships coming in under ballast and the government refuses to do anything about it because it wants to have a multilateral solution.

How many years do we have to wait until we get a multilateral solution? How many ships under ballast will visit the Great Barrier Reef and the reef ports while we wait? The government's ministerial statement today is interesting. It says that there are some 1,700 movements through the inner route of the reef, 600 of which do not call at any Queensland port inside the reef. So I assume there are 1,100 movements through the reef where ships do visit Queensland ports—1,100 ships, the overwhelming majority of them coming in under ballast. That means that there are 1,100 opportunities a year for the contamination of the Great Barrier Reef and nothing is done because the government wants to have a multilateral solution. If the government is fair dinkum about protecting the reef, then the government will impose a few unilateral conditions on de-ballasting and, if necessary, work with the states to ensure that provisions are made so that ships can de-ballast into tanks where the water can be treated before being discharged. That is the only way to protect against this problem.

I now move to the other matters contained in the statement, and they are the four initiatives outlined by the government. These include minimising shipping pressure on the inner route, additional steps to improve the safety of ships that use the inner route, improving navigational safety in the Torres Strait, and improving the safety and reliability of the outer reef. There is a lot to commend most of those initiatives. I share Senator MacGibbon's concerns, however, about blindly assuming that running ships down the outer channel or outside the reef will necessarily solve the problem. It is correct that if a ship comes into difficulties outside the reef it cannot anchor, because the continental shelf drops straight off. That is why we have a barrier reef—the geology underneath the water is such that the continental shelf drops straight off. A ship in deep water can be blown back onto the reef because of the currents and wind. That is something we have to concern ourselves with. So the blind assumption that you run ships down outside the barrier reef is, in and of itself, not a solution.

There are parts of this statement that are good. It is appropriate that work be done to improve navigational safety in the Torres Strait and to improve the safety of ships using the inner route. That is important because any time you have ships moving in shallow waters you always have the risk of a ship running aground. Accidents can happen. We also need to pay attention to modelling the currents on the reef. The currents on the reef are of particular importance to minimise the potential impact of any spill that may occur on the reef and also, where there are minor spills onto the reef, to track down the culprit ship.

Obviously if a tanker runs aground, it is holed and we see millions of gallons of oil spilled onto the reef, we know who is at fault, because the ship is on the reef. But it is entirely possible that a ship could spill oil into the water, still be perfectly seaworthy and blithely sail right out in the hope that nobody knows. So if we could improve the modelling of the currents on the Great Barrier Reef, then we could track down ships which have improperly allowed oil to spill out and therefore hold the masters and the owners of those ships responsible for the environmental damage which they have done.

But there is another consequence from properly modelling the currents on the reef. In the event of a spill, we will have a very good idea where that oil is going to end up. It is a very complex task. We have an inordinately long coastline, we have a myriad of reefs, we have changing currents from month to month and we have different wind conditions and so on.

It is a very difficult task, but it is something we have to do because, if we are to be prepared for a spill—and we have to assume that a spill is going to happen—we must know where the oil is going to move. In that fashion you can get the equipment to the right place to ensure that you protect the reef from the oil spill. There is no use having all of the equipment in, say, Mackay, if the oil spill is not going to be on that section of the reef, if it is going to be 100 kilometres to the north. It takes time to move and deploy these things. The couple of hours in question may be the couple of hours in which the oil comes ashore or hits a reef and the damage is done. So that aspect, which is relegated to the very last page of the government's statement, should be taken more seriously. It is insufficient to say that it is just one of the things we have to look at. It has to be a very high priority. In terms of the issues addressed it should be one of the highest priorities. Unless we do that, we will be caught unprepared if an accident happens.

talk.start.para: —The Greens (WA) welcome the initiatives by the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton). As a number of speakers have already mentioned, they are certainly not sufficient as yet. It is pleasing to see that the government has acknowledged the importance of protecting Australia's coastlines. I trust that the shipping industry will also support these initiatives. Compulsory pilotage in the Torres Strait as well as on the inside route through the Great Barrier Reef is long overdue. The extent of reefs and islands and the narrow passage of the Torres Strait, combined with the strong tides and currents, create a climate that is just waiting for a major accident to happen. Hopefully, pilotage could substantially reduce that risk.

para.tab: The proposals to improve the quality of navigation charts in the region, together with the increased use of global positioning system technology on land and on ships, will also go some way to reducing the risk in the Great Barrier Reef and Torres Strait shipping routes. In addition, the establishment of a radar traffic system is essential. I trust that the timetable for its implementation will be expedited. In the statement there was some mention of the standard of shipping but the mention indicates that the Australian Maritime Safety Authority is involved with more inspections. Yes it is, but as I have mentioned on a number of occasions, including on AMSA's annual reports, that does not mean there are more people to do those inspections; it is probably related to the fact that we have more single voyage permits every year and the standard of shipping internationally and around Australia's waters has not necessarily improved. So more inspections do not necessarily reflect a higher standard of shipping; they reflect the fact that we are in a very vulnerable position with Australia's very large area of coastline, added to the fact that there are more ships which should be inspected. So if there are more inspections and fewer staff it means that each inspection cannot necessarily be as effective as it might be.

There was some mention from Senator O'Chee with regard to ballast and I agree that there is a huge problem with ballast. The response the government has given so far in relation to its lack of desire for unilateral action reflects also its lack of desire to take unilateral actions with regard to a liability regime. That has been mentioned by me on previous occasions. The United States, for a start, has a liability regime which tries to make sure that, if there is a major accident, somebody is responsible for it. There is not much point in trying to get the money back from a fairly limited liability company, I suppose, if we are accepting more and more single voyage permits or flag of convenience carriers. But there needs to be some line of accountability. There is no point in Australia waiting, whether it is in relation to ballast water agreements or liability regimes, for everybody else in the world to agree; it is our country that is at risk, our environment and our very precious coastal ecosystems.

The issue of a liability regime that incorporates compensation for environmental harm and non-economic loss for marine-based oil pollution needs to be addressed.
