I have noted the government's comments in relation to this issue in a report that was provided to this parliament as a result of a Senate resolution late last year. I feel it is important that Australia pursue this issue in the international community, particularly given our isolation and consequent reliance on shipping, but it is not enough, as I said, that we pursue this as simply a multilateral action. If the international community will not act because of a desire to protect corporate profits, through lower costs of shipping and lower standards of shipping, then it is not good enough.

Finally, I make a plea to the government on behalf of the environmental movement, the fishing industry and the tourism industry to establish some similar protection measures on the north-west coast. There is already an extensive oil industry in the North West Shelf area and it is in close proximity to the ecologically important Ningaloo Reef and the fishing grounds and tourist areas at Exmouth and Broome.

There is a possibility that the risk in these areas could increase as a result of the measures taken to protect the Great Barrier Reef. It may actually mean that some ships will take that other route as a means of getting an easier passage. Many vessels have the option of travelling across the north of Australia to get to Sydney or Melbourne or of travelling the Western Australian coast and around the Great Australian Bight. If the cost of travel is, justifiably, increased due to the requirement for compulsory pilotage, some shipping companies will take the cheaper option and travel through these important areas of Western Australia. I trust that the government will give serious consideration to addressing these issues in Western Australia.

speech.speaker: Woodley Sen J.

talk.start.para: —There is a need to examine in detail the statement that was presented today. I compliment the government for at least making a start on what is a very important issue. I concur with most of what has been said by previous speakers in relation to this statement. I will read the statement in more detail and perhaps comment on it at another time.

para.tab:
In January I was in Cairns to launch a report by the Cairns and Far North Environment Centre entitled
The ever present danger of an oil spill on the Great Barrier Reef, Australia
. At that launch I was involved with the director of the local tourist association who raised many of the same fears that were expressed by the environment centre. I will read from the report that was launched at that time because it provides a useful comment on what the government has done. I think the Environment Centre will be pleased with the start the government has made in meeting some of the concerns it has raised. It is interesting to note that the report stated:

speech.para: The International Maritime Organisations resolution A710(17) States: IMO recommends that ships of 70 metres and over and all tankers carrying oil, chemicals and liquefied gas to use the Australian Commonwealth licensed pilotage service when navigating the Torres Strait and the Great North East Channel between Booby Island and Bramble Cay. However 10% of all vehicles travelling through these two areas chose to ignore IMO's recommendations posing a huge risk to this sensitive area.

I notice in the government's statement that there is a slight difference in terms of the percentages, but I do not know that that really matters. I support the call of the environment centre in its report where it states:
We call for mandatory pilotage of all ships of 70 metres in length or more travelling through Torres Strait and the Great North East Channel.

I note what Senator MacGibbon said about the difficulty of doing this. I believe we as Australians, and certainly the Australian government, need to put all the pressure we possibly can on those ships that are not observing the resolution of the International Maritime Organisation to adhere to that recommendation. It is critical. Another recommendation in the Environment Centre's report stated:

We call for the Australian Government and AMSA to encourage other countries to establish tanker surveillance programmes. The Australian Government and AMSA must establish a programme whereby tanker standard and competence of crew on vessels are checked before entering Australian waters. Improper lashing of containers on vessels is currently a major concern.
Another recommendation which fits in very well with the government's statement, and one that I support, is the one that states:
We call for a designated surveyed separation lane via the Coral Sea for all transit shipping. There must be a buffer zone between the separation lane and the reef.
It appears that the government's recommendation goes some of the way to satisfying that. Finally, the environmental report, endorsed by the tourist association in Cairns, reads:
We call for Establishment of DGPS—
differential global positioning systems—
service for Marine navigation purposes along the Great Barrier Reef, to increase navigational safety and minimise grounding and collisions.

I am pleased to say that there seems to be a real coming together of various interests in this whole area of protection of the Great Barrier Reef. When tourist associations and environmental groups and groups like the various fishing organisations all agree, then obviously there is strong support for government action in this area.

para.tab: Last week, I visited Cairns again with Dr Bob Morris, who is an internationally recognised marine scientist. I spent two days with him visiting the reef. I did a little bit of snorkelling. He did much more than I did because I am not really up to it. It was a very useful visit. I spent two days and he spent a week on the reef consulting with the Department of Environment and Heritage and other people and looking at various problem areas.

I agree to a certain extent with Senator O'Chee, whom I do not always agree with, that one of the problems is not just an oil spill but the dumping of bilge water. I looked at one problem at a place called Richters Creek near Yorkey's Knob where, before Christmas, 400,000 litres of liquid containing at least 25 per cent of highly polluting oil was dumped within 200 metres of the ocean; in other words, within 200 metres of the possibility of polluting the reef. So, it is not simply what ships might do; it is also the fact that liquid—it was mostly bilge water and other liquids from ships dumped on the shore—also has the potential to greatly damage the reef. Another concern which was drawn to our attention when we were in Cairns was the dumping of dredge material close to Trinity Outlet, again allowing very dangerous and polluting substances to leach into Trinity Bay and, therefore, to affect the reef.

Contrary to what Senator Macdonald said, the marine scientist whom I took with me was also doing work on the Oyster Point, Port Hinchinbrook development. His opinion was that it is quite clearly a threat to the Great Barrier Reef, and his investigations confirm the dangers associated with the projected dredging of the Hinchinbrook Channel. When his detailed report is available to me, I will make that report available to the Senate and, of course, to the government. I close by commending this report to the Senate.

speech.speaker: Coulter Sen J.R.

talk.start.para: —I also wish to speak briefly on this ministerial statement and to observe, first of all, the inadequate time which is allowed for discussing very important documents such as this. I think it is a great pity that this document arrived on my fax machine only a very short time before the matter arose in the Senate chamber.

para.tab: The way in which these matters are dealt with—namely, that we are expected pretty much to discuss them as soon as the statement has been tabled—is somewhat unsatisfactory, particularly in view of the great importance of the Great Barrier Reef. I think the previous speakers have drawn attention to that, and I think it would be an excellent idea if the Senate were to consider the availability of these ministerial statements a day or so before they actually came to be discussed in the chamber. Having said that, I draw attention to that part of the statement which says:

speech.para: To this day shipping oil spills remain the greatest threat to our coast line. They are a constant threat of which we must be forever vigilant. Vigilance will help prevention, or in the event of an unavoidable spillage, the ability to minimise the damage to our marine environment.

The point I make with respect to this is that, while we might improve the security of ships by pilotage, by ensuring we do not have rust buckets going up and down the coast or by perhaps putting more ships outside the reef, although I am not convinced in relation to this; nonetheless, all the evidence is that sooner or later we will have a major oil spill on the Barrier Reef and that very considerable damage will be done. The inadequacy of dealing with that oil spill, I think, is the thing to which the government needs to give a great deal more attention.

para.tab: I am pleased that Senator Ray is here in the chamber because he will know that on numerous previous occasions I have pointed to the value to Australia of buying the Canadair CL215 aircraft, which is an amphibious aircraft well capable of going to remote oil spills on the Barrier Reef and dealing with the spill either by way of dispersant or by way of landing on the water and putting out booms, something which cannot be done at the moment. We are still in the situation in which a major oil spill has to be tackled essentially from either end of that 1,000 kilometres of reef extending between Cairns and the Torres Strait. We do not have an ability to intervene quickly should a spill occur somewhere perhaps halfway along that stretch of reef.

This aircraft would be useful not only in that capacity but also in a whole range of other activities. It has particularly been developed for firefighting, picking up six tonnes of water in 10 seconds. It could be used for offshore surveillance, northern surveillance and a whole range of other things. I think it is a great pity that we have not bought a fleet of these aircraft and multi-tasked them so they could take on this whole range of activities, which would actually reduce the cost for each particular activity. It is quite true, as has often been said against these aircraft, that they are expensive at $25 million each. To keep them purely for northern surveillance or to keep them purely for firefighting individually would be too expensive. However, by multi-tasking them I think it would be an extremely reasonable purchase.

The point I stress is that this stretch of 1,000 kilometres of Great Barrier Reef is still extremely vulnerable to an oil spill. We do not have adequate protection in place and sooner or later an oil spill will occur and we will deal with it totally inadequately.

While I welcome this statement, I think we need to go further. We need to look particularly at how we can more adequately deal with oil spills. I think there is a technology by which we could do that more adequately and far better than we do at the present time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

speech.speaker: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

talker.name: Senator ROBERT RAY
talker.role: Minister for Defence)

talk.start.para:
—I table a document entitled
New Directions in Australia's Overseas Aid Program
. I seek leave to make a statement and to incorporate it in
Hansard
.

para.tab: Leave granted.

The statement read as follows
—

speech.para: In the last annual report to Parliament on the aid program, which my colleague the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs tabled at the end of 1993, the Government's approach to poverty alleviation through its aid program was set out. That report emphasised the importance of sustainable economic growth and social development proceeding in tandem.
The report being tabled today highlights significant new directions in Australia's aid program in the social sector and in the area of humanitarian relief.
The report also covers the major achievements of the aid program over the past 12 months and I shall begin my comments by outlining some of the most important of these achievements.

Despite the need for continued budgetary restraint in order to consolidate the economic recovery in Australia, the Government demonstrated its commitment to international development by increasing Australia's aid program by 3.6 per cent in real terms. This meant that we were one of only four of the 21 OECD donors who increased their aid programs in the last year. As a result, Australia continues to remain above the average for donors in terms of aid to GNP ratio.

Aid volume apart, there have been significant changes in our region, not least in Indochina and the South Pacific. Further afield, the transition to democracy in South Africa will change the nature of economic relationships throughout Southern Africa.

Mr President, I will now draw attention to significant developments in Australia's relationship with the South Pacific. During the run-up to the South Pacific Forum, the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs gave a speech to the Foreign Correspondents Association highlighting the need for policy reforms in the region. The overriding theme of his address was the need for the region's governments to develop improved national policies to encourage sustainable social and economic growth. I am pleased to say that this theme was taken on board by regional leaders and, as a result, the Forum generated an unprecedented level of commitment to improve economic and environmental policies, particularly in forestry. Just recently, a code of conduct on logging was signed by Forum Island Countries, and only last week a meeting of the region's Finance Ministers took place at which crucial policy issues were discussed, including fiscal, forestry and civil aviation matters, which have been identified as priorities by island leaders.

In Papua New Guinea we have agreed on a radical transformation of the program. By the end of the decade, the program will have completely moved from budget support to jointly-programmed project activities.

In Indochina—one of the poorest regions of the world, where annual incomes are less than $400 per head—our aid program is expanding rapidly. In May 1994, we announced a four-year, $350 million package, targeted at the high-priority areas of health, infrastructure, education, human rights and the strengthening of legal institutions.

One of the most visible examples of the effectiveness of our development assistance is the Mekong River Friendship Bridge. It is the first road link between Laos and Thailand and will yield substantial economic benefits to both countries. Moreover, as one of the highest-profile aid projects undertaken by Australia in recent years—and, incidentally, a project completed ahead of schedule and under budget—the bridge is an invaluable showcase for Australian capabilities in major infrastructure design and technology transfer.

I wish to draw members' attention to the Government's response to the tragedy of Rwanda. The Government has so far contributed $35 million to support the relief effort there, a contribution matched by an extraordinary public response of over $30 million. Australia's response was one of the earliest and, from my observations, one of the most effectively targeted of all donors. At the same time, and despite our limited resources, we have begun an increased program to support the peaceful transition to majority rule in South Africa providing assistance of $30 million over three years. This program has been designed to meet the objectives of the Government of National Unity's Reconstruction and Development Program, including through building up capacity in areas such as planning, economic policy and the media.

There have also been important developments in the sectoral focus of Australia's aid program. In particular, we have continued to expand environmental assistance, and in this financial year we will spend around $120 million on these activities. Amongst other things, this funding will cover the establishment of what we are calling `Green DIFF', part of the highly successful Development Import Finance Facility which has been the catalyst for many Australian companies to become involved in the region. Green DIFF will help to finance environmental projects in areas such as pollution control and energy efficiency, gaining wider exposure for Australia's environmental expertise. The last budget also heralded an Australian contribution of nearly $43 million to replenish the Global Environment Facility, as well as an increase in support for the Montreal Protocol on Substances that Deplete the Ozone Layer.

A vibrant private sector is an essential part of the development process. Initiatives such as the Private Sector Linkages Program, which has seen its budget double to $10 million, are targeted at this sector. In addition, the informal sector is now recognised as a fundamental resource for social and economic development. Australia's aid program is reflecting this with an increased allocation of funds to micro-enterprise development with a two-year, $1.3 million package for development in the South Pacific and South East Asia.

The change in the role of the private sector in development is just one example of the way that the aid program has adapted to remain relevant and effective. Another excellent example is provided by this year's launch of the policy document
Towards a Sustainable Future: Ecologically Sustainable Development through Australia's Development Cooperation Program
. Australia's policy in this area fully takes into account the UN Conference on Environment and Development in Rio by defining the importance of integrating the economic, social and ecological dimensions of development.

The past year has also seen the Government continue to pursue policies on human rights and good governance through the aid program. On human rights, Australia's policy is to maintain a consistent and principled stand against abuses, while stressing the importance of continued engagement through dialogue and institution-building. On good governance, Australia's policy encourages the effective management of social and economic resources in developing countries in a manner that is open, transparent, accountable, and equitable.

As you can see, over the past year we have continued a process of review and adaptation which will ensure that Australia's aid program continues to be of the highest quality, responsive to the needs of developing countries and appropriate to Australia's place in the world.
I would like now to turn to new developments in our overseas assistance in the social sector. The Government's policy framework for poverty reduction has three components:

para.tab: encouraging sustainable economic growth;
investment in human resources through education, health, capacity building and social sector development; and
provision of safety nets and poverty targeting, including humanitarian relief.

speech.para: The social sector provides a crucial contribution to sustainable social and economic development. Recent World Bank reports have highlighted the major role that government commitment to social sector development, particularly in education, has played in the rapid growth of many Asian economies. Reflecting this importance, the past two budgets have seen a significant upgrading of the already high priority given to the social sector in the aid program through the introduction of major population and health initiatives.

In the 1993-94 budget, we trebled expenditure on the population sector with a four-year $130 million initiative. To ensure the effectiveness of this initiative, the Government commissioned an independent inquiry into the links between population and development. This was one of the most comprehensive surveys of population and development issues ever undertaken, and its conclusions have been vital in highlighting the complex links between population and development.

The results of this inquiry have helped AIDAB to develop a range of principles which now guide the aid program's population activities. Amongst the most important of these principles is that access to safe and effective family planning services is a fundamental right; and that women should have access to a wide range of reproductive health services and should participate fully in defining the services they need. Above all—and I emphasise this most emphatically—coercion has no place in Australian aid program's family planning activities.

The priority which the aid program affords population issues was reflected in the major role that Australia played at the International Conference on Population and Development held in Cairo in September 1994. Helped by our efforts, the Conference adopted a ground-breaking program of action for the empowerment of women, and called for major increases in global resources for family planning and health activities.

I would also like to refer to the significant developments in the nature of our assistance to the health sector. Funding for health was given a major boost in the 1994-95 aid budget with the introduction of a four-year initiative targeting four priority areas—malaria, polio, neonatal tetanus, and HIV/AIDS. The initiative involves additional funding of $110 million over four years nearly doubling Australia's current spending on health under the aid program.

As with assistance for population activities, AIDAB has developed a set of principles which will guide this new funding. These principles state that improvements in health are best achieved through an integrated approach which tackles the causes of poverty and improves the status and well being of vulnerable groups, particularly women and children.
Changes are also afoot in Australia's program of assistance to education and training.

Assistance to the education sector has always been a large part of the aid program. At present, the sector receives an allocation of around 20% of the total budget. The majority of this funding goes towards assistance at the tertiary level. We are now reviewing our assistance in the sector, with a view to diversifying the kinds of assistance to include increased support for basic, technical and vocational education.

There is no doubt of the social, economic, health and population gains that are derived from basic education. At the same time, the primary responsibility for the provision of basic education lies with the recipient government—aid should not substitute for that responsibility. That means that our assistance to the education sector must be carefully targeted to assist and strengthen, rather than replace or duplicate, the efforts of national governments.
Finally, Mr President, I would like to talk about developments in the humanitarian relief program.

One of the most tragic features of the past few years has been the continued increase in the frequency and impact of international emergencies. In the past five years over 300 million people have been affected by natural disasters and civil strife. Over the past 20 years, the numbers of refugees rose from an estimated 3 million to 23 million, half of whom are children and most of whom are from developing countries.

This is a huge cost in human terms. It is also a huge financial cost. Just to give you an example; the annual expenditure of the UN High Commissioner for Refugees has risen from US$450 million in the mid eighties to US$1.1 billion in 1993 and the cost of UN peace keeping operations has risen from under $1 billion in 1991 to over US$4 billion in 1993. This trend shows no sign of slowing.

The forces driving this situation are highly complex, demanding an equally complex international response. Factors such as the link between poverty and vulnerability, the increase in political volatility since the end of the Cold War, and the proliferation of humanitarian relief agencies, have to be taken into account in providing a coordinated response.
It was against this backdrop of increasing complexity and growing demand for assistance that, early last year, AIDAB undertook an extensive review of its refugee and relief program.

The results of this review are helping the Government to update Australia's response to international humanitarian emergencies. The review found that Australia's spending on humanitarian relief had not followed the rapid increase of other donors.

This relative decline in funding for humanitarian emergencies is in stark contrast to the clear wishes of the Australian public, which has repeatedly demonstrated that it wants its Government to respond generously to such humanitarian tragedies as those witnessed in Rwanda.
AIDAB is already responding to the recommendations of the review and is also exploring opportunities for increasing funds for humanitarian relief.

As Australia improves its aid response to international humanitarian emergencies, we also share a responsibility with the international community to do more to prevent disasters and complex emergencies from happening in the first place. This is a priority that requires a range of strategies addressing the underlying causes of dispute and conflict. We require improvements in prevention and response strategy through arrangements which minimise threats to security, promote confidence and trust, and create frameworks for dialogue and cooperation. We must also develop peace-building activities to ensure that conflict does not arise in the first place, or if it does, to ensure that it does not recur. That involves strategies which encourage economic and social development, environmental protection, human rights and good governance. Australia will be doing as much as possible through the aid program to support these activities.

In the years ahead, I am confident that Australia will continue to deliver a compassionate and effective aid program that has a real impact on the lives of millions of people throughout the developing world. Australia's future, and the Australian people, demand nothing less.

talk.start.para: —I seek leave to move a motion.

para.tab: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —I move:

para.tab: That the Senate take note of the statement.

talk.start.para: —This statement about new directions in Australia's overseas aid program is an important one. It is apparently made about once a year by the minister who is responsible for Australia's development assistance. It is a rather brief statement, and it appeals to values that are well accepted on both sides of the chamber and, indeed, by the Australian public. There is one reference to humanitarian relief which indicates that the Australian government is self-critical for not giving humanitarian assistance to the extent that it appears the Australian public would want the Australian government to give it. I welcome the candour that the government has shown in this matter.

para.tab: I think the government is right. When the Australian public is touched by children dying in Rwanda and the chaos arising from a tragic civil war, they give to non-government organisations—even though that giving is to an extent subsidised by tax deductibility offered by the Australian government—and this compassion of the Australian public leads to large subscriptions of money and throws into a shadow the assistance that the Australian government is directly giving, despite it being some $35 million for Rwanda so far.

I accept that we in this parliament do need to encourage the Australian government to respond to those expressions of compassion and of justice, and to ensure that children in the world, refugees and others displaced by war and natural calamities, are given resources to meet their urgent human needs. That is especially so having regard to an affluent country like Australia, where we have more than a handful of suits to wear, swimming pools, backyards, too many cars on the roads and every manner of convenience. I think that development assistance is an area that, from time to time, grabs the full attention of the Australian public, and it ought to grab more of the attention of the Australian government.

There is a reference at the beginning of the statement that is rather self-congratulatory which says that Australia has increased its aid program over the last 12 months by 3.6 per cent in real terms. It says that this is a greater degree of increase than for most of the OECD donor countries, and it remains above average for donor countries from the OECD in terms of it being a proportion of GNP. They are minor badges of merit that the Australian government gives itself and gives all Australia. Frankly, it is way below the UN standard, which is the objective that the Labor Party has accepted as appropriate and that the coalition has accepted as appropriate. It is only half of that amount. I do not believe that any of us can congratulate ourselves for giving an appropriate proportion of our gross national product to overseas aid.

talk.start.para: —And they broke their promise at the last election.

—Senator Kemp is right. Before the last election and the one before that, the Liberal and National parties were too honest in setting forth our policy of keeping that objective but implementing some cuts, especially in multilateral aid. We were given heaps by the Labor Party for that honesty, yet it did the same thing in government and did not live up to its own precise commitments with regard to development assistance. All I am saying is that on the first page of this statement by the minister a few badges are awarded, but not the ones that matter. We need a lack of hypocrisy in the competition we have at election time.

para.tab: There is reference to some special developments in the South Pacific with regard to Papua New Guinea, Indochina and Rwanda. I have read these paragraphs and welcome them all. The Australian initiative with regard to forestry in the South Pacific is important. When we back it up with some cash to gain agreement in the South Pacific forum, it will be a good thing. It is long overdue that by the end of the 1990s we reach the target in Papua New Guinea of transforming our very substantial aid from budget support to jointly programmed project activities.

I refer to Indochina. I am very glad to see that a $350 million package over a four-year period is directed especially at the high priority areas of health, infrastructure, education, human rights and the strengthening of legal institutions. Justice Michael Kirby has met with parliamentarians as the UN's special raconteur on human rights in Cambodia. In his observations, he has called for this kind of assistance. I strongly support health, education and legal institution assistance by Australia, which will be the best foundation for ensuring more normal and acceptable human rights for the people of Cambodia.

I see reference to the Mekong River Friendship Bridge. This important Australian project, which links Laos and Thailand, is now completed. I believe that it is a sound and good project that Australia has brought to this region. It is so obvious an area of aid on Australia's part that it has been ridiculed by those highly sceptical of development assistance to any part of the world, let alone Indochina. I dismiss the sceptics and continue to support that important project in a bipartisan way.

The bridge, which is a transport corridor linking Laos and Thailand, is a symbol of the kind of assistance that we as a people want to give to this part of the world. It is there for everyone to see that this major bridge—the most important bridge across the Mekong in its northern reaches—was provided by Australia. The symbolism of it is a physical point of reassurance for all of Indochina to see.

I would like to have said some more about this statement, not least about human rights and population matters. However, I will cut short my speech in order to allow other senators to make a contribution.

speech.speaker: Harradine Sen B.

talk.start.para:
—I welcome the opportunity to say a few words about this matter, even though this debate concludes at half past four. I thank Senator Teague for his great courtesy in shortening his speech to allow me to say something on this matter. I am rather concerned about this tabled document entitled
New directions in Australia's overseas aid program
. The reason I am specifically disappointed in it is that it is too self-congratulatory. That is the problem with our approach to overseas aid. Our approach is more concerned with whether the organisation is called AIDAB or `AUSAID'. It is always too self-congratulatory.

para.tab: This is probably done for propaganda purposes to try to get more support in the community for increased development assistance. That can be done in a number of ways. But, when you are talking about a document that is tabled before the parliament, the minister should know that there are a few hardheads in the parliament who are going to have a look at it to see just where the new directions are and what directions are going to fit and be tested against separate criteria in terms of their effectiveness. Unfortunately, this document does not do so.

Section 1 talks in rather glowing terms about the achievement of the government of a real increase in the size of Australia's overseas aid effort by 3.6 per cent. What we have to realise is that it has not kept pace with GDP. The document does acknowledge that. It says, `Oh well, it hasn't kept pace; Australia was one of only four OECD donors to achieve an increase in aid volume in 1993.' It then talks about its current aid standing at 0.33 per cent of GNP, which is substantially better than the 0.30 per cent of OECD donors combined. So what! We are responsible for seeing that the amount is not only increased but increased more effectively.

I will not go into great detail as Senator Margetts may well want to say something briefly. I would have liked to address the question of Africa. As I have said in the estimates committee time and time again, I believe we have not played our role in the development assistance area in Africa as well as we should have. We are going to have to do something more than that which has already been done. After the South African elections, the government did increase the level of assistance, but it is $30 million over three years. That is the first time we have increased the level. Previously there were problems with doing that.

I wish to discuss the issue of population. This document is not only self-aggrandising but also false. It provides a false description of what occurred and of the outcome of the government's own hand-picked inquiry on population. The document does not include one of the most major suggestions and recommendations of the government's own hand-picked inquiry, which stated:

speech.para:
If governments seek to improve the economic position of the poor, it is best, where possible, to use
direct
policy instruments, such as increased access of the poor to land, credit, public infrastructure, and services, particularly education and health. Some of these policies will be opposed by powerful pressure groups.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

debate.sub1.title: Egg Industry Research and Development Council

para.tab:
Debate resumed from 2 February, on motion by
Senator O'Chee
:
That the Senate take note of the document.

talk.start.para: —The Egg Industry Research and Development Council report is a document which is well laid out in a logical, simple and easy to read fashion. Annual reports vary enormously in readability. It is always a relief to come across one which is well written.

para.tab: Egg production is associated in the minds of many people with the terrible image of hens crammed into battery cages. The practice of caging hens for egg production developed due to the belief that this enabled maximum productivity and economic efficiency. Whilst I am not saying that economic considerations are not important, they should not be the only factor used in assessing the suitability of our food production processes.

There is no good reason why, once an animal is identified as being suitable for the purposes of producing food for humans, all considerations for the welfare of that animal should disappear. Putting any bird or animal in a cage so small it cannot turn around would be quite rightly seen as inexcusable by most people if it were in a zoo or kept as a pet. The Democrats believe the same standard should apply when the animal is being used to produce food for us to consume.

This general principle is one that is of great importance, as serious consideration is being given at the moment to greatly expanding the commercial use of native wildlife in Australia for food production and other commercial uses. But if the use of kangaroos, emus, possums, bandicoots, crocodiles and other Australian wildlife becomes common place, it is likely that the same disregard for their welfare will occur. This is something the Democrats would strongly oppose.

After a lot of work from many people concerned about the problem of battery cages, there have been some moves to more easily enable the sale of eggs which are clearly labelled as being free range. Whilst this sort of consumer driven demand for reform is vital in the food industry, I believe the industry must also consider basic ethical standards and work harder to improve the situation.

Recently, minimum cage sizes were agreed to by the Agriculture and Resource Management Council of Australia and New Zealand, ARMCANZ, which is made up of primary industry ministers from all states and territories and chaired by the federal Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Senator Collins. The report containing this decision was also tabled in the Senate earlier this week.

Whilst it is good that minimum cage sizes will become regulatory and enforceable across Australia from the start of 1996, it is unfortunate that it was accompanied by a reversal of a 1992 code of practice which gave hens more space. The actual size allowed and the slowness of moves away from caging birds are matters of great concern to the Australian Democrats. The minimum floor space allowable for each bird is 450 square centimetres, which is less than the size of an A4 page. I find it hard to see how anyone can justify keeping a bird in a space this size for its entire life.

This report states that animal welfare was a high research priority for the council in 1993-94. While most of the welfare issues would not arise if the birds were not kept in such unnatural and confined situations, it is still pleasing to see that the issues are being considered. Among the areas being looked into are beak trimming, cage design and sizes, osteoporosis and bone fractures in hens.

According to the report, some of the research suggests that one hen housed in a 1,500 square centimetre cage may be chronically stressed when compared to two hens housed in the same area. This, in effect, is simply implying either that a hen prefers to have a smaller space or that it prefers to have company in its cage. I would think that any research that alleges that a hen is happier in a smaller cage—
(Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: —The Wheat Board report for 1993-94 has been around for quite some time, and I am sure it has been read by almost every senator in this place. However, this gives me an opportunity to address something else concerning the Wheat Board, the Grains Council of Australia and the allied industry generally. I refer to the report of the strategic planning unit commissioned by the Grains Council of Australia and paid for, in the order of $2 million, by the Grains Research and Development Corporation of Australia—commonly known as the SPU report. That $2 million enabled the report to go virtually from seed and fertiliser right through to the bread on the table, but it was long on narration and very short on recommendations. I believe that the report, to a certain extent, simply provides the Wheat Board with a self-fulfilling prophecy rather than spelling out the situation facing the Wheat Board and what sort of marketing—say, single desk marketing—we will have in the future.

para.tab: The point that I would like to address more in my limited time—and, incidentally, I thought it was 10 minutes for each speaker but obviously it is five; so I will have to cut my remarks rather short, unless some kind person on the other side will move that my time be extended—is the wheat industry fund. It is no secret that I have been trying to get an inquiry into the wheat industry fund for quite some time in this place.

Basically, it came about that in 1989, with the Wheat Marketing Act, virtually two per cent of all wheat sales was to go into a fund to provide a guaranteed underwriting for when the government underwriting will disappear from that act in about 1999. At the present moment the fund has $200 million—and, incidentally, nearly half of that comes from Western Australia.

But we have no definition of direction. That is why I am looking for an inquiry to be undertaken into what that fund has been used for. When Booz, Allen and Associates brought out that report—actually, there were three reports—one of the consultants, Sam Hill, on delivering his findings in Western Australia, picked up the point of the wheat industry fund. Very little mention had been made of it in the written report. However, when he was delivering his findings, he was rather vicious in his attack on the way the wheat industry fund might be used.

Sam Hill identified that the wheat industry fund had three facets: firstly, as providing a guarantee for borrowings, and that is what we passed legislation on; secondly, as a strategic investment fund actively working to lift returns to growers; and, thirdly, as a retirement fund for grain growers who believe that they will get their money back. He went on to say that the fund cannot cover all three of these functions.

Mr Acting Deputy President, I remind you that the fund was established in the beginning to provide a guarantee for borrowings. The Wheat Board and the Grains Council of Australia in their wisdom think they can use this fund, gathered from growers, for purposes they think fit, but which may not necessarily be in the interests of wheat growers in Australia, and the wheat growers of Western Australia in particular. I will certainly be pushing much harder to come to get this inquiry. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

para.tab:

talk.start.para:
—I will be speaking today on only one of this group of reports—that is,
Cultivating the human factor: employment and skills in Australia's rural industries
—and I will be seeking leave to continue my remarks later. What I see here is a series of failures of vision and understanding.
Cultivating the human factor
is part of the title of this report, but is that what it is really about? It is about the rural sector in relation to competing in the global economy. We have seen again and again that, in relation to the rural sector—especially agricultural industries—both major parties are interested in promoting global competitiveness and think the way to do this is through restructuring.

para.tab: In the World Trade Organisation debate last year, we heard that the citrus industry and other industries would have to restructure. It was clear that this meant the end of small and medium business and the consolidation of farms and orchards. That is what the small growers saw, and that is what the big growers saw. The way things are going, small producers are doomed. Big producers can survive because by owning large acreage and employing people on a minimal outlay on an as needed basis they can get by, whereas family farms working on a smaller holding have a hard time because they have to support themselves continually. That is what we are told. In light of that, I cannot understand why any surprise is expressed, as it has been here, at the difficulties of attracting young people into the industry.

It is easy to plug into the jargon. On page 21 we see talk of inappropriate labour and characteristics of the situation as being partly inappropriate and/or inadequate on-the-job training and partly a problem of developing attractive career paths, especially for young people. Attractive career paths? We have to be kidding! Employers are under stress to pay workers less to compete internationally with nations like Brazil and the banana republics. So we have some people who might, if they cannot find a real job, lob in and pick fruit for a few weeks on marginal wages or, if they are lucky, pick for a few months. Usually they can camp out in tents or sleep in their cars so that they can minimise their costs and low wages are not so important. Besides, that is liable to be more fun than hanging around without work or money.

So there will be a labour force, but it is stupid to talk about career paths. It is a young person's job when they cannot find anything else to do, and it is a job for the sort of people who find themselves going mad when shut up inside. It is short-term, both in job security and in relation to the period of one's life when they follow such a path.

I said there is no vision here. Following the path of international competitiveness will not fix anything. If the government is really serious about small and medium business in rural communities, it will have to broaden its vision. It cannot largely concentrate on jobs in monoculture, agriculture, forestry and mining. What amazes me is that I see nothing here—not a subject heading, not a statistic—that indicates there is a tourism or hospitality sector, agricultural value added industries, or services in rural communities. Yet the most vital small rural towns have a high level of these activities as well as businesses that work in well, such as cultural businesses, furniture making, artisan work and art businesses—places like Maleny which have other sophisticated industries. Under growing rural enterprises we again get the song and dance about international export. There is life inside the global economy.

In terms of agriculture, monoculture is a problem—not a solution. Sales and markets, even international sales and markets, could be addressed through things like producers' cooperatives that would allow smaller farms to compete. There is no mention of training for this. It would also allow farms to move more in the direction of diversification. That would be an advantage both in terms of markets where prices are unreliable and in terms of a nation where weather is unreliable. We see government elsewhere talking about the need for restructuring agriculture to deal with drought and climate change. Surely diversification is one way, yet nothing is said about how to make diversification work. Perhaps some training in this and in setting up growers' co-ops, which are a fine old agricultural tradition, would be appropriate.

There is also the whole issue of looking at establishing and working in local and regional markets, instead of global ones, and managing farms in a more integrated way. We have community after community—certainly in Western Australia—where the primary activity is agri-pastoral activity, and yet food is imported from Perth, other capital cities or even overseas. What about employment schemes and small business assistance in providing local food markets? These can be as simple as providing a parking lot or school verandah once a week where farmers can bring produce. I have a great deal more to say on this issue. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debated adjourned.

speech.speaker: Tierney Sen J.W.

talk.start.para: —I move:

para.tab: That the Senate—

(a)reminds the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Mr Lee) that his television anti-siphoning list will fail its first major test if the West Indies cricket series is not shown on free-to-air television;

(b)condemns the Australian Labor Party Government for failing to deliver what was promised to the Australian people, that is, an assurance that those events that television watchers have been used to seeing on free-to-air television would remain available to them;

(c)expresses its lack of confidence in the Minister for presiding over a television anti-siphoning list that failed its own test by not preserving the West Indies telecasts for free-to-air television;
(d)calls on the Minister to stop his monumental buck-passing and accept that he, as Minister, and not the television networks, is wholly responsible for this West Indies cricket coverage fiasco; and

(e)demands action from this incompetent Minister, with the West Indies cricket series only a matter of days away, to settle the dispute and protect the rights of millions of low-income viewers who rely on free-to-air television to see the West Indies cricket telecasts.

speech.para: We have seen over the last few weeks an absolute debacle in communications policy. We have a minister who has failed an extremely simple test of ministerial competence. We have recently seen the West Indies series of cricket tests, which many Australians love to watch, absolutely destroyed by the debacle caused by the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Mr Lee). Quite simply what has happened is that the minister has created a list of programs that should be on free-to-air TV. That means, of course, that it cannot be siphoned off—to use the expressions used—to the pay TV networks.

para.tab: During a period of about eight months we have had ample opportunity to put this new system in place. But what we have seen happen in the last few weeks is the minister flip-flopping from side to side, being totally indecisive over how this matter should be resolved. We are now seven days away from the cricket series. Fans in Australia are about to miss out and the West Indies cricket board is about to lose an enormous amount of money because of the way this has been handled by this minister.

This is not a rare and isolated event; this is part of a long series of policy gaffs by the minister for communications. What this minister is all about is show. What we saw yesterday was the release of the report on the information superhighway and multimedia services from the Broadband Services Expert Group. We have had a look at this report. It is an absolutely excellent report, top rate—but it is a little late. What we have seen over the last few years is the various media operators in this very dynamic communications industry work out how to position themselves well to take advantage of the booming communications industry. What the government has decided to do, after a lot of these operations are getting well under way, is to call for a report on what it should do in terms of a legislative framework to control these matters.

The horse has bolted. The system is operating out there. The very dynamic communications market is off and running. Billions of dollars have been involved in rolling out the information superhighway. Tens of millions of dollars are involved in developing various products and all of this is happening within a communications vacuum. We have the situation—with converging technologies of television, computers and telephones—of a great need, as I have said before in this place, for a uniform system where we have one converging technology legislative framework that takes into account the operation of people on television, telephones and computers as these industries merge and as the products move between those different types of mediums.

What is the minister doing? He called for a report. We have a report. Where is the legislative base? When are we going to get that? It has taken several years to get this report. Let us hope for the sake of Australian communications that it does not take several years to get the proper legislative base. That is not the only problem we have had with this minister in terms of the sorts of things he has been doing.

We have had a huge problem also in recent weeks with cross-media ownership rules. The government again is flip-flopping, dillydallying and trying to decide which way it should go in terms of cross-media ownership rules. Are we going to have greater foreign ownership of the media industry in our country? Are we going to allow greater concentration of the media industry? Both sound like undesirable outcomes to me. But because the system has been set up in a dynamic, changing industry we have the government again caught flat-footed with its policy.

We also have recently—and it is still currently under inquiry—the ABC. The ABC has been shown to be moving in the range of new directions with very little external audit control. The ABC inquiry that is currently under way has revealed quite a lot of things that it will be reporting to the Senate on fairly soon. All this shows a minister who is very much just paddling around and not really keeping a hand on the department that he is the minister for.

That brings me back to the major problem we are now facing. This anti-siphoning list is a test for the minister. It is a pretty simple test. One fears for the future of the communications industry, the nature of which I have just described, if this minister cannot get this very simple situation right. Let me describe the nature of the task to show how simple the task initially was and how much of a muddle he has got it into. All he had to do was come up with an anti-siphoning list. These were products, programs, that people frequently watch—like the West Indies test cricket series. He had to put these things on a list. He produced a list but, like a lot of what this minister has done, the problem has arisen because what he did was far too late. He did not anticipate what was going to happen in a dynamic market.

What was happening out in the dynamic market was that Australis, one of the main pay TV operators that operates Galaxy, had shot off with no regulatory regime in place—so there was nothing saying it could not do this—and decided it would buy the rights to this West Indies cricket series. It has done that; it has bought the rights. And then the minister comes out with a list, which more or less says you cannot buy the rights. He brought this list out months ago. Fairly obviously, the decision had to go one way or the other. Either he stuck by his list or he did not.

One would wonder why it has taken five or six months for this minister to work out what his problem was and come up with some sort of solution. He has not come up with a solution. He started out taking the line that he would protect his anti-siphoning list. Then he went into some negotiations with Channel Nine and Galaxy and decided that Galaxy could have it 24 hours later. Then he decided that maybe 12 hours would be better. This is a classic case of policy on the run, of a minister again caught totally flat-footed in a dynamic, changing market.

What is going to be the outcome of all this? The outcome is, if Galaxy gets its way, that probably a few hundred people will watch the West Indies cricket series. Galaxy has on its books at the moment under 2,000 people for subscription television. That is in total. It is not 2,000 cricket fans—it is 2,000 viewers. They want to watch it live. There is one little brake on it. First of all, you have to be prepared to sit up between midnight and dawn to watch. That will cut a few of them out. The other thing is that the 2,000 are not all cricket fans. My guess is that probably about 200 or 300 people might watch this. Isn't that a disgrace? We have a nation of cricket lovers here and because of the government's incompetence in handling this fairly simple matter, we have to come to a point where a few hundred people might watch the game.

The minister has to come to a decision very quickly. He has to stop buck-passing. He has to make a decision. If he makes the wrong decision he has to explain to the West Indies why they are going to lose an enormous amount of money out of what he has to do. But the main thing is that the minister must keep his promise that viewers will not be forced to pay to watch the major sporting events.

That is what anti-siphoning is all about. You should not be forced to pay for these particular events. Minister Lee and the ABA must settle this dispute between the parties so that the free to air and pay TV operators have very clear rules to abide by. What we have at the moment is the law of the jungle—will they do this or will they do that. They are out there brawling publicly about whether it will be winner take all or some sort of compromise.

The free to air television channels involved in this matter are really digging in and I think they have good reason to dig in. They do not want this test case with Galaxy siphoning off, against the anti-siphoning list, a major event like the West Indies cricket series because they fear that if it succeeds it will happen with a lot of other major cricket series and other sporting events in the future.

The Australian television consumer is outraged by this outcome of ALP government incompetence. What the government must do as we count down to day 7, day 6 and day 5 is come up with a situation where this test actually gets to the majority of viewers. In other words, the government must come up with a situation where it sticks by its rules in the anti-siphoning legislation. That is the initial position the minister took. Now he has done a backflip and gone over to the pay TV operator side. If you make a set of rules you should stick by them. As I said earlier, I fear for not only the future of the pay television and television industry in this country but also the future of the whole communications industry in this country if they are guided by a totally inadequate legislative framework and a totally incompetent minister.

speech.speaker: Carr Sen K.J.

talk.start.para: —I rise to oppose this motion before us today. I cannot for the life of me see how the opposition can come in here and have the gall and hypocrisy to suggest that somehow or other this government should interfere in the market negotiations for the broadcasting of the West Indies test. If I had come in here and argued the case for the government interfering in the market relations you might have been able to

speech.para: understand it because that is traditionally my position. What we are hearing from the opposition is that the market has failed and the government should step in and somehow or other direct Channel 9 to broadcast this test. What hypocrisy and humbug from the great free enterprise coalition.

para.tab:
We have a situation where Senator Tierney has indicated his extraordinary and amazing ignorance of this area of government policy. What we clearly have is a case where there has been a gross misrepresentation of the facts to the Senate. We have a clear case where one company, a pay TV company, purchased the rights to broadcast a test in the West Indies before the siphoning list was declared by the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Mr Lee). The facts are that it purchased the rights to this test before the government acted.
According to the opposition's line of argument, the government is somehow or other supposed to retrospectively change the rules and say that the list that was declared on 31 May 1994 should be backdated to when the company bought the rights on 27 May. These are clearly matters that are subject to action before the Australian Broadcasting Authority. We as a parliament are presumably, if we follow the logic of the opposition's line of argument, supposed to say, `Blow all that. You must broadcast this test despite the fact that the laws did not come into effect, according to submissions put to the ABA, until three days after the purchase of these rights.'

It may be that Senator Tierney has information that I do not have. It may be the case that, in fact, the ABA has been misled. It may be that the minister has been misled. It may be that, in fact, the rights were purchased after the declaration of that anti-siphoning list. If that is the case, we have different circumstances altogether. But that is clearly not what the companies are saying at the moment.

The ABA has written to Australis Media asking it to put its case. Those opposite will recall, of course, that it was Australis Media that claimed to have the ownership of the rights. It was not pointed out to the ABA until 22 December 1994 that there had been the purchase of these rights by a junior company of Australis Media. When this matter came before the Senate select committee and the principals of Galaxy were asked about this, they explained, `Look, we are a very small company. We didn't really have all the infrastructure necessary to get our paperwork clear and right. What we had was our chief executive running around the world buying up shows wherever he could get them.'

We now discover that the ABA is looking at the facts to establish whether or not these rights were purchased when the company claims they were purchased. We have then a motion before the Senate which, essentially, is based on that fundamental failing in logic. A proposition is being put to the Senate that somehow or other the minister has been involved in some sort of debacle, that he has had eight months to get this right.

This simple proposition of the date on which these rights were bought is quite fundamental. We do not hear anything about it from the opposition. We hear a lot about flip-flopping, and I would like to hear a fair bit more about the flip-flopping opposition. I would like to hear, for instance, when the question of the anti-siphoning laws was debated. I would like to hear what its policy was. You never hear much about what the opposition policy really is but, occasionally, you get a glimpse of it.

For instance, on 20 May 1994, an edition of
Media Australia
stated:

speech.para: . . . Senator Richard Alston, also warned that ensuring wide-spread free-to-air access to sporting events could be to the detriment of the developing pay-tv industry.

He says it could be of detriment to the pay TV industry if we have an anti-siphoning regime. He said that it would be a travesty if the list was so far reaching that it undermined the viability of the fledgling pay TV industry. That is really at the nub of all of this, isn't it?

para.tab: What we have here is a case where the opposition wants the government to interfere in the commercial negotiations between the pay TV company and Channel 9. What you are expecting us to do is to say, `We'll pick the winner in terms of the arrangements that you enter into about the broadcast of the test series.' The government makes it very clear that it wants to see this test broadcast. It makes it very clear that Australis and the Nine Network have to reach an agreement and a sensible accommodation which would permit the free to air broadcast.

Also, the government has to recognise that the attitude of Channel 9, as expressed by David Leckie on the ABC and before the Senate select committee, was a disappointment. What he said was difficult to understand. `After all,' he said, `Channel 9 had met all the financial demands made upon it by Australis.' He said that the whole issue was a question of whether or not there be simultaneous broadcasting. What I find particularly odd is that Australis is able to reach agreements with the SBS over simultaneous broadcasting of the English FA Cup, with the ABC over simultaneous broadcasting of the netball world championship and, I understand, also with Nine over the US Masters golf.

I suppose there might be some debate about what simultaneous means in those circumstances. It was suggested by Channel 9 that simultaneous could, in fact, mean a delay of one minute. All of these things strike me as particularly odd. If there were a bit more goodwill around these issues, I do not see why there could not be an agreement reached in the case of the cricket. What strikes me as particularly interesting is the history of this matter in regard, for instance, to the New Zealand cricket test—where again we saw all this fracas. Of course, just before crunch time we saw a settlement. What we have here is two companies engaged in commercial negotiations: a free to air service company with a very large audience and a pay TV company with, I think, 3,000 subscribers. These companies are currently negotiating. Those opposite want the government of this country presumably to interfere in those negotiations and determine a result.

Those opposite do not say how that should be done. They say that, somehow or other, the government must come up with a situation whereby the test is made available to the majority of viewers. Quite clearly, that is the government's policy. But what those opposite have to do if they are to make those sorts of demands is explain their policy. How would they do it, if they are so clever? They want to interfere in negotiations; they should explain their position. We have seen their position.

talk.start.para: —It is opportunism.

—Their position is extremely clear, as Senator Sherry has indicated. It is opportunism. It is hypocrisy. It is based on the fraudulent notion that somehow they are not a free enterprise party. I thought that is what they stood for. They are saying that the market has failed. Perhaps the market has failed, but I would like those opposite to tell me how the government of this country is going to force Channel 9 to broadcast the West Indies tests. We say to the broadcasters that if they do not broadcast it there are very severe implications. There is an incentive for them to broadcast it.

para.tab: The anti-siphoning list, which I am sure senators are familiar with, is very extensive. It says that certain sports which have been traditionally seen by Australians should remain free to air. They should not be available to be siphoned off for commercial advantage, for smaller audiences which have the capacity to pay. It also says that if they fail to do that there are mechanisms to reduce the size of that list. So it is an incentive for them as Channel 9 or the free to air service broadcaster, whoever it might be, to somehow make sure they make an agreement. It is my belief that an agreement will be reached.

talk.start.para: —When?

—Just before the deadline because that is when the commercial advantage will be. That is the nature of free enterprise, surely. That is what you are saying. You are saying, `That is the nature of the market. Market negotiations should determine the outcome.'

para.tab: This really does come down to the opposition's position on media. It likes to use the Senate and the parliament as a device to grandstand and to present positions which are totally out of touch with reality—the commercial realities and, in fact, the law as it currently exists, which is currently being investigated by the ABA. It is not good enough for the opposition to somehow present itself as the great champion of the cricket fan when at the same time it presents no policy or options. All it does is present a notion that somehow the government has failed.

We will wait and see if the government has failed. Submission after submission that came before the committee from all sections of the industry supported the government's position on the anti-siphoning laws. A list has been prepared which is of international importance. It is the most comprehensive list prepared around the world.

Unlike the Liberal Party, the Labor government does approach these issues on a long-term basis. It does approach these issues with a clear view of where it is going. What do you stand for? You stand for nothing. You stand for absolutely nothing other than the hypocrisy—

talk.start.para: —They are like the English cricket team. They keep losing.

—Absolutely, and they will continue to lose while they come forward with this sort of nonsense. When it boils down to it, you have to state your policy, not just criticise the performance of others. What do you stand for? I come back to that and I will continue to come back to that.

para.tab: There are negotiations under way. I expect that they will be concluded in a way which demonstrates the efficacy of the government's anti-siphoning laws, which are designed to protect Australian citizens, to protect the viewing public and to ensure that there are going to be, for all time, free to air services on those very popular sports. That list includes such things as the Melbourne Cup, the AFL, rugby league, rugby union, Australian Cricket Board activities, soccer, tennis, netball, basketball, golf and motor sports. It does not include just a few issues.

If the commercial corporations involved in this industry cannot reach an agreement, consequences will flow in terms of the removal of those protected sports listed. In my view, we will quite clearly see a resolution; perhaps we will just have to wait a few more days to see that occur.
Debate interrupted.

debate.sub1.title: Finance and Public Administration Legislation Committee

talk.start.para: —I present the report of the Finance and Public Administration Legislation Committee on the supplementary estimates hearing concerning the National Media Liaison Service.

para.tab: Ordered that the report be printed.

speech.speaker: Reid Sen M.E.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move:

para.tab: That the Senate take note of the report.

speech.para: I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

para.tab: Leave granted; debate adjourned.
Debate resumed.

speech.speaker: Bourne Sen V.W.

talk.start.para: —This motion addresses one of the burning questions of the moment: will sports fans get to see the test cricket series between Australia and the West Indies when it starts in a week's time? The clock is ticking and there is a time bomb attached to it. If this impasse between Nine and Australis is not resolved satisfactorily, there will be a lot of angry sports fans out there.

para.tab: The opposition has stepped in now with a timely motion which seeks to lay the blame entirely at the feet of the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Mr Lee), and there is no doubt that the minister must take a large slice of the responsibility for what has gone wrong. We warned him last year that there were problems which needed to be rectified, but very little has been done to address those. It is quite clear that the licence conditions in the act invite the sort of manipulation which the Nine Network now appears to be indulging in. I have to ask whether the Australian Broadcasting Authority has dealt with this dispute in an even-handed manner. It seems to us that the early signals sent to Nine encouraged it to play hard ball on this. The government has now changed its position, which has created an impression of indecision all around.

The minister is not the only culprit. The Nine Network has taken a very boots-and-all approach, which makes one wonder who its public relations advisers are. Prime International and Australis Media have done their bit by giving out conflicting information about exactly who acquired the rights and when they acquired them. Having considered the evidence given to last Thursday's committee hearing on this issue, we have come to the view that the solution to this problem lies in the hands of the Nine Network. We can see no justification for Nine's insistence on an exclusive live broadcast. It was never envisaged that the free to air broadcasters would use the act to degrade coverage on pay television, but that is what has happened in this case, or potentially is about to happen.

The available evidence is that Nine actually knocked back the rights in May of last year, having been offered them by Trans World International acting for the West Indies Cricket Board of Control. The board appears to have been insisting on more money than it got from Nine in 1991 to avoid making a large loss on the tour, as happened in that year. Nine, according to Trans World International, said no. Australis then stepped in and said yes.

There appears to have been prior discussion between TWI and Australis, and this may well have influenced the asking price which Nine knocked back. Nine then sought to use its anti-siphoning privileges to obtain the free to air rights at a lower price than the price knocked back originally. Going by some press reports, the price that has been offered may be lower than it paid in 1991. Given that it did knock back the rights that first time, you have to ask yourself how serious Nine was about screening the tour in the first place. Did it decide that it was not a priority at that price given the lack of interest in the 1991 tour, even though it could have cut its costs by on-selling those rights to pay TV? Did it only change its mind when it found it would be screened on pay television? They are interesting questions.

Leaving them aside, we now have a situation where Nine could buy the rights at a reasonable price and show the series now. It has so far refused to do so unless it gets exclusive rights to the entire series on the ground. We do not believe that that is reasonable. Live broadcasts on pay television should not be a threat to Nine's revenue base or anyone else's. If they were to make a small but significant impact in the longer run, the price of free to air rights would adjust to reflect that.

Nine has argued that to allow live broadcasts on pay TV is like asking it to accept simultaneous broadcasts on Channel 7. That completely ignores the fact that Australis, unlike Seven, is not a free service. Nine has a strong cost advantage. It has no basis for demanding exclusive live coverage. That is where the minister has only belatedly got it right. He should have come to this position much earlier. It should have been the message last year, not this year.

What has happened to the other networks? Why have they not bought rights to the series? We appear to be seeing a very convenient agreement at work here which is giving Nine a very large negotiating advantage. It is high time that the Trade Practices Commission took a long hard look at the reluctance of other networks to get involved.

This motion calls on the minister to act. But he appears to be running out of options. The only hope is that Nine will finally see reason or that another network will buck that system and take the broadcast. The minister can pile on the pressure, but he cannot do much else.

He could have unravelled this mess much earlier. Had he accepted our suggestion late last year to allow pay TV licensees to buy pay rights to listed events, Nine would have had no way of enforcing a demand for exclusive live rights overall. It would have had to play with a straight bat. That is no longer an option because time is running out. But the Broadcasting Services Act must be amended to prevent this from happening again. A change to the licence conditions to allow the independent purchase of pay TV rights would certainly help. But there needs to be safeguards against the risk that Prime or Australis, for example, would then refuse to on-sell free to air rights to listed events at a realistic price.

The Democrats are proposing that the minister establish an arbitration system to handle claims by the free to air networks that this is happening. We believe that the ABA and the TPC should both be involved. If they determine that an unfair asking price is being asked, the minister should have the power to prevent pay TV from screening the event in

speech.para: question. But, in the meantime, we can only say again that Nine or, failing it, any other free to air network should take the rights as offered and screen the series. If they deny the public this event, they will all seriously undermine the very privileges they now enjoy.

para.tab: Pay television is here to stay. It is time that we all learned to live with it. However, I am sure that Nine would have come to an accommodation had the pay TV licensee been Optus Vision instead of Australis. I wonder whether its tactics have as much to do with buying time for Optus Vision as protecting its free to air interests. I am sure that we will face real problems with siphoning once Optus Vision is up and running. We should fix them right now.

We believe that the motion makes some very valid points but that it has two main weaknesses. Firstly, it reads as though the series has already started. It is premature to say that the minister has failed because a final judgment is yet to be passed. Secondly, it lacks the courage to criticise the bloody-mindedness of some networks, especially Nine. There is more than one cook spoiling this broth.

talk.start.para: —I rise with some pleasure to support my colleague Senator Tierney in the motion that he has put today. I was very pleased to see the new champion of free enterprise, Senator Carr, who I have never heard in quite such a vein before, getting very excited about this prospect of free enterprise. He is about the only one who is getting excited in Australia. Not too many cricket fans are getting excited. All they see is the prospect of the West Indies cricket tour taking place and their being unable to watch any of it on television.

para.tab: While I think of the current impasse, it is interesting to note that Senator Murphy and Senator Sherry are here. Unless this is resolved, they will not have a chance to see it, because pay TV will not be reaching Tasmania for some time. We have one of those rare occasions when we have two Tasmanians in the cricket side to go to the West Indies. I am quite sure that Tasmanians everywhere will be very disappointed if this impasse is not resolved and they do not get the chance to see David Boon and Ricky Ponting in action. Senator Denman is here as well. I am sorry that I missed her. We already have half of Tasmania here. Senator Calvert is in the chair. I had no idea that there were so many Tasmanians here.

The reason that we have reached such an impasse is not that the market has failed; it is that the minister has failed. The minister has failed to provide Australians with the opportunity. Anti-siphoning is the minister's idea. It is the minister's own creation. The fact that these events were not on the list—the list came out too late—is not the fault of anybody else but the government and the minister. If that list was in place at the right time, we would not find ourselves in the current impasse where it appears as though nobody will be able to get live coverage of that test tour in the West Indies. That tour has now become one of the most popular throughout the cricketing world.

It is not a fact that the market has got things wrong. It is a fact that the government has got things wrong due to its own mismanagement. It promised Australians that there would be free to air coverage of all of those major sporting events which were on that list. We understand the difficulties facing the West Indies Cricket Board of Control. A letter and a submission to a committee here last Friday from the West Indies Cricket Board of Control is a pretty unusual measure. You do not very often see somebody from outside Australia putting in a submission to a committee which is having a public hearing on legislation.
