The board stated quite clearly that if this area of the world, which is not very wealthy and which relies heavily on this sporting event to provide it with income by way of television rights, does not get these television rights and the dollars that it expects to come from it, it will find it very difficult to survive through this tour. It runs at a loss of about half a million dollars with every tour because of the economic conditions within those areas. It is only television rights—whether they be from Australia or the United Kingdom—that make these visits to the West Indies by touring teams profitable events. That money helps those young people who are less privileged than those in Australia to be able to start out in sporting careers. Without it they would not be able to survive.

What about the low income earners in Australia? Now that we know that Senator Carr is a champion of free enterprise, it looks as though we are the only ones that will try to make sure that something happens for the low income earners who rely entirely on free to air television to be able to provide them with the sporting coverage that they are entitled to get and which was promised to them by this government. If we reach the situation that currently exists where only some 2,000-odd people will be hooked up to pay TV and able to watch it through Galaxy—I guess if it is going to be on from midnight till seven in the morning you will probably be lucky if 200 of those 2,000 will watch the cricket all through the night—it is a very small percentage of Australians who will have any opportunity to watch this unless something is done very quickly.

I heard senators opposite say, `Yes, but we're acting as though the event has already started.' All we are doing is alerting you to the fact that, unless something is done very quickly, people will not be able to see it. It is a very short time before the first match is due to be telecast. It is a great pity that we have got to this stage where, in the week prior to this major event starting, we still do not know whether the events will be telecast. On current indications they will not be. A couple of weeks ago the minister supported the Nine Network's position that only it should have live television coverage. Now the minister is on the other side of the fence. He is adopting the position of the pay operator, Australis, which wants live coverage.

My colleague Senator Tierney has covered most of the areas in relation to this motion. I support the motion that Senator Tierney has put before the Senate. I call upon the minister to stop passing the buck. Let the minister get to the stage where this impasse is resolved so that all Australians who are between—

talk.start.para: —I know there will be a few bucks passing somewhere along the line, Senator Murphy. Let us hope those bucks are passed pretty quickly. I, along with all the other keen Australian sporting enthusiasts, want to ensure that all Australians have the opportunity of watching this significant sporting event which had already created a lot of interest before the issue of whether or not it will be televised was raised. I hope that all Australians who want to will be able to watch what we hope will be a most interesting series in the West Indies.
—In the short period of time that I have been in this place it never ceases to amaze me just how much time we can waste on nonsense.
—So the cricket is nonsense?

—No, it is not the cricket that is nonsense; it is stupid motions like this that we see time and time again that you people bring into this chamber. One thing about the motion is that it will not deliver the cricket to Australians. Yes, we all want to see the cricket but, as Senator Carr and others have pointed out, it is a commercial decision at the end of the day. The reason I say this is a ridiculous motion—and I think it is almost out of order—is that it is framed in a way that purports that the cricket is over and there has not been a telecast.
—Rubbish.

—It is rubbish. I am pleased you said that, because your motion is rubbish. The fact of the matter is that a particular circumstance has developed within the anti-syphoning list that will only ever occur once. As Senator Carr pointed out earlier, at the end of the day, the cricket will be shown.

para.tab: I think it is that very point that demonstrates the political opportunism that is contained within this process. This is a ridiculous situation. We have heard from the parties involved the claim that this sets a precedent. As I said, this is the only time this can ever occur under this legislation. I feel quite sure that, despite Senator Tierney's best efforts with his stupid motion, at the end of the day Australia will see the cricket. We will just have to wait and see. During the course of the debate Senator Carr said that you are a bunch of panic merchants. I think he is right about that.

I was disappointed because your motion did not contain any congratulatory or best wishes messages to the Australian cricket team and indeed the Tasmanians, David Boon and Ricky Ponting, in the West Indies. I certainly wish them all the best. I think Australia has the best cricket team in the world. I know that we will get to see them perform and deliver exactly that, that they are the best.

There is no sensible reason why the majority of Australians cannot see this cricket, except that there is dispute between two companies and it is totally commercial. I thought that you people were the ones who claimed to be the representatives of free enterprise. Yet you come in here with a motion that really says, `Direct the minister to fix the problem.' I think that is a contradiction of your policy; that is, if you have a policy about anything, but it is a direct contradiction of your policy about free enterprise.

There is nothing in the government's policy that prevents the showing of the series. I know Senator Carr has made these points already but I am going to make them again because it seems as though it takes a long time for them to sink in for those on the other side of the chamber. This matter involves the commercial decision of broadcasters; it is not the government's decision. The government has ensured, through the anti-syphoning list, that Australians will continue to receive popular free to air television, sporting and cultural programs.

I want to ask: where does that contrast with what your spokesman on communications, Senator Alston, has said? He was reported, and again Senator Carr said this, in the
Media Australia
publication on 20 May 1994. He warned that ensuring widespread free to air access to sporting events could be to the detriment of the developing pay TV industry.

Effectively, at this point in time, your policy is to have less—not more—free to air transmission of sporting events across the spectrum for Australians. You have the hypocrisy to come in here and move some stupid motion and waste the time of the Senate about one event that, as I said, I believe Australians will ultimately get to see. As has been pointed out by Senator Carr and Senator Bourne, the facts are that through this government's policies, the possibility of companies facing penalties is so great that, at the end of the day, they will bring this free to air broadcast to Australia.

I think you ought to at least understand some of the commercial toing-and-froing going on within this debate at the moment. You have displayed pure political opportunism by coming in here with this nonsense motion. It never ceases to amaze me that you choose to waste so much time of this place with these stupid motions when there are so many other important issues that we could deal with.

talk.start.para: —Getting communications policy right is an important issue.

—Well, Senator Tierney, you ought to have framed this motion somewhat differently. That is all I can say with regard to this issue. There is no validity to the processes that you have suggested. There is no validity to the condemnation that you have incorporated in your motion. Quite frankly, I hope that this debate ends very quickly so that we can get on with the relevant issues for this country.

speech.speaker: Crane Sen A.W.

talk.start.para: —I would like to support my colleagues from this side of the chamber, Senator Tierney and Senator Ferguson. I particularly want to congratulate Senator Tierney for his efforts over the last few days. He has moved this motion and highlighted very succinctly what is happening in Australia preceding the coming test series between the West Indies and Australia.

para.tab: I want to highlight and bring out a couple of points, because it is quite obvious the previous speaker from the other side, Senator Murphy, had not read paragraph (e) of the motion before us. I will read it out to him so he knows what it is. It says:

speech.para: (e) demands action from this incompetent Minister, with the West Indies cricket series only a matter of days away, to settle the dispute and protect the rights of millions of low-income viewers who rely on free-to-air television to see the West Indies cricket telecasts.

Obviously, you have not read it. It talks about the crisis which is before Australian viewers at this time. It is not good enough for government senators to stand up in here just seven or eight days before the start of the series and say, `I believe this matter will be resolved.'

para.tab: Senator Carr came in here and demanded to know our policy. We very strongly supported the television anti-siphoning provisions. That is where the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Mr Lee) has failed. He has not delivered on his own policy. That is why we have the situation which we have now. It is going to spread far beyond Tasmania, which was mentioned. It is going to spread beyond those people who cannot afford pay TV. It is going to spread into the outback of this country. It is going to spread into regional towns and all those areas that are not covered by pay TV. It is a situation which should not have arisen.

While I do not have figures in front of me, I suspect that cricket is probably the most watched national sporting event on TV in this country. It does not matter whether it is cricket, the Olympic Games or another sporting event: when those events are on, Australians like to watch them. They like to see the best in the world, and there is no doubt that this series will be the best cricket competition in the world in recent times. This situation has come about through the failure of this minister to get on with the job and get this problem sorted out, because it is his policy.

This situation is of particular personal interest to me because I, like many people in this chamber, have been not only a very keen cricket follower but also in my time a very active cricket player. I think this situation is an absolute tragedy for the education process of young people in this country and their ability to see the very best.

talk.start.para: —You just made a duck in that innings.
—I will enjoy playing you at cricket any day of the week, and I guarantee I will make more runs than you could every think or dream of.
—You're on. We'll have a cricket match.
—We will have a cricket match.
—You're on. We'll take that up.

—Right—love to play you in a cricket match any day of the week. But, unfortunately, under the rules of those opposite and the way their minister behaves, nobody will be able to watch it—and that is rather tragic indeed.

para.tab: Coming back to the importance of this particular motion and the fact that it is highlighting this situation, we hear people on the other side saying that there are far more important things for us to be dealing with. There is no question: there are many important things we have to deal with. But, certainly, communications and recreation opportunities that Australians get through watching events of this nature are also very important.

This chamber is the proper place to highlight the incompetence and lack of action that has occurred and the changing of the particular positions. We have here the product of a failed policy position and activity by a minister of the current government; that is the problem that we have. As I said earlier on, had this issue not be raised by the likes of Senator Tierney and others on this side the chamber, it could well have dragged on only for us to find in a week or so that we had no broadcasting of cricket.

I sincerely hope that at the end of the day, before the relevant period of time is up, we do hear an announcement to the effect that there will be broadcasting of the cricket which all or most Australians will have the opportunity to watch at their leisure. But I have great concerns as to whether that will actually occur. The day is getting very late for that to be done.

I conclude my comments by once again congratulating Senator Tierney and Senator Ferguson for their comments, which highlighted very strongly that Australians have a right, in a country as diverse, as wide and as long as ours is, to have access to events of such national importance and such national interest.

speech.speaker: Cooney Sen B.C.

talk.start.para: —I do want to add some words to those which have already been said. I think Senator Tierney, Senator Ferguson and Senator Crane should be congratulated for wanting to get the Australia and West Indies cricket series televised out here. Indeed, that is no doubt what everybody would want. But the interesting thing about the motion is that those opposite condemn the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Mr Lee) for not doing something about it. If we look at item (d) in Senator Tierney's motion, it says that it:

speech.para: . . . calls on the Minister to stop his monumental buck-passing and accept that he, as Minister, and not the television networks, is wholly responsible for this West Indies cricket coverage fiasco . . .

I suppose we on this side must make something of this motion. I think the only thing that can come from this motion is this: that three very senior members of the coalition have brought this motion forward, and they blame the government and the minister for not making available the cricket from the West Indies when it is played. The only thing we can deduce from that is that it must be the policy of those opposite that the government must ensure that this happens.

para.tab: I suppose we on this side would not make the same deduction because, as is clearly apparent from this, we will not, as it were, force Channel 9 or pay TV stations to take certain action. But it would seem that the only way we could get the cricket to be shown out here is to force these stations to broadcast it.

I suppose what comes from that is—I should imagine there would be some sympathy for this around the country—that, if the coalition were in government, it would pass laws forcing Channel 9 to program the cricket. Perhaps Senator Tierney could confirm or deny that at the end of my short address.

It would seem to me that the only way the government could ensure the cricket was made available would be for it to take over—commandeer and nationalise—the pay TV stations and make sure it gets the cricket out to Australia. I am sure Senator Sherry would agree with me that in the motion it is not the station that the opposition says should be condemned; it says that the government must do these things. The whole thrust behind this motion is that government is responsible for getting cricket here. The only way it would seem open for that to happen is if the government were to take over the station—I suppose only for the duration of the test cricket and for the duration of the games being played.

If you believe that that approach of taking over a particular station—Channel 9 in this case, or a pay TV station, depending on which one you want to broadcast on—is reasonable, then you can say that the minister is passing the buck by putting it on to the station. If I understand the thrust of this motion, the opposition is saying that the minister should ensure that the station does what the opposition says it should be doing. It thinks the minister should march in there and tell Channel 9, Channel 7 or Channel 10 what to do about things.

We on this side of the chamber say that ownership should be respected; that there should be freedom of expression; that television owners should have the right to be able to program their particular day in the way they choose, subject, of course, to the laws that protect people against pornography and things like that. But this suggestion made by Senator Tierney—a very responsible person, as we all know—that it is not a matter of banning things but a matter of, in a positive way, making stations show particular programs is an interesting extension of the sort of philosophy that has been put in the past.

The select committee into pay television, of which I believe he is a member, seems to be a very interesting committee. It is interesting to note the initiatives that have been taken apparently by the committee and by Senator Tierney, who I think heads that committee. I might be wrong about that, but I believe that is the case. He certainly shows a lot of interest in it if he is not. Whether he is head of the committee or not, it is interesting to note his initiative of suggesting that government take over private stations. If the television stations cannot do it, perhaps you ought to take over a radio station, Senator Tierney. Perhaps you can explain that when you give your answer in this debate.

I think I can speak on behalf of the government—as I said, I am not a member of the government; I am a member of the government party—and say that the government will not be taking over television stations and the companies that own them and forcing them to show particular programs.

If that is the opposition's position, I can understand why it uses the terms it does in this particular motion—why it condemns the government; why it says that there has been monumental buck passing; why it says that the government is wholly responsible and that the television networks are in no way responsible; and why it says that this is a coverage fiasco and that the minister is incompetent. But if, on the other hand, those opposite took the minister's approach—I simply ask them to put themselves in that position for a minute for the purposes of this exercise—and said that he is not and should not be obliged to take over television stations, they would perhaps see that their motion is a little harsh on him. Minister Lee is a person who respects the rights of property, and he respects the right of media people to run their own ship.

talk.start.para: —in reply—I thank all senators for their contribution to the debate. I want to make a number of comments about some of the things that have been said this afternoon in relation to this matter. My speech was followed by Senator Carr, who I found made a very surprising analysis of the whole situation. I was highly amused that a member of the socialist left—indeed, one of the doyens of the socialist left in Victoria—would be such a fierce advocate of private enterprise. We do not support Senator Carr's totally laissez-faire approach to this. We believe governments do have some role, unlike Senator Carr, it seems, in this matter.
—That makes you a member of the extreme tomato-throwing left, as they say in Victoria.
—Is that right?
—You are in good company with Bill Hartley and others.

—I thank Senator Schacht very much for his contribution. Senator Carr went on to make a number of rather silly points relating to this matter. He kept saying, and a number of government members have repeated these refrains, that `this will be solved', `we can still fix it' and `I have confidence that it still can be fixed.' I believe Senator Bourne of the Australians Democrats has a similar view. I call on particularly Senator Bourne to consider the fact that there are seven more days to this test.

para.tab: We have obvious evidence from both Australis, which operates Galaxy, and Channel 9 that they are digging in on their position. We have a very even-handed minister handling all this. He first supported Channel 9. He did that for about eight or nine days. Then he decided he would support Galaxy. So that is being very even-handed. Then he had a shot at supporting the free to air networks, and then he had a shot at supporting the pay TV people.

What we wish the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Mr Lee) would do is support the cricket fans of Australia. He can support the cricket fans of Australia by allowing cricket games to be seen on free to air television. It should not be too hard for the minister to do that because that is the government policy. All we are asking the minister to do is resolve this in the way in which it was intended to be resolved: people with low incomes having the opportunity to see important games—games that have wide coverage, games that are watched—without having to pay for that right.

In summary, we support the government's policy on anti-siphoning. We think it is a great policy. We believe a lot of the important sporting events in Australia should be left on free to air television. We are just calling on the minister to implement his own policy. I have great fears for the communications industry in this country—it is one of the great growth sectors of the future—because this is the tip of the iceberg that shows that this minister cannot run the very complex communications department if he cannot get the cricket scores right.
Question put:
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
That consideration of general business be not further proceeded with this day.

debate.sub1.title: Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade: Joint Committee

para.tab:
Debate resumed from 27 February, on motion by
Senator Burns
:
That the Senate take note of the report.

talk.start.para: —I hope this report is worth while, considering I have waded through an hour and a half of cricket to get to here. I find this report on the visit to Thailand and Laos a bit hard to believe. There are a lot of issues which are touched on that I could expand on. What is appalling is that they are not treated in any depth in the report. I know some of the background, so when the report says on page 21, paragraph 117, that Thailand is larger than Laos and Laos would like to retain its identity, I understand some of what that means. But I wonder how many other people could get much insight from that statement. The same paragraph says, `The two countries will remain close, but there are extensive plans for a number of dams on rivers in the north of Laos to generate hydro-electricity for sale, principally to Thailand.'

para.tab: I spent a few minutes at lunch to mention some of these projects in relation to the Asian Development Bank, and their more horrible implications. Nothing is mentioned here, except on page 18, where it is mentioned that in Thailand these concerns were raised at the Thailand Institute of Public Policy. These issues were obviously raised. They are of concern not only in Laos, but in Thailand, and indeed in the international development community.

I will take this opportunity to say that the Thai non-government organisation community is very active, and heavily involved in opposition to such projects. This is not a Thai-bashing exercise. The Thai communities, including extensive grassroots organisations such as the Buddhist development networks, are also threatened by the intrusion of transnational influence, and the astronomically growing power of economic elites in their own nation.

Relocation of villages at gunpoint is also known in Thailand and, in spite of laws and principles on deforestation, Thailand's active environment movement fights clearing of so-called degraded forest for use as blue-gum plantation feeding the Japanese pulp industry, and clearing even of areas like the last indigenous pine forests near Chang Mai, having three unique Thai species. This was heavily protested by environmentalists, and the local Karen and Lanna-Thai population.

On page 14 we see a mention of a visit to the Mae Moh lignite mine, a project supported by AIDAB and feeding directly into the neighbouring power station. A few references give clues to the cognoscenti who know that the Mae Moh power plant has been a running environmental disaster, polluting the air and water to an extent where the communities that were worse affected raised the issue through extremely militant civil action. I leave to your imagination what is referred to with the phrase, `water supply and environmental problems and their solutions', and the implications of the phrase, `relocation of villages'. Is this an example of our `clean coal' technology?

What is most distressing is that, while the dams in Laos are briefly mentioned, more attention being given to the state of the Chancery building, the sentence in paragraph 131 on page 23 seems to imply that the delegation not only was not willing to report on some of the social or environmental implications of the dams, but instead seemed to be presenting the dams as an opportunity for Australian business. Indeed, they are, and several Australian businesses are already involved. One wonders how that fits into a code of conduct for businesses in South-East Asia.

I also note that the concern of the Thais over the remarks made on the possible sale of Steyr rifles to the Khmer Rouge was raised on several pages, and several times. It appears to be one of the dominant issues that came out of the Thai visit. The main point about the proposal to sell Steyr rifles to the Thais is that, currently, while the Thai side is not willing to proceed with the sale, the Australian defence industries and the Australian government seem to be more than willing to participate.

I find this report wholly inadequate as a guide to our relations with these countries, and will put more information before the Senate in the future. I have already spoken once on development in Thailand and Laos today, but I seek leave to continue my remarks.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

Debate resumed from 2 February, on motion by
Senator Robert Ray
:
That the Senate take note of the report.

speech.speaker: Troeth Sen J.M.

talk.start.para:
—I would like to comment on this report by the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters entitled
Women, elections and parliament
with regard to the progress that is being made in identifying and encouraging women to stand for parliament. I noted with interest what I suppose is an official response in this month's committee bulletin which referred to the `SNAP decision', the decision made by the SNAPs, the sensitive new age politicians on the hill. It says:

speech.para: Perhaps this indicates what's to come—quick, understandable responses to speed up equality in the House.

In so far as the committee recommended that the minister authorises the committee to monitor developments in the area of participation by women in the electoral process and to report on this matter from time to time, I do not regard that as a quick moving response. The coalition would perhaps have liked a more positive report. In looking at the numbers of women in politics the first thing to be said is that, if we are serious about the goal of getting more women in parliament, we will need to work a great deal harder than we do at present. The number of women in parliament has been increasing but it would be hard to call the response brilliant. At present I think we are in a holding pattern, and that probably goes for all parties.

para.tab: A number of factors work against greater numbers of women entering politics. In part, the low number of female politicians is linked with women's lower economic standing and over-representation in lower socio-economic groups generally. There are logistical constraints associated with women's family responsibilities and the demands of a parliamentary career, particularly in federal politics. It is very hard to balance the rearing of small children with the long hours and frequent travel associated with a career in politics. Some women would see the confrontational style and atmosphere of male dominated parliaments and unsympathetic treatment of female parliamentarians by the media as a disincentive to run for parliament, but probably some males find this a disincentive also.

Given these constraints, what strategies are in place or could be utilised to entice more women into the political arena? Should we change the system and make it more appealing to women, such as lessening the sitting hours, providing more travel allowance, and providing creches and tutors for the children of parliamentarians? Should we implement a quota system, as the ALP has done, and force parties to preselect a certain number of women in a given time frame? Should we try educating young women at school to be more aggressive and assertive so that the confrontationist style of federal parliament, or indeed state parliament, would not appear threatening? Should we encourage more women to stand for preselection and be more supportive of those who do, so that in time there will be so many to choose from that no-one could ever say, `But there were simply not enough women of substance to choose from'?

I would like to comment on the quota system implemented by the Labor Party. Labor's quota system, with an aim of 35 per cent female representation by the year 2002, has so far failed to jump the intransigent hurdle of factional dealings. Many seats that should have been given to women, had the party machinery been serious about selecting more women, turned into factional warfare with principles of gender equity lost in battle.

talk.start.para: —What happened in Kooyong?

—We had women standing, and the best person was chosen for the seat—Petro Georgiou. Perhaps one of the most derisory examples of the way the ALP factional system works is the slipping down to an unwinnable third spot on the ALP's Western Australia ticket for a half Senate election. When factional interests are so powerful that even the position of the Senate's President is not safe, what hope do women have of ensuring that their interests are going to be recognised?

para.tab:
The quota has not proved popular in the electorate, as numerous statistics would attest to. A news poll in the
Australian
on 12 October revealed that nine in 10 people did not support a quota system, although a clear majority of them believed there should be more women in politics. At a Women in the Workplace Conference in Sydney in October, it was reported, again in the
Australian
, that about 90 per cent of women present voted against quotas. Women at that conference said that quotas will:

speech.para: . . . reinforce negative perceptions of women as competent performers . . . They—
that is, women—
can be too easily stigmatised regardless of their level of performance.

The most recent ALP idea is to create a fund to woo women into parliament. It seems likely that such a fund would divide men and women, and pit women against each another in an attempt to access money from the fund. It may serve only to strengthen one faction at the expense of another.

talk.start.para: —What are you going to do, Judith? What's the Liberal Party doing?

—I will be talking about that in a moment. Senator Schacht ought to contain his impatience. I know he is very anxious to find out what the Liberal Party is doing, but I will be talking about that in a moment. Identification and encouragement of potential women candidates is the answer—not internal funding, which will cause divisions. It is significant that, in an article on the fund, Dr Carmen Lawrence said, `It is causing certain difficulties for the party structure.'

para.tab: Ironically, the woman who is the main push behind this fund idea is Joan Kirner. She resigned to allow more women to follow her in Victorian state politics, but her seat of Williamstown was won by a man. Perhaps Ms Kirner would have done more good for the women's movement if she had stayed in her seat. In contrast, I would like to outline some of the ground breaking work the Liberal Party has already done in supporting women, both in the community and in parliament.

talk.start.para: —You have a thick hide, Judith.

—Yes, I do have a thick hide. I am going to stay here and make my remarks. However, as I probably will not have time to entirely cover the subject of Liberal Party and women, I will seek leave to continue my remarks later. But I would like to make a few further general comments at this stage of the debate.

para.tab: By definition, political life will never appeal to everyone. I was interested to read a comment by Steve Vizard—a television personality in Melbourne—who, the media reported, was also approached to stand for the Victorian federal seat of Kooyong. He was somewhat stunned that he was approached to stand for that seat. He said he was interested in issue-driven politics and he was interested in party politics. He told the media and the people who suggested he enter politics that he was looking forward to leaving his family, his home, his beach house, his farm, his business and his life so he could go to Canberra—that international city of fun—and have journalists write demeaning articles about him.

Unfortunately, I have also found that many people in the community could not ever imagine themselves running for political office. To me, it is with a degree of sadness that I contemplate there is not a bigger pool of people from which to draw future parliamentarians. There will never be huge numbers of men and women volunteering to lead a life which requires long separations from family and friends, the possible truncation of a professional career, and such a commitment to timetables that many find it an infringement on their personal freedom.

I think we should realise that, in our efforts to cast the net far and wide to find suitable candidates—particularly females—many people simply cannot contemplate leaving their family and leaving their career. In many cases people spend years building up a professional career, and many people cannot contemplate leaving that to come to Canberra to lead the sort of life that many of us lead, although I do that very willingly because I am very pleased to make a contribution. However, at this stage, I seek leave to continue my remarks at a later date.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

debate.sub1.title: Report of the Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee

para.tab:
Debate resumed from 1 March, on motion by
Senator Burns
:
That the Senate take note of the report.

speech.speaker: Harradine Sen B.

talk.start.para: —I want to speak on the report of the Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee to express my appreciation, and no doubt that of the members and participating members of the committee, for the extraordinary way in which the public and interested organisations responded at short notice to requests for submissions. I also want to place on the record my appreciation, and I am sure that of all other honourable senators who participated in the meetings of the committee, of the work of the staff in bringing together the various views that were placed before the committee.

para.tab: There were a number of complaints from a number of people that they did not have time made available to them to make submissions. That is one of the things that the Senate needs to give further consideration to in respect of the committees that are considering the various pieces of legislation that come before this chamber. It is unfortunate that so many organisations and people who are interested in and concerned with this legislation were unable to make submissions.

However, with very short notice we did get rather substantial submissions from a number of organisations. Those organisations are listed in an appendix on page 28 of the report. I think there was only one letter which actually supported the legislation. The submissions overwhelmingly opposed the legislation. The legislation which is the subject of this report is the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3). The legislation has two operative sections. On page 1 of the majority report it states:

Firstly,
clause 2
which contains the proposed subsections 36(3) and (4) will exclude certain persons who might otherwise possess membership of a `particular social groups' from claiming refugee status due to their membership of a `particular social group' based on the fertility control policies of any country. The proposed subsection 36(4) mentions the fertility control policies of the People's Republic of China (`PRC') as a specific example of a foreign government's fertility control policies.
Secondly, the Bill addresses the issue of a refugee applicant making repeat or multiple applications for refugee status.

speech.para: I will not cover the matters in respect of the session. All those people who gave submissions and presented their case to the committee condemned this bill. Even the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees stated that the legislative approach was not the approach to adopt. He has since publicly branded the bill as unusual, unfortunate and without precedent.

para.tab: It was denounced by the Law Council of Australia, Amnesty International, the Catholic Bishops of Australia, the Bar Association of New South Wales, prominent feminists, researchers Dr Renate Klein and Dr Lynette Dumble, FECCA, the Refugee Council of Australia and the Australian Law Reform Commission. Some excerpts of their opposition are to be found in the minority report that I have presented.

The majority report was signed only by the government members and, if you read between the lines, it is less than enthusiastic for the legislation. It is not for me to justify the majority report. There were dissenting reports by the opposition senators—Senator Ellison, Senator O'Chee and Senator Abetz. There was a further dissenting report from Senator Spindler and a dissenting report from me.

This legislation, if enacted, would tarnish Australia's international reputation as a leading defender of human rights; would legislatively restrict Australia's obligations under the refugee convention in a manner likely to be injurious to the principle of non-refoulement, which is not handing back refugees to their persecutors; would be a confused and completely unnecessary response to a decision of the refugee tribunal as held by the Federal Court; and, most importantly, would send a message to the PRC government which it would interpret as condoning its fertility control policies involving forced abortions, coerced sterilisations, crippling fines, anti-worker penalties and other punishments.

A lot of fear has been engendered about the refugee situation. There is a lot of confusion that this is the same sort of bill as the No. 2 bill, which dealt with the Sino-Vietnamese situation. Let me make it perfectly clear that, in order to achieve refugee status, an asylum seeker must overcome two hurdles. The refugee convention requires that they must establish a well-founded fear of persecution if returned to their country. That fear must be on the ground of a convention—race, religion, nationality, political opinion or social group. If you cannot jump both hurdles, you are not accepted. Even if you can prove persecution, you are still not accepted unless that persecution is on the ground the convention grants.

Are the fertility control policies of the PRC on the grounds of race? No. Colour? No. Race or religion? No. Nationality? No. Political opinion? No. They are against a particular social group, and that particular social group is defined by a consideration of how it is perceived by the rulers. That is the essence of the judgment of the independent Refugee Review Tribunal and the judgment of the Federal Court.

So you could have a situation where asylum seekers in Australia could have a real fear, a well-established and reasonable fear, that they are to face coerced abortion or sterilisation. They will not be able to jump that second hurdle if the government continues with the legislation and instructs the courts and the refugee tribunal to disregard the policies of the People's Republic of China in this matter. I appeal to senators to read this particular report thoroughly before they come to their conclusion, and I particularly ask the government senators to do just that.
(Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I appreciate your cooperation in giving me the opportunity to spend a few minutes addressing some remarks on the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs into the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1995. I want to address some of the comments made by Senator Harradine, the speaker who preceded me in this debate.

para.tab: Senator Harradine mentioned a timetable for submissions. I agree with him on that matter—and I suggest that it is probably one of the few matters in his comments that I do agree with—but I do think that, if legislation committees are going to work and work properly, more time has to be made available to take submissions and for the public to attend.

This particular bill was referred to the committee, I believe, on the Tuesday when we first sat—I think it was 31 January. The committee met on the Friday, 3 February—a matter of a few days. It was not possible for me to beat up a bandwagon back in my own state of Western Australia in order to get submissions to the committee, but I am sure I could have matched the numbers that came in who were in opposition to the legislation, with perhaps a hundredfold of those constituents of my state who are exceptionally concerned about this problem.

If my home telephone over the Christmas period is any indication of this, there is enormous concern in the community of Western Australia. My colleague Senator Panizza, who is sitting in the chamber, had cause to agree with me when I was addressing some remarks to this matter in the chamber some weeks ago. I think we do have to look at Friday committees and perhaps use this as an opportunity for the community to make comment on matters of high importance such as those that this legislation addresses.

The other matter I want to comment on is the reference Senator Harradine made to the Australia-New Zealand South Pacific representative of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, Mr Pierre-Michel Fontaine, and some of the remarks that are reported in the media attributed to Mr Fontaine. Those remarks concern me greatly.

Mr Fontaine gave evidence to the committee, and that evidence is in the record of the committee's deliberations. I have seen, since then, conflicting remarks attributed to Mr Fontaine that do not in any way match the comments that he, as the official representative of the UNHCR, gave to this Senate committee. I will give him the benefit of the doubt because from time to time the media in Australia does not get things right. As a matter of fact, at the National Immigration and Population Outlook Conference held by the Bureau of Immigration Research in Adelaide of last week, his comments were reported by two newspapers and the two reports conflicted. It just shows how far it can go.

I am making further investigations on the matter. I have sought a copy of his speech to that conference, and I will follow that through. I am concerned that a person of his stature, with such responsibility in Australia, has not corrected the record in relation to those conflicting remarks—maybe he has tried. The record I will stand with is that of the comments he directly gave to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs.

I turn to the signing of the report. I am a signatory to the report of that under the signature of Senator Cooney, the chairman of the committee. I stand by everything that is said in that report. I agree with Senator Harradine in that some comments in the report may be seen by some as not all that complimentary of government action in this regard. Because I do not have the report in front of me, I refer to the use of ministerial discretion, which is something that we in government have to address in the long term.

I was very surprised when I received my copy of the report last evening to note that the dissenting report was signed by Senators Abetz, Ellison and O'Chee. I was amazed to find that Senator Short had not signed it. Senator Short is the opposition spokesperson on immigration. I fully expected him, as one of the leaders in his political party and indeed in the coalition, to attach his signature to the dissenting report. It is not as if Senator Short had not seen the dissenting report. On Tuesday evening during the legal and constitutional committee hearing on the Racial Hatred Bill, I sat beside Senator Short as he proofread and corrected the draft of the dissenting report.

So Senator Short has seen and made contributions to the report, but he has not put his signature to it. I wonder why that is the case. Perhaps it is to save him the embarrassment that he has gone through over the Migration Legislation Amendment (No. 3), which deals with compensation through legal action for persons unlawfully in Australia. Last year the Senate rejected that bill. The opposition, after opposing the bill last year, has done a huge backflip by supporting it on Tuesday of this week in the House of Representatives. Is Senator Short seeking to avoid embarrassment? I believe that, when Mr Howard's attention is drawn to this bill, when he understands the full repercussions and ramifications, he will—

talk.start.para: —Madam Acting Deputy President, on a point of order: I have listened to Senator McKiernan with a great deal of tolerance, but he is now seeking to ascribe an improper and dishonourable motive to Senator Short which I can certainly assure the Senate he would not ever have. I find Senator McKiernan continuing to go down this line grossly offensive and also contrary to the standing orders. I respectfully submit that Senator McKiernan be accordingly instructed not to continue such an attack on Senator Short, who is not in the chamber.

para.tab:
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator West)
—There is no point of order. However, perhaps you would like to discuss the report, Senator McKiernan.

talk.start.para: —I was discussing the report, Madam Acting Deputy President. When Mr Howard sees the report and understands the ramifications of the bill, there will be another backflip. My greatest concern with the report is that it has been reported in the Australian media today. I have seen those reports myself. I believe at this moment in time the wires between Australia and different parts of Australia, particularly the southern part of China, are hot with the news that Australia is an easy touch. The opposition parties, particularly opposition senators with their dissenting report, together with Senator Harradine and Senator Spindler, will clearly tell people that numbers are against the government for the passage of this bill. Australia will again be seen as an easy touch for illegals.

para.tab: That would be a further embellishment on the decision of the Federal Court by Mr Justice Sackville last year, which expanded beyond the realms of imagination in adding into jurisdictions throughout the world the definition of a refugee.

There have been numerous cases in various parts of the world. Fortunately, only those that have changed the laws to advantage of refugees are quoted. But I am assured by learned colleagues and those with many more dealings with the law than I have that there have been cases in other parts of the world that have sought to keep the definition where it is, to not expand it in the way that perhaps the Canada case has.

The Canada case is quoted in the report. I cannot remember the quotation, but it is referenced in the report. Unfortunately, there are many other countries in which actions have been taken to seek a similar form of expansion on the basis of the fertility control policies of one or another country. I am certainly hopeful that when the bill comes forward for debate in this chamber next week or in the weeks to come the coalition parties will take a responsible attitude and support the government.
(Time expired)

speech.speaker: Short Sen J.R.

talk.start.para: —I was not going to participate in the debate on this report because the debate will take place when the bill is debated, but I really cannot let go the absolutely misleading and scurrilous comments that Senator McKiernan has made. I know that he knows he has been deliberately misleading. The simple fact is—

—Mr Acting Deputy President, on a point of order: we are here about matters of concern to Senator Short because he feels motive was imputed to him, but he has just described Senator McKiernan as `deliberately misleading' the Senate. I believe that is unparliamentary and I would ask you to ask him to withdraw it.
—On the point of order, if a senator has deliberately misled the Senate, as Senator McKiernan has, then I cannot see how it is unparliamentary to describe an actual, factual situation.

para.tab:
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McKiernan)
—I am in a very difficult position. On taking advice, I am advised that the words you have used, Senator Short, are unparliamentary and I would ask you withdraw them.

talk.start.para: —Unparliamentary?

—I rise on a point of order. Senator Short used the words `deliberately misleading'. Are you saying that for a senator to suggest that another senator is misleading the parliament is unparliamentary? Surely you are not saying that. It is being said all the time.
—Thank you, Senator Harradine. As I explained earlier, I am in a difficult position and I am taking advice on this. My advice is—
—Call for a replacement.

—Order! My advice is that it is the use of the word `deliberately'. Were the assertion to be `misleading' it would be parliamentary, but when it is in the form of `deliberately misleading', precedent says that it is unparliamentary and I would ask you again to withdraw, Senator Short.
—I withdraw, but I substitute: `Senator McKiernan's completely misleading comments which may or may not have been deliberate'.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, on a point of order: if you are able to advise me that this is playing with words, that is fine. We understand very clearly the meaning of deliberately misleading, which implies intent. That is the point Senator Short is standing up to object to. He has just played around with those words in his so-called withdrawal and I would ask you if you could rule on that.

—I rise on the same point of order. This is the most ridiculous point of order that we have ever had from Senator Crowley. Senator Short has very properly said that the statement was completely misleading. That is parliamentary. It is Senator Crowley's sensitivity on the subject which is damning of the government.

—This afternoon the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Bolkus) put out a press release in relation to the report that we are now debating; in particular in relation to the dissenting report by coalition senators, my colleagues Senator Ellison, Senator O'Chee and Senator Abetz. Senator Bolkus made several quite wild assertions in that statement. They are misleading, confused and inaccurate assertions and I will take this opportunity to refute them.

para.tab: Indeed, I have refuted them in the form of a press release which I put out an hour or so ago. Given the content of Senator Bolkus's statement I could think of no more appropriate title for my press release than `Has Bolkus gone bonkers?' One would have to think that he has gone bonkers if one looks at his press release.

His statement was prompted by the dissenting report by the coalition senators. He said that the coalition senators have opposed the bill. Wrong! The coalition senators have not opposed the bill. What my colleagues have said is that the bill has several major deficiencies and its consideration by the parliament should be deferred until the minister attempts to resolve those problems.

The minister says that I expressed my support on 30 December 1994 for measures to present the undermining of Australia's refugee-humanitarian program and to protect our borders from illegal immigration. What I actually said was that whilst I welcomed the belated statement on that day about these matters from the minister, the coalition would—

speech.para: need to see the detail of the Government's proposed new legislation before taking a final decision on it. However, the Coalition agrees with the intent of the legislation and will take a sympathetic approach to it.

That is what I said on 30 December and that remains the case.
In line with the spirit of my 30 December statement the coalition supported the expeditious passage of Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1995 which provided for the return to China of the several hundred Sino-Vietnamese illegal boat people who arrived in Australia from around mid-November 1994.

para.tab: The fact is that the bill that the Senate reported on yesterday is acknowledged by everyone, including the minister's own department, to be very seriously flawed. It has many flaws to it, as my colleagues on the Senate committee have so ably pointed out in their dissenting report. They were not alone in this criticism. This bill has attracted criticism from the Law Council of Australia, the Australian Law Reform Commission, the Catholic Bishops of Australia, the Bar Association of NSW, the Federation of Ethnic Communities' Councils of Australia, Amnesty International, the Refugee Council of Australia and many other organisations.

The minister also said in his press release today that he had already discussed with me amendments `which may clarify and give certainty to the legislation'. I raise two points about that. First of all, that was wrong. The fact is that, during the Senate committee hearings, there was general agreement not only by non-governmental witnesses but by the minister's own department that amendments would be required. Three hours after the minister made his statement, some amendments were faxed through. But at the time of making his statement, there had been no amendments. The minister had had no discussion at all with me about amendments, other than a passing conversation which I initiated with one of his advisers yesterday, saying, `Where on earth are the amendments that you know full well you need?'

The minister has been absolutely misleading, for whatever reason—and Senator McKiernan picked that up today and followed the same line, regrettably—in his interpretation of the whole situation. All I can say to the Senate is that this bill has many serious difficulties. It is not necessarily irretrievable but it does need some major amendments. We will be considering our final position with respect to the bill in the next few days, following the normal due processes. I find the assertions and allegations that have been made, both by the minister today and regrettably by Senator McKiernan, who is in the chamber, regrettable because they are so totally inaccurate.

speech.speaker: Abetz Sen E.

talk.start.para: —The first thing that needs to be understood is that the evidence before the Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee was overwhelmingly opposed to the legislation as it is currently drafted. For the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Bolkus), Senator McKiernan and others to assert otherwise would be incorrect. The shadow minister, Senator Short, has indicated a number of organisations that oppose the legislation. It would be very helpful if we also heard from Sir Ronald Wilson, a former judge of the High Court of Australia and President of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. This is what he said:

speech.para: Coerced sterilisation or abortion is a flagrant disregard of a fundamental human right. In my submission, it is wrong for the Government to ask the Parliament and people of this country to condone the exclusion of asylum seekers from refugee status based on a well founded fear of that kind of persecution.

Indeed, the committee heard evidence in camera from witnesses from China as to some of the barbaric procedures that are implemented in pursuit of the so-called fertility control policies. Some people, unfortunately, refer to them as one-child policies, but in certain areas of the People's Republic of China, if you do not have a licence to have a child, you are not allowed to have one. That is then enforced by compulsion in certain areas.

para.tab: If the government wants to go on public record as a fighter for human rights and give credence to that sort of behaviour by the People's Republic of China, let it do so, but let it do so openly, honestly and without the sort of obfuscation that the minister tried to engaged in during the debate today. His scandalous press release was clearly incorrect. He asserted that he spoke to the shadow minister for immigration and ethnic affairs, which he clearly has not done. Clearly, the government is realising that it is in a very difficult position; it cannot get out, so what does it do? The best form of defence is to attack, so it sought to attack Senator Jim Short in a press release and also in this parliament just a few moments ago.

As Senator Short has so ably pointed out, the attack has misfired; indeed, it has backfired. Senator Bolkus—the minister—and others who support the Labor Party stance on this issue must be severely embarrassed. It would be relatively rare, I would suggest, that one could get such a diverse coalition of organisations and interests all saying the same thing about this legislation, including the Liberal Party, the National Party, the Democrats, Senator Brian Harradine, the bar associations, the law societies, the President of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission—and the list goes on and on.

The Labor Party is asking us to believe that it has it absolutely right and everybody else has it absolutely wrong. The simple situation is that the Labor Party has it wrong and I am very comfortable with having my name associated with the dissenting report.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I present the government's response to the report of the Community Affairs References Community—

speech.para: Senator Herron
Chairperson
Senate Community Affairs
References Committee
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Herron
I write in response to your Committee's Inquiry into the Validation of CAM and SAM Funding of Nursing Homes.

I would like to emphasise the considerable importance this Government places on the nursing home validation program. The validation program is an accountability program which helps protect frail elderly nursing home residents by checking that funds allocated to nursing homes to care for their residents is actually spent on residents' care.

The reference was initially made to the Committee by the Senate on 30 September 1993. In December 1993 the Committee sought comments on the Terms of reference from all nursing homes. There were public hearings in June 1994, and the Committee tabled its report on 16 November 1994.

I am pleased to note that after such a comprehensive canvassing of all nursing homes, the Committee's report did not find major systemic problems with the validation program. The report usefully identified some areas where we can improve our administration of the program, and I welcome those recommendations which focus on the need for more timely processes (recommendation 1), more training (recommendations 2 and 3), clearer and simpler information, and consultation and training for nursing home proprietors and staff (recommendations 4, 5, 7, 8, 9, 10).
I am pleased to be able to report that considerable work is being undertaken in each of these areas, for example:
.The Department has asked the Australian Law Reform Commission to help redraft legislation to make it simpler and clearer;

.the Government initiated a major consultation of nursing home accountability and regulations, chaired by Sir William Keys. Within a fortnight of becoming Minister, I approved all of his recommendations;

.the Department is committed to improving timeliness of the validation process—all of 1986-87 validations are completed and more than 70% of 1987-88 are completed. A risk management approach will be adopted in the validation program, which will enhance the timeliness of the process and enable the program to be brought up to date.
.currently a major consultancy is underway to improve the information the Department sends to nursing homes.

The Government is committed to both the protection of frail aged residents of nursing homes and to a streamlined and efficient administration and regulation system. In responding to the Committee's report the Government is concerned to maintain that balance.

It is on this basis that the Government cannot agree to recommendation 6 of the majority report. Professor Gregory's first report on the structure of nursing home funding noted that option 2 would minimise flexibility and profitability for nursing homes. I should make clear however that following Professor Gregory's second report, the Government is considering more relevant changes to nursing home funding arrangements. I note that a Dissenting Report by four of the eight Committee members disagrees with the majority report recommendation number 6 while supporting all of the other recommendations.

The Government's response to each of the recommendations is attached. I will be tabling this letter in Parliament in the week commencing 27 February 1995 as the Government's response to the References Committee's report.
Yours sincerely
Dr Carmen Lawrence
ATTACHMENT 1
SENATE COMMUNITY AFFAIRS REFERENCES COMMITTEE REPORT ON VALIDATION OF CAM AND SAM FUNDING OF NURSING HOMES
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO RECOMMENDATIONS OF THE REPORT
Chapter 2—Timeliness of Validations
That the Department of Human Services and Health provide a detailed schedule to the Committee outlining its proposed program for completing outstanding validations.

The key component in completing outstanding validations will be the successful adoption of a risk management approach to scheduling and conducting validations. This initiative is part of the recently introduced quality assurance strategy in the nursing home program. A risk management approach to validation started in October 1994. This approach still means that all nursing homes are subject to validation, but it means homes most at risk of not spending care funds on residents' care will be visited earlier and more frequently, and that all financial records may not be validated.
The resulting schedule is a rolling program of validation visits based on homes' performance against a range of factors.

The Department is unable to give a detailed schedule of the program for completing outstanding validations as the validation program will now be constructed to deal progressively with homes which indicate the highest level of risk against a range of indicators. As one of these indicators is length of time since last validated then homes not validated for earlier years are likely to be visited first.

At the beginning of 1994-95, there were 5000 outstanding validations. The Department proposes a risk management strategy based on validation of 75% of outstanding home-years on an ongoing basis. Accordingly, some 3500 of the outstanding years are likely to be validated. The department will have a capacity to perform at least 1500 validations a year which would see the program brought up to date, within existing legislative parameters, by the end of 1996/97. This enables validation responsibilities to be met under the new benefit payment scheme, effective from 1 July 1993, which requires a fee to be set within three years of the end of the year of funding.
Chapter 3—The Validation Process
That the Department of Human Services and Health improve its training program for validators to ensure an optimal level of consistency in the validation process.
The Government supports this recommendation. Training of validators is a key component of the recently introduced quality assurance strategy for nursing homes.

The Department's internal validation documentation is currently being revised and its implementation will be supported by staff training. The Department is currently developing a nursing home manual which draws together nursing home information needed to understand Government requirements in operating nursing homes. This will be available for use by Departmental staff and the nursing home industry in March 1995.
Other measures which will maximise consistency include regular management and staff conferences and improved management information systems.

These measures will ensure staff are able to provide clear statements of requirements to nursing home proprietors. Validators will for example provide improved information to new proprietors, facilitate industry information seminars, implement a nationally consistent validation methodology for all homes based on risk management and improve communication with homes on the validation process.
These initiatives will help ensure consistency across the program.

That the Department of Human Services and Health encourage the upgrading of the professional qualifications of validators, and that validators be required to have formal accountancy qualifications or other appropriate training or qualifications.

The Government agrees in principle with this recommendation. The validation program has progressively moved to improve the qualifications of validation staff. The percentage of staff with formal qualification has increased from 50 percent in 1992/3 to 60 percent in 1994/5. Recruitment is based on relevant skills including appropriate qualifications, and on experience with the nursing home funding system.

para.emphasis: Recommendation 4: Information to the Nursing Home Industry

speech.para: That the Department of Human Services and Health publish a document, expunged of confidential internal Departmental information, that would provide guidance to nursing home proprietors on the validation process, and:
.that this document form the basis for validations for the year in which it is issued and that any changes to the validation process be incorporated in subsequent editions of the document;

.
that the document be widely disseminated throughout the
industry.

The Government supports this recommendation. The aged care program is reviewing information provided to nursing homes including about validation process. The Department's internal validation documentation is currently being revised and a version for proprietors will be released publicly. This document will replace the validation information kit released to the nursing home industry in December 1992. The nursing home funding manual currently being developed will also include information on the validation process.

para.emphasis: Recommendation 5: Information to the Nursing Home Industry

speech.para: That the Department of Human Services and Health issue guidelines to the nursing home industry outlining the criteria used in approving applications for extensions of repayment periods in relation to the recovery of overpayments.

The Government supports this recommendation. As described above the aged care program is reviewing information provided to nursing homes including information to proprietors about the outcome of validations. Information about extension of repayment periods for recovery of overpayments will be included in the nursing home funding manual which is currently being drafted. The repayment period will also be discussed with proprietors at the time of validation exit interviews and will be included in the advice to proprietors of changes to their advances of nursing home benefit as a consequence of the imposition of a negative loading.
Chapter 4—CAM/SAM Boundary Issues

Majority Report—The Committee recommends that the Government introduce a funding system for nursing homes based on a system of acquitting labour costs and providing a non-acquitable grant for non-labour costs, based broadly on the system proposed in Option 2 of the Gregory report, Review of the Structure of Nursing Home Funding Arrangements: Stage 1.

Minority
Report
—That the current CAM/SAM funding system should be maintained.

The Government has considered carefully the recommendation and views of both the majority and the minority report. It is the Government's view that the advantages of the majority report recommendation are countered by the disadvantages. In particular:
.importantly, as was noted by both the majority and the minority reports, the proposed system would reduce safeguards for residents' care;

.most homes use contract services, the cost of which would have to be divided into labour and non-labour components. This would require the Government to validate both labour and non-labour costs incurred by contractors, as well as labour costs incurred by nursing home proprietors. Currently only labour costs incurred by proprietors need to be validated. Therefore as well as simplifying some aspects this would also add complexity;

.while the proposed system would make it easier for nursing homes to use staff part-time on SAM (infrastructure funding including profit) and part-time on CAM (care funding), it would make it harder to share SAM staff between the nursing home and an attached hostel or other care facility;

.as was noted in the majority report the proposed system would actually reduce the incentives for efficiency, since efficiency savings in labour, a large component of SAM, would reduce profitability; and

.the change would require that the amount of SAM be split into SAM labour and SAM non-labour, in a situation where the Government is unlikely to have reliable information on which to base the split, and where a "wrong" decision could substantially affect the viability of many homes. Even a "correct" decision would cause considerable disruption, since it would provide significantly less funding than many homes currently use for non-labour costs, and significantly more than many other homes use.
The Government does not therefore propose to adopt the recommendation of the majority report.
However, following Professor Gregory's second report, the Government is considering more relevant changes to nursing home funding arrangements.

para.emphasis: Recommendation 7: Consultation with the Nursing Home Industry

speech.para: That the Department of Human Services and Health improve its consultative mechanisms with the industry in general and, in particular, consult widely with the industry and industry organisations in the formulation of Departmental circulars.
The Government supports this recommendation. The Aged Care Program is currently developing a new approach in the way information is disseminated to the nursing home industry.

A consultant who is a communications and information expert is helping improve the clarity and usefulness of aged care information. An information strategy has been developed after extensive consultation with a wide range of industry players.
A key component of the strategy is consultation with industry, through peak bodies and editorial groups of proprietors and senior nursing staff in the development of circulars and other information.

para.emphasis: Recommendation 8: Information to the Nursing Home Industry

speech.para: That the Department of Human Services and Health in future distribute Departmental circulars to both proprietors of nursing homes and Directors of Nursing to improve the overall access to information.

The Government supports this recommendation. The Department is currently developing a Nursing Home Manual which draws together all information needed to understand Government requirements in operating a nursing home. This will be finalised and sent to all homes in March 1995. Two copies will be sent free to each home with the intention of ensuring the proprietor and Director of Nursing have access to the information. This material will be available to prospective new entrants to the industry.

The format of Circulars will change once the Nursing Home Manual has been distributed. Circulars will become cover sheets detailing the target audience, summary, action required and replacement instructions for the Nursing Home Manual. Two copies of the Circular, together with the replacement pages for the Manual, will be sent to each home.

That the Department of Human Services and Health ensure that the NH20 form or documentation on the structure and format of the form is made available to nursing homes at least one month prior to the beginning of each financial year.

The Government agrees in principle with the recommendation. The NH20 is the form which allows the Department to reconcile homes' yearly acquittable expenditure. Changes in the NH20 from year to year are largely the result of policy changes including changes from the Budget. There may be times when changes will occur during a financial year which must be reflected in the NH20.
That nursing home organisations encourage the expansion of training initiatives for nursing home proprietors, especially in the areas of financial and general managerial skills.

The Government supports this recommendation. The program's quality assurance strategy is both an underlying philosophy and a management approach for ensuring that quality outcomes are achieved. The Department's strategy has as an objective informing proprietors of their requirements in receiving nursing home benefits. The nursing home funding manual and revised validation documentation are examples of Departmental initiatives in this area.

The Department will be providing support to nursing homes whenever there are changes to the nursing home program. Information seminars on changes to the funding arrangements and the nursing home funding manual are planned for July 1995.
The Department agrees that nursing home industry associations could usefully review their role in maximising the competence of small business operators.

talk.start.para: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. Senator Crowley called a colleague of mine `gross'. Can I get a ruling from you as to whether that can be regarded as an unparliamentary term and whether Senator Crowley can be asked to withdraw it?

para.tab:
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McKiernan)
—Order! I believe it is unparliamentary and would ask the minister to withdraw.

talk.start.para: —I withdraw the remark about the senator; I will re-apply it to his comments. I seek leave to move a motion.

para.tab: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —I move:

para.tab: That the Senate take note of the document.

talk.start.para: —I welcome the government's response to the report of the Senate's Community Affairs References Committee on the validation of CAM and SAM funding to nursing homes. Validation has been a problem for a long time. The validation process, particularly the delays on the part of the Department of Human Services and Health, have been criticised by all sectors of the nursing home industry—proprietors and their industry representatives.

para.tab: The coalition has raised concerns about this issue on numerous occasions. I have spoken about it many times in this chamber. The Auditor-General has tabled a damning report on validations, highlighting some of the systematic problems in this validation process. When it was obvious that the situation was reaching crisis point and the government was doing nothing to rectify the situation, the coalition moved a motion to have the validation of CAM and SAM funding of nursing homes referred to a Senate committee for inquiry. That was on 30 September 1993. The report of that committee was tabled on 16 November 1994. Today we are discussing the government's response to that report.

Throughout all this period, the Department of Human Services and Health continued to be criticised for delays in the validation process. Even after the department realised in 1990 that there was an urgent need to speed up the validation process, it took another four years for all the 1986-87 data to be processed.

In her response, the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) emphasises the importance of validation as an accountability program which helps protect frail elderly nursing home residents by checking the funds allocated to nursing homes to care for residents and to make sure that they are actually spent on the care of those residents. This view is supported by the Auditor-General and is a view with which the coalition concurs.

Before I deal with the government's response to each recommendation, I would like to say that the minister misrepresents the situation when she says in her covering letter to the report that `all of the 1986-87 validations are completed'. I believe that that statement is not correct. When the Auditor-General brought out his report, it indicated that a number of the validations for that period had not been completed. In addition, in estimates committees only a few weeks ago, we asked the department again. We did not get an absolutely clear answer.

It would appear that the validations have been done—that is, the validators have been there—but I am not absolutely sure whether all the exit interviews have been done and all the nursing homes have been told whether they owe money as a result of that validation process. I am sure that Senator Woods will speak about a number of cases which he has been alerted to where that process has not been completed. I would like the minister to be more clear when she addresses this issue. If she wants to say that the 1986-87 validations have been completed in the sense that the validators have been into the nursing homes, that is fine; let her say that. But if she means that they have been completed in the sense that all the nursing homes know exactly where they stand in terms of the amount of money they owe for that period, there is some doubt about that. I would really like to see it clarified.

The committee recommended that the Department of Human Services and Health provide a detailed schedule to the committee outlining its proposed program for completing outstanding validations. The government has admitted that it is unacceptable that there should be such delays in the validation process and that to complete the outstanding validations—there were 5,000 of them at the beginning of 1994-95—it will adopt a risk management approach to scheduling and conducting validations.

This is not before time. One can only ask why it has taken a Senate committee report for the government to accept responsibility for the debacle of this area of administration and to take some action to rectify it. It is just ridiculous to expect that a business should have to wait for years before it knows whether it owes money to the department. It impinges on how it engages in financial planning. Another problem with validations is that nursing homes could be repeating the same mistake, some of them unwittingly and some, albeit few of them, wittingly. Some of them were repeating the error. If they were not validated, they could continue to do that for ensuing years.
