Another two recommendations of the committee are that the Department of Human Services and Health improve its training program for validators to ensure an optimum level of consistency in the validation process and that the validators should have formal accountancy qualifications or other appropriate training. The government's response is that it agrees in principle that the validators should have training. In 1992-93, only 50 per cent of the validators had appropriate formal training. In 1994-95, 60 per cent of people have formal qualifications. It is obvious to me and some of my colleagues on this side of the chamber that there are problems in the area of training and the qualifications of validators. It has taken endless criticism, a Senate inquiry and a critical Auditor-General report before the government would even listen, let alone take any action.

Another recommendation made was that the Department of Human Services and Health publish a document, expunged of confidential internal departmental information, that would provide guidance to nursing homes on the validation process, that this should be widely distributed and should form the basis of validations for that year. So the document is issued and then you would refer to the validations for that year in the relevant document.

What was happening was that the goalposts kept changing. There were guidelines and the nursing homes carried out their business on the basis of those guidelines. Then, when the department got a bit more experience with the system, it changed the guidelines and validated the back years on the basis of the new guidelines.

You cannot actually do that. That is unfair. The guidelines were not clear. I believe that many of the nursing homes were not fully informed. It may have been an error on their part, but the department could have been more pro-active in ensuring that the nursing homes were very clear about what constituted CAM activities and what constituted SAM activities. There were enormous complaints about that. Hopefully, there will be very clear directions and those problems will be overcome as a result of the government responding to that recommendation.

One of the other recommendations was that the government introduce a funding system for nursing homes based on a system of acquitting labour costs and providing a non-acquittable grant for non-labour costs based broadly on the system proposed in option 2 of the Gregory report entitled
Review of the structure of nursing home funding arrangements: stage 1.
Of course the government would not agree to this. There was a minority report. We argue that the government ought to take these recommendations into serious consideration. I ask the government to look at it again because I do not think that the minister's response is adequate.

Another recommendation was that the Department of Human Services and Health improve its consultative mechanisms within the industry in general, and in particular consult widely with the industry and industry organisations in the formulation of departmental circulars. This recommendation lies at the very heart of so many of the criticisms of the validation process. I am glad that the government has come to recognise this, even though it is very late in the day. A constant criticism on the part of proprietors and industry bodies has been the failure of the department to consult, the plethora of circulars and the lack of appropriate communication.

Another recommendation was that the Department of Human Services and Health in future distribute departmental circulars to both proprietors of nursing homes and to directors of nursing to improve the overall access to information—a very simple thing. If it had actually talked to the industry, it would have found out that this would have made things easier.

Given the number of circulars, and given that nursing homes are busy looking after their residents rather than doing unnecessary administration, it is absolutely important for the director of nursing and for the management to have a copy of those circulars. It is going to do this in a form that is able to be put into loose-leaf folders so that the circulars can be kept in some sort of order.

Recommendation 9 was that the Department of Human Services and Health ensure that the NH20 form or documentation on the structure and format of the form is made available to nursing homes at least one month prior to the beginning of each financial year. Nursing homes were gathering data, then getting the form and having to try to make their data fit the form. There seemed to be no good reason given to us on the committee why that form could not be given out as the year began. The government has agreed to that. One of the other areas of recommendation was that there be more adequate training for nursing home staff.
(Time expired)

speech.speaker: Denman Sen K.J.

talk.start.para: —As a member of the Senate Community Affairs References Committee on CAM and SAM funding to nursing homes, and in particular as one of four signatories to the dissenting report disagreeing with the majority report recommendation 6, I have a few matters to raise. The dissenting report contains the crux of the reason why we as a government cannot agree to recommendation 6 of the report.

para.tab: The government is committed to both the protection of frail aged residents of nursing homes and to a streamlined and efficient administration and regulation system. The government is very concerned that this balance be maintained. It is imperative that the scales not fall to one side. It is a true balancing act that would be destroyed if recommendation 6 were adopted. I am happy to say it will not be, but in my view the recommendation should not have been made in the first place. It defied commonsense.

The dissenting report is about achieving a balance. In the view of the government, together with Senator Lees, the status quo should remain subject to better and more relevant changes being made to nursing home funding that is more sophisticated and fairer than option 2 supported under recommendation 6.

Professor Gregory's first report on the structure of nursing home funding noted that option 2 would minimise flexibility and profitability for nursing homes. It should be made clear to this chamber that, in response to Professor Gregory's second report, changes will be considered. But I can assure you that any changes that are mooted will not be at the expense of care as supported by the majority report. The reason the status quo should remain is that the current standards monitoring system would fail as a tool under option 2 to adequately ensure the same quality of care that now exists.

What higher purpose could be met but that the funding be directly linked to the care that is provided by nursing homes, but the opposition wants to put that at risk. The risk of adopting a funding system based on acquitting labour costs and providing a non-acquittable grant for non-labour costs based on option 2 of the Gregory report has in my view spoiled what was a very constructive and worthy report.

talk.start.para: —I raise a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. The standing orders clearly provide that senators should not read their speeches in this house. Clearly, Senator Denman is reading this word for word.
—I am reading from copious notes.
—It is clearly not the case. Clearly, there is a point of order against Senator Denman being allowed to read her speech verbatim.

para.tab:
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Calvert)
—I believe that Senator Denman was reading from copious notes, and that is quite allowable under the standing orders.

talk.start.para: —Just like your lot do, goose.
—I raise a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. I suggest you ask Senator Burns to withdraw that last remark.
—I am sorry. I did not hear what he said. If it was unparliamentary, I would ask you to withdraw.
—What did I say?
—He clearly said `goose'.
—If you would withdraw the comment it would make the running of the chamber a little bit easier.
—To accommodate your wishes, I will withdraw.

—It is with much pride that I can say that no major systematic problems exist with the validation program. The problem is that such a clean bill of health of this program could be placed at risk with a reduction of residents' care. In fact, the changes proposed could mean the amount of SAM, split into SAM labour and SAM non-labour, could seriously put in jeopardy the future viability of homes. The government would not be in a position to adequately decide on which factors the base should be split.

para.tab: What also puzzles me is that the opposition is always harking on about incentives for efficiency in funding programs across a myriad of areas, yet recommendation 6 would actually reduce the incentives for efficiency since efficiency savings in labour, a large component of SAM, would reduce profitability.

The opposition is also on about reducing the complexity of paperwork requirements. Yet with recommendation 6 and the adoption of option 2 of the Gregory report, you run the risk of a net gain in complexity. Currently, only labour costs need to be validated. Under the majority proposal, the government would be required to validate both the labour and the non-labour costs incurred by contractors as well as labour costs incurred by nursing home proprietors.

It is conceded by the government that improvements could be made with more relevant changes to nursing home funding arrangements. This is conceded by the minister. But that which is proposed by the majority is not the correct manner in which to do that. It must be stressed that validation is an essential process of providing assurance that care is being provided to the frail aged residents of nursing homes in the quality intended. I do not just say that—it is also contained in the efficiency audit by the Auditor-General, and I read from the report:

speech.para: The risk to the Commonwealth if validation does not occur is that nursing and personal care will not be available to residents of nursing homes when required.

talk.start.para: —I intended to use my copious notes as well. I rise to speak on the government's response to the CAM-SAM report of the Community Affairs References Committee. I welcome the government's acceptance of all but one of the recommendations of that committee. The one recommendation which has not been accepted is recommendation 6, which relates to our restructuring of the CAM-SAM system.

para.tab:
It is very sad because this is recommended by the government's own report, the Gregory report, where there is a recognition of the structural difficulties that the CAM-SAM system imposes upon directors of nursing, staff and proprietors in the nursing home industry. It is an arbitrary definition which leads to excess bureaucracy, which leads to time wasting, which leads to red tape and essentially diverts resources and funds which can be better used for the care of patients in determining whether in fact a particular task falls on one side or other of the arbitrary CAM-SAM boundary.
This is one of the biggest wastes of time in the nursing home industry.

Senator Denman has raised a question of care. To all of us care is paramount. On our side, we believe that the issue of care would be enhanced by removing the waste of resources utilised in adapting to a CAM-SAM boundary which changes whenever the government bureaucrats decide it should be changed. The goal posts are changed regularly, and that is entirely inappropriate and makes life very difficult for providers of care in the nursing home industry.

Gregory's option would have created flexibility which would have meant that there would be a more efficient use of resources not only generally but in particular in terms of those small nursing homes where multiskilling is vitally important. It is crazy that an employee who takes food from the kitchen through to a patient somewhere along that journey changes from being a CAM funded employee to being a SAM funded employee. This is a particular problem for small nursing homes. The Gregory option which we supported would have increased efficiency, reduced bureaucracy and red tape, and would have led to a better caring environment for those residents.

The artificiality of a CAM-SAM structure is something which surely should be got rid of. I wonder why the commission's reports are ignored the way the Gregory reports are ignored by the government. What is the point in commissioning reports if they are then ignored? The SAM funding should be reviewed, as is recommended in the Gregory report, but the government has no initiative, no purpose in terms of improving the quality of care offered to residents in nursing homes.

Clearly, the increase in funding recommended by Gregory should be put in place as a matter of urgency. Yet the government really ignores a whole raft of reports. There have been two Gregory reports, there is a report by the Auditor-General, a report by the Ombudsman, the Keys report, and every single one of these reports is critical of the government in one way or another. Yet the government still does not fix up the problem.

It is an absolute debacle that the government allows a structure like this, an inefficient structure, to continue. The problem is that the people who pay the price for this inefficient structure are not the proprietors or the staff so much as the residents in the nursing homes. It is care that suffers because time and resources are wasted in terms of looking after the requirements of the bureaucracy.

To say that care would suffer under a changed CAM-SAM system is entirely inappropriate. The inspection system in the nursing home industry is probably greater than any other single industry. That in itself would take care of the importance of caring for the residents in their system. There are state and Commonwealth inspection teams coming out of your ears. I have no doubt at all that the care aspect, vitally important to everybody in the industry, is vitally crucial.

I should point out that there are inaccuracies in the report. The point saying that validations from 1986-87 have been completed is absolutely wrong. There are a list of eight or nine nursing homes that I am aware of where the validations have not been completed. The changes in the CAM structure have not been defined as has been promised by the department, neither has a timetable been proffered.
Debate interrupted.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Calvert)
—Order! It being 7.20 p.m., I propose the question:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

speech.speaker: Herron Sen J.

talk.start.para: —I have been in abject terror only once in my life and that was when I was in Rwanda. My life was saved by one thing and one thing only. I want to show you what saved me.
—It is unparliamentary not to have on a collar and tie.

—I have a jacket on. It was the insignia that I have proudly on my chest. I wear it as a badge of honour, and I am proud to be associated with CARE Australia. My security was the badge that I have on my chest and it saved me on many occasions. I was absolutely appalled to see the attack made on this wonderful organisation by the
Sunday
program and Channel 9 last Sunday. I want to refute some of those allegations because I have had time to find out what they were about.

para.tab:
I was held up in Rwanda itself with a gun pointed at me because a vehicle broke down. It was a vehicle that we had purchased from an east German manufacturer, and it is relevant to the allegations that were made on the
Sunday
program. What were those allegations? The first allegation was that there was fraudulent behaviour and misrepresentation. Most of the former employees who made allegations of this type were not in positions where they would know the full facts.

In other cases, they were completely unaware of the difficulties of field operations of the type that were undertaken and those field operations were governed by strict rules. Organisations such as the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau and the office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees governed those actions. There was another allegation that there was an attempt to bribe the President of Kenya. In several cases set out by the
Sunday
program, the existence of contract arrangements and negotiated budgets was ignored, as were the cases of acquittal.

Who made those allegations on that program? There was one Julian Fidge. I have before me a document signed by my friends who were with me at the time, and I left a month earlier than they did, and he followed me on. It states:

speech.para: We the undersigned employees of CARE Australia approve of and appreciate the decision of management to remove Julian Fidge from its operations in Zaire. We feel that his behaviour was unpredictable, unsafe and showed an unwillingness to work as part of a team. We would be unwilling to continue our work in Zaire with him as part of our team.
He was there seven days and then Channel 9 got him to appear on its program as an authority—seven days in the Kitale camp.

para.tab: The same Mr Fidge took an action and his case was heard on 11 October 1993. He was dismissed as an employee of the Caulfield pharmacy. The judgment of the Employee Relations Commission was that the pharmacy was entitled not to re-employ him, and why not—because they found that he acted unprofessionally and out of his area of expertise as a pharmacist. He lost the case—the man that Channel 9 produced as its expert. After seven to 10 days—I think he was there some days in Nairobi and they redeployed him there—that is the man who is the expert for Channel 9. It does not say so much about Fidge himself, but it says a lot about Channel 9. These are the experts.

Another man who made allegations is a Mr Mitchell. Mitchell lied about a photograph that was fabricated. I am not sure who fabricated it but it was a fabricated photograph. It is a paste-up that can be seen when you analyse the material. Mitchell said in the document:

speech.para: In the ten convoys that I took part in and delivered some 100 tonnes of aid it was taken where it was needed and I thank CARE for putting me in charge of doing it. I would like to return to work for CARE again.

He was the man who lied about that photograph. It is enormously difficult for aid organisations to screen people who ring them. When I rang, there were 2,000 calls coming in. CARE was in a desperate situation and had to accept people at face value. Another person who made an allegation on that program was Alma Lovecic. I have a letter before me from the Australian-Bosnian Herzegovinian Community Association that says:

Within Sydney's Bosnian community Ms Lovecic has a reputation as a self-centred personality who divided the community, always for the sake of importance of her personal role in the community. Not only has she divided the community but she managed to destroy some opportunities to gather large quantities of medicines and money for Bosnian civilians here locally.
They are the three experts. The other allegations were four years old and were investigated by AIDAB and found to be incorrect.

para.tab: I come back to another allegation; and that was in relation to the trucks. Funds raised through the pursuit program have helped tremendously in the expansion of the existing CARE non-government organisation dedicated trucking fleet. What happened was that the funds raised were insufficient to buy trucks. As I mentioned at the very beginning, it was an impossibility to ship trucks over. It was with the agreement of the board of governors that that money was spent on another purpose.

Staff have no knowledge of auditing and accounting procedures. It is not their role. I have not the faintest idea. I was grateful for the provision of supplies in the area I was in and for the opportunity to deliver the care that we were trying to deliver to the thousands who came up every day. A group of six of us attended to between 800 and 1,200 people, as well as 1,200 children; 300 of them with dysentery, AIDS, diarrhoea, tuberculosis and everything else.

Mr President, I think I have demonstrated to you the fact that the witnesses Channel 9 relied upon were not witnesses of credibility. CARE Australia believes that the
Sunday
program was biased and unprofessional. The objections are that it gave inadequate opportunity for CARE to respond; it would not allow CARE to go live; it did not check its facts and it failed to become familiar with the business issues involved in aid delivery and negotiated contracts.

I am proud to announce that CARE Australia is suing Channel 9—and I hope that it sues it to its boots; because that program has defamed one of the most wonderful organisations that exists in this community, an organisation that is overwhelmingly supported by Australians throughout the community. That program maligned the Australian director and a former Prime Minister. Anybody who could impugn the motives of Malcolm Fraser or Ian Harris, the Director of CARE Australia, deserves the utmost condemnation.

I hope that legal action is successful and I hope it will teach the
Sunday
program the lesson that it must never do such a thing again because of the damage it does to all non-government organisations and aid organisations in Australia. I conclude my remarks by thanking CARE Australia for giving me the opportunity to take part in an event that has changed my life.

speech.speaker: Woodley Sen J.

talk.start.para:
—Tonight, I wish to raise the matter of Eastlink, which is a proposed high voltage powerline between the Gatton region west of Brisbane and the Armidale area in northern New South Wales. The powerline will be around 400 kilometres in length and is intended to be part of a national electricity grid connecting the power systems of the two states. The imminent construction of an enormous electric powerline, with the inherent consequence of enabling increased electricity consumption, is extremely relevant, given the current agonising of the federal government over how it is going to live up to its commitment to significantly reduce greenhouse gas emissions. Senators will probably be aware that I have placed on the
Notice Paper
proposed terms of reference for an inquiry into the Eastlink proposal. I have sent that to the Economics References Committee for consideration.

para.tab: As a Democrat senator for Queensland, I have received many expressions of great concern about various aspects of Eastlink. Australian Democrat members at the community level in these areas have also had many people approach them to voice their disquiet. These concerns have come from people all throughout the regions surrounding the corridor of the powerline in Queensland, from Gatton and Laidley to Allora, Warwick and Stanthorpe. Similar concerns have been expressed to me by residents over the border in places such as Armidale and many other small rural communities in the Eastlink path. As an example, one submission from residents of Boonah and the surrounding towns of Kalbar and Aratula detailed a wide variety of concerns about Eastlink. It contains over 1,200 signatures from people objecting to the powerline.

The Senate this week received petitions from over 2,000 people from areas such as those I have mentioned, all asking for a Senate inquiry. For the benefit of the Senate, I will outline some of the concerns expressed by those who have signed the petition. The petitioners point out that Eastlink is contrary to a recommendation of a 1992 report of the Senate's industry, science and technology committee. After the changes made by the Senate last year, this committee no longer exists and the area has been taken up by the Economics References Committee, which is why I proposed that the matter be considered by that committee.

talk.start.para: —A very worthy committee.

—It certainly is, Senator Panizza. The people who signed the petition are also concerned that there have been no proper comparisons made of other options for meeting future energy needs or of the impacts on rural productivity, economic, environmental, health, development or lifestyle issues. The petitioners also voiced a widespread concern at the complete absence of any meaningful consultation. Unfortunately, Eastlink is not the only project in Queensland about which this could be said.

para.tab: Perhaps most disconcerting of all is the possibility that this powerline will be only the start. I have been informed that a Queensland Electricity Commission representative has told the deputy mayor of the Stanthorpe shire that a second line will be needed within five to 10 years.

I know that the Liberal Party member for Groom, Mr Bill Taylor, and the National Party member for Maranoa, Mr Bruce Scott, have also received many expressions of concern from their constituents, and they are supportive of this Senate inquiry. Mr Scott spoke on Eastlink in the other chamber earlier this week, as did Mr Taylor, and I understand that other coalition senators, Senator Boswell and Senator Herron, have been approached by concerned residents. My hope is that all senators from all parties will recognise the need for an inquiry at least. Concern from residents has been sufficient for the Leader of the Opposition in Queensland, Mr Borbidge, who is from the National Party, to state that under a coalition government there will be no Eastlink, and that any land acquired by the state government would be given back to the people at no cost to those people.

Whilst I welcome the concerns expressed by Queensland members of the coalition, it should be pointed out that it is a coalition government in New South Wales which is pushing for Eastlink to go ahead. So there is some conflict there. The Senate may also be interested to know that former Queensland Premier Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen has come out strongly against Eastlink.

talk.start.para: —For what reason?

—You will have to ask Joh. I must say that I would have thought he would at least approve of the Goss government's consultation techniques, having pioneered some of those techniques during his own time in office. I will leave senators to judge for themselves whether Sir Joh's stance strengthens or hinders the credibility of such a viewpoint, but I am very pleased—and I give testimony here tonight—that, after living in Queensland for most of my life, I have found something about which Joh and I agree. Perhaps this is Blessed Mary MacKillop's second miracle. Anyway, I place that on record.

para.tab: It is arguable that, given the right circumstances, sharing power, as in the Eastlink proposal, can reduce the need to duplicate power generation infrastructure. This can provide major savings in infrastructure costs and in reducing consumption rates of fossil fuels and levels of atmospheric pollution, including greenhouse gas emissions. It is, however, far from clear that Eastlink fits the bill in this regard, or that other possible alternatives to constructing the powerline have been fully explored.
I am not convinced that adequate consideration has been given to all aspects of Eastlink; and, more importantly, those residents who will be directly affected are also far from

speech.para: convinced. It is unfortunate that so often state governments do not give adequate consideration to the people they are meant to serve. As Eastlink covers two states, and is intended to be part of the national electricity grid, it is certainly appropriate for the Senate to examine the proposal. I hope that when my motion comes before the Senate next Wednesday all senators will join the Democrats in giving their support.

speech.speaker: Baume Sen M.E.

talk.start.para: —Today the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) surprised us all with a sudden burst of integrity that enabled him to repudiate and condemn the dishonest election tactics of the Australian Labor Party relating to preferences for independent candidates in the recent Australian Capital Territory election.

para.tab: While still imbued with this unusual, but politically convenient, spirit of integrity, the Prime Minister might also repudiate the dishonest and devious device used to protect his then half owned piggery company from prosecution for polluting the upper reaches of the Scone water supply in August 1993, as I outlined earlier today.

It is astonishing that Mr Keating has not, at any stage, apologised for, expressed any regret over or expressed any condemnation or mild criticism of the actions of his piggery group while he was its half owner. All he has said is, `Look, I was not in charge of running it. It is basically not my fault.' There was not one word of apology; not one word of condemnation; and not even mild criticism.

The actions of this company, while he half owned it, ranged from multiple breaches of the Australian Securities Commission's recommendations relating to its reporting rules to continual breaches of anti-pollution laws. I now ask Mr Keating—I know it is a waste of time, but I nonetheless do it—whether or not he supports the dishonest conspiracy his piggery group entered into with the Danish multinational company that has enabled him to escape the ignominy of his half owned company being found guilty of a pollution offence. As I said earlier today—I did not get a chance to complete it—the report of the New South Wales Environment Protection Authority revealed that:

speech.para: . . . on the morning of the court case. . . Brown and Hatton—
that was Mr Keating's half owned company—
lawyers told the EPA that Brown and Hatton Group Pty Ltd had transferred the piggery and its assets to Hunter Valley Piggeries in May 1993.
The transfer has never been lodged with the Land Titles Office.
The EPA release then went on to state:
The prosecution could be brought only against the company which operated the piggery at the time of the pollution incidents on site. Since this was not Brown and Hatton Group Pty Ltd—
despite the fact that this was the only name on the register—
the charges could not proceed.

I might add that not only was that the name on the register, but also payments to contractors working in the piggery had been provided by the Brown and Hatton Group—that is, of those contractors who were paid on time. Applications to expand which were made to the local council developmental authority were also in that name. In none of the activities—for example, before the New South Wales government commission of inquiry into proposed expansion, payments to contractors or development applications—was the name `Hunter Valley Piggery Pty Ltd' ever used.

para.tab: Dr Shepherd from the EPA said that part of the reason legal action was commenced was to ensure that the environmental performance of the existing piggery was upgraded, particularly with regard to waste water treatment and effluent irrigation. No wonder it needed to be upgraded because the piggery itself had admitted in front of the commission of inquiry that there were frequent breaches of the pollution laws as the arrangements were inadequate. Dr Shepherd went on:

speech.para: We will now be issuing legal notices to require the operators of the piggery to carry out these improvements designed to protect the local environment.
The current operator can expect that our requirements will be precisely defined and the time frame for compliance will be closely monitored . . .

Legal action will be considered if any pollution incidents are detected in future. Given recent events at the site, we would not exclude legal action against any individuals involved with such pollution incidents.

The legal action was for breaches—and I do not say `alleged breaches'; I say `breaches' because they were never at any stage disputed—of 8B(1) of the Environmental Offences and Penalties Act 1989 by virtue of the provisions of section 16(1) of the Clean Waters Act 1970.

para.tab: I understand that the pigs in this piggery are housed in 15 sheds. Their effluent is collected underneath the sheds in trenches where it is discharged to the waste water treatment system. The solid and liquid pig waste is flushed into two separate but identical systems that screen solids and then direct liquids to primary treating ponds, and thence by gravity to irrigation ponds, whence it is irrigated onto other areas of the property.

I have been informed that management of these systems is poor. There have been a number of instances where effluent has run off the property and polluted local water courses. The disposal of effluent and the generation of odour from the premises have created constant complaints from residents and action groups, principally in regard to odour. But I have been informed by the New South Wales government that the piggery is not controlled by any pollution control, licence or approval. It has been able to get away with this because the piggery commenced operation years before these requirements were introduced; in other words, there were prior use arrangements.

While a half owner of this company, our Prime Minister was quite happy for it to have inadequate, inappropriate, improper pollution arrangements in place, without making any attempt to fix them during the three years he was its half owner. What a hypocrite, that this man should stand up and claim to be the leader of a government which has strong concerns about pollution!

One incident occurred on 10 August 1993 when excessive irrigation had led to effluent of fairly high BOD and nutrient levels escaping the property. The detailed facts are that the office of the EPA received a phone call from the Scone-Parkville environmental watch group—which, as I say, I commend strongly for the way it has consistently pointed out the continuing pollution from Mr Keating's then half owned company—that reported that red effluent was coming down a gully leading from an irrigation paddock at Parkville piggery and running into a property owned by a Mr Dick Smith.

By the way, the effluent flow on analysis showed BOD of 120 mg/l, ammonia of 130 mg/l and Ph—phosphorus, I suppose—of 7.9. The effluent flow was then followed upstream to a hinge joint fence line on the western boundary of a paddock that the piggery uses to dispose of effluent by spray irrigation. Effluent was coming out of a pool of effluent at the southern end of a rough bank system running along the fence line. The pools of effluent and the soggy ground led to an irrigation spray jet located in the general nor'-nor'-east direction. The irrigation spray was not in operation at that time, but the extent of the spray impact circle around the spray jet could clearly be seen. Further investigation determined that there were no other possible sources of pollution.

Another incident occurred during an unplanned visit to the piggery and again revealed poor management of the waste water treatment system and high nutrient run-off. This was on 19 October 1993 when Commissioner Cleland had requested that the EPA take a water sample. They saw that the northern gully was running with mid-brown coloured water and the middle and southern gullies were running with clear water. Clear details of continuing environmental problems.

A local environment watch group was formed through the concerns of local residents over the impacts and discomfort of odours and discharges of effluent emanating from the Parkville piggery. In the seven months preceding this offence, EPA officers attended the piggery on three occasions to take water samples following complaints of effluent run-off. It seems to me that this is just a non-stop situation where there is contempt for the law.

The offences must be considered in light of the history of the piggery. They are aggravated having regard to the history and the difficulties of getting the piggery to apply proper management practices. Despite numerous visits, it has proven difficult to get management to do anything. To some extent, this situation has not been helped by the commission of inquiry which has tended to put active measures on hold. However, the piggery is still operating and still causing problems and will continue to do so, whether or not the joint venture with Danpork goes ahead.
(Time expired)

speech.speaker: Abetz Sen E.

talk.start.para: —My contribution to the adjournment debate tonight is to discuss the decision of the full bench of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission to overturn the decision of Commissioner Hodder of December 1994. Commissioner Hodder's decision ordered that the small non-union company Asahi Diamond Industrial Australia Pty Ltd `shall negotiate in good faith' with the Automotive, Food, Metal and Engineering Union. That order was made despite the fact that, firstly, not a single one of Asahi's employees belonged to a union, nor did they want to belong; secondly, the employees were not interested in negotiating an agreement because they were satisfied with their present arrangements; and, thirdly, not a single employee wanted the union to be representing their interests.

para.tab: It was an outrageous decision of Commissioner Hodder. It was made more outrageous by the fact that the decision flowed from an outrageous law. Overnight, the Hodder decision had the potential to destabilise all those highly successful and productive non-unionised companies right around Australia.

For both the unions and the employees, this test case had important principles at stake. On the one hand, employers, particularly those with non-union workplaces, bitterly opposed an enterprise bargaining system that forced them to negotiate with unions. On the other hand, the unions feared a system in which they might be locked out of the non-union sector. Indeed, the ACTU assistant secretary, Tim Pallas, has stated that the non-union sector is `a system that is tantamount to industrial apartheid'. He also said:

speech.para: . . . the ACTU cannot and will not condone as consistent with the accord agreement—
that they struck with the Labor government—
. . . a formalised and collective process for the unionised sector and an unaccountable, informal and unilateralist system for employers should they choose—
the latter system—
as their preferred option.

The full bench decision is really a very big slap in the face to the union movement. The company at the heart of the dispute, Asahi, is a small engineering works that employs about 42 workers under the metal industry award. It is now well known that the employees and the employers of Asahi had come to a union-free agreement on how they wanted to work in order to achieve their mutual interests of improved productivity and higher wages. The enterprise bargaining arrangement which was sealed at Asahi saw employees and employers happy. It was an effective arrangement—that is, until the militant AFMEU foisted itself onto the Asahi company against the explicit wishes of every single employee who worked there.

para.tab: The confusion that subsequently emerged baffled workers, puzzled the employer and perplexed most Australians who followed the case each evening on TV and in the newspapers the following morning. So much publicity was generated about this one small company that Asahi placed large advertisements thanking the many thousands of Australians who lent their support to the company.

It is interesting to note that the Asahi decision comes on top of plans announced earlier this week by Mr Kelty, the Secretary of the ACTU, to expand union membership by 200,000 by the year 1997. It was widely reported at the end of last year that Australian workers were leaving unions in droves because they were failing to meet their members' needs. Indeed, former Labor Senator Jim McClelland is now on record as saying that he believes there is no longer a useful role for trade unions.

Indeed, it appears that workers all around the country agree with that. Australian Bureau of Statistics figures released in December, combined with the ACTU's own figures, display the real extent of the defections from the trade union movement. The ABS labour force figures indicate that since 1988 there has been an overall decline in union membership of approximately seven per cent. That is of course despite a growing population.

The ACTU executive meeting in Melbourne in early December backed up these figures. The meeting in fact was warned that union membership affiliated with the ACTU had fallen over the last year by 400,000, leaving a total of 2.4 million members. Later that same week the New South Wales Labor secretary, Peter Sams, admitted the picture was more grim, with membership closer to two million; that is, union membership affiliated with the ACTU had fallen by 800,000 in a relatively short period.

It is interesting to note that Mr Kelty, in his membership drive, is targeting only a quarter of the membership lost over the past year. The decline in membership really says a lot about the way in which unions are representing Australian workers today. To have the unions complain bitterly that the loss in membership will reduce their power to lobby governments stretches the imagination as to what role the union movement actually plays for its membership.

I am sure most union members would be horrified to think that the only thing unions are concerned about is their grab for power and allowing Bill Kelty to sit around the cabinet table in Canberra. The fact is that unions have been playing the tune for the Australian Labor Party and have been forgetting the workers that they are supposed to represent.

Clearly, the workers are finding that out themselves, and that is why they are leaving, not only in their thousands or tens of thousands but in their hundreds of thousands. Clearly, the desire to conscript new members at Asahi was a significant motive behind the union's actions. It is therefore very rewarding to see that that proposed action by the union failed.

Many unions have consistently failed to meet the needs of employees who are looking for service providers to help them be part of the workplace culture. Trade unions have enjoyed enormous institutional, legal and political privilege within the Australian industrial relations system. Despite that privilege, their membership has been declining.

Since many unions have had a guaranteed role in the system, and automatic membership thanks to compulsory unionism, the incentive to meet employees' needs was of course greatly diminished. I suggest to the ACTU that the only way unions will grow will be when they start listening to their members and meeting their needs.
The Asahi test case decision is very significant because the workers at Asahi rejected union interference in their workplace. Amongst other things, in its conclusion, the full bench said:

speech.para: The commission cannot order a person to negotiate. Such an order is beyond power.

From all the stories I have seen on this particular case, the workers at Asahi were more than happy with the deal they struck with their employer. With militant AMEFU demands, the workers at Asahi are probably relieved that they are not members of a union organisation, that their employer was not forced to negotiate with that union, and that they can continue with the arrangements that they had enjoyed for so many years to the mutual benefit of both the company and the workers.

para.tab: The Chief Executive of the Metal Trades Industry Association, Mr Bert Evans, has said that some 700,000 non-unionised businesses in this country would have become exposed to intrusion by unions had the Hodder decision stood. So it was welcoming to see the decision of the full bench.

Employers have every right to be sceptical about union arguments that unions are necessary, particularly at a time when union membership is rapidly declining. After all, if employers are meeting award or enterprise agreement conditions, and if employees do not want union involvement, I would argue the era that allowed unions to still impose their will has long passed.

debate.sub2.title: Brandy v. Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission

speech.speaker: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

talk.start.para:
—I rise tonight to speak very briefly on two matters which I believe warrant further mention in this place. The first is the imminent release of contaminated water from the Ranger uranium mine down the East Alligator River in Kakadu National Park. I would like to incorporate a short document in
Hansard
.

para.tab: Leave granted.

The document read as follows
—

speech.para: Big Bill Neidji gives his apologies for his absence today. It is not unexpected his not being here. You see he was born in nineteen hundred and twelve. That makes him some 83 years old. For him to travel from Jabiru to Darwin some 300 kilometres would mean no small effort on his part.

para.tab: The mere fact that he is a senior and a most distinguished and respected citizen of this nation, and held in high esteem by equally distinguished visitors from many countries does not automatically grant him the benefits and privileges that most of his age and status would be entitled to. And that sadly, so very few get to enjoy. At 83 years old Bill Neidji knows that he has to fight for his country yet again.

So it is with reluctance that I speak, without him being at my side. Not because I lack the confidence in doing so, but because, perhaps to all of you, only his presence would perhaps validate to you the issue I am about to relate. I assure you however I am under his careful instructions, that I am obligated to do so. His absence does not diminish in any way the message that I carry from him.

Bill Neidji is an Aboriginal Man. By this, I mean, he carries the authority formed by a culture indigenous to the very land that your feet walk on today. His authority has been created and shaped by many decades of obligation, of ceremony and learning from the Old People of many, many generations. His authority has been created by personal actions and deeds and by strength and by teaching, kindness and most of all, by immense dignity. He has written books and spoken many times and been filmed in documentaries, seeking always to educate all others about Aboriginal culture, land and responsibility.

Age does not always guarantee having learned in ones life time, for truly there are some will never learn. But it is plain to all who have ever met Bill Neidji, that he also has the carriage of wisdom and knowledge. He knows and has a love and obligation to his country, for it is in truth, a part of his body.

The authority and values held by Big Bill Neidji should not to be taken lightly. For they are precious and so very important to myself and many, many others. But I fear that perhaps that too often, despite his efforts, these values have been trodden over, clearly misinterpreted by ignorance or with purpose or sometimes dismissed, as just too hard to deal with. They may at first appear too complex to those with English as a first language, but I assure, they are not.

Yes, it is our culture that makes all of us different. There are times when we might react differently in some situations to others or we may even sound different. Cultural differences can sometimes have its comedy and then sadly its tragedies. But men and women of all cultures do have common ground. So Bill Neidji asks of you and I, what is it that we value most of all?

Authority dictates to Big Bill Neidji that he must speak about his country. He is obligated to speak and therefor should not be contained. Today in Kakadu National Park a World Heritage Area, Big Bill is extremely alarmed and concerned deeply about the proposed release of contaminated waters from the ERA mine site that will flood his land.

His authority places little trust in the government nor with science and he is most doubtful that they would have a
proper duty of care
in relation to management of the land he resides on with his family. For they have not learnt as he has. He knows of no scientist or federal government representative who is dependent upon land as food source downstream of a mine release site. He knows of no scientist or government representative who wants to live downstream of the proposed release site.

Yet he is being asked to place his trust in a Science that he knows very little of.
He does not.
A science that relies on Aboriginal knowledge to show them how and why things happen in relation to land management and resources. A Science who with all its cleverness, cannot communicate in either his father's or mother's language. A science that is almost always unintelligible when spoke in English to him. A science that has only monitored information relevant to the area from 20 years ago.

He is also being asked to place his trust in a government decision.
He does not
. He knows of our history and Governments when dealing with Aborigines. He knows what is going on today, he believes it is not a good story. His personal experience of dealing with government has seen inevitably, a NO turns into a yes, right before his eyes. The use of the English language and sometimes the use of government still confound him, when it becomes clear that "it was never the intent, even though it was said".
Big Bill Neidji, Senior Traditional Owner of Gagudju Country Bunitj Man Is asking that you listen to him. To trust him and his authority and the science that he knows.

He knows this, that the proposed release of contaminated waters from rention pond number two is not good for the land and the country. Big Bill Neidji believes it will slowly poison the trees and grass and the food and the earth. He believes it will kill his country. And inevitably him. He speaks for his grandchildren. He speaks for his country he speaks for the families down stream. He asks for you to act responsibly to what you should value most of all. Land and country and its people.
Who in government will heed his words?

talk.start.para: —This document was written by Christine Christophersen on behalf of her uncle, Bill Neidji, senior traditional owner of Gagudju country. The document speaks eloquently of the strong bonds between Aboriginal people and their land. Bill asks us to heed his words when he says that the release of the water will kill his country and, inevitably, him and his people.

para.tab: The second issue is the matter of Brandy v. Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. The Greens (WA) welcome the government's moves to protect the enforcement of human rights in response to the decision of the High Court in Brandy v. Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. We are also gratified that the High Court has handed down such a decision which reinforces one of the few constitutional protections of human rights in Australia, the separation of powers.

The separation of powers embodied in the constitution ensures that non-judicial persons cannot exercise judicial power. The necessity for a separation of powers and the protection of judiciary from arbitrary influence can be seen in the response of Jeff Kennett in Victoria to the victory of the Koori people in the Northcote college case. The Premier has moved to make sure that the decision-makers in such cases are not so independent of the influence of the government or government policy.

As anyone who has any knowledge of constitutional law knows, as a result of the Brandy case the amendments to the Sex Discrimination Act, the Racial Discrimination Act, and the Disability Discrimination Act, which were passed in 1992, have been found to never have been valid. At this point, I seek leave to incorporate the remaining two pages of my notes.
Leave granted.

The speech read as follows
—

speech.para: The premier has moved to make sure that the decision-makers in such cases are not so independent of the influence of the Government or Government policy.

As anyone who has any knowledge of Constitutional Law knows, as a result of the Brandy Case the amendments to the Sex Discrimination Act, Racial Discrimination Act and Disability Discrimination Act which were passed in 1992 have been found to never have been valid.

The Attorney-General has stated that there were 37 determinations which were made between the passage of the amendments and the handing down of the High Court's decision in the Brandy case. It is fortunate that the validity of those amendments was tested at such an early stage before the rights of more people were adversely affected through the passage of the invalid legislation.
It would be easy to attack the government, and its legal advisers, for introducing amendments to these Acts which were so clearly unconstitutional.
However, this is not the point.
What is important is that it is now the responsibility of the government to establish an effective and constitutionally valid mechanism for the protection of Human Rights.

In the short term the government has stated that it will move to amend the relevant legislation to return to the situation to before the 1992 amendments. While there is obviously a need to act rapidly it is important that this only be a temporary measure.

It was the lack of enforcibility of determinations in the pre-1992 Acts which led the government to attempt to create an alternative process, which has subsequently been found to be unconstitutional by the High Court.
Since it is clear that determinations by Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission cannot be used as an enforcement mechanism, a Court mechanism must now be established.

The Public Interest Advocacy Centre in Sydney has advocated the establishment of a "Human Rights Court". Without wishing to pre-empt the recommendations of the Basten Committee, the Greens (WA) would support the establishment of such a Court. This would give Human Rights, and their protection, the status that they require and which have been lacking to date.

Under both the pre and post 1992 schemes, persons whose Human Rights had been infringed could not go directly to the Federal Court for enforcement. They had to go through the conciliation and determination process conducted by HREOC. For many people this would be seen as further barriers to the enforcement of their Human Rights. While HREOC has an admirable record in conciliating disputes, it is essential that any future regime allows people direct access to a court.
We understand the difficulties faced by persons seeking to enforce their Human Rights and the differentials in power and resources between the victims and perpetrators of human rights abuse.
As a consequence the government must, therefore, ensure that the mechanisms in such a court are free from undue formality and legalism.
They must also ensure that there is adequate legal aid and other support for people seeking to protect their Human Rights.
The legislation which this Parliament has enacted to protect Human Rights is a good first step. However, there have never been the necessary enforcement mechanisms put in place.
The government has a wonderful opportunity provided by the Brandy decision to create an effective and powerful mechanism for the protection of Human Rights.
It must not let this opportunity slip.

proctext.para: The following answers to questions were circulated:

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Resources, upon notice, on 5 October 94:

para.tab: (1) Does the Minister agree that a forest: (a) deemed to be of world heritage value by a government agency is of high conservation value; 2 (b) listed on the register of the National Estate is of high conservation value; (c) that provides habitat for endangered or vulnerable species is of high conservation value; (d) identified as wilderness by a government agency is of high conservation value; and (e) identified as old-growth by a government agency is of high conservation value.

(2) With reference to the ABC Lateline program of 12 September 1994 during which the Minister stated that since 1992 when the National Forest Policy Statement was signed, `no old-growth forest of high conservation value has been logged for woodchip', is the Minister aware that old-growth forests: (i) in Tasmania that have been deemed to be of world heritage and wilderness value and are listed on the register of the National Estate are being logged after approval from the Minister in December 1993, (ii) in south-west Western Australia that are of wilderness value and listed on the register of the National Estate are being logged after approval from the Minister in December 1993, (iii) in East Gippsland that are listed on the register of the National Estate are being logged after approval from the Minister in December 1993, (iv) in north-east New South Wales that have been identified as wilderness by the State Government and that contain endangered or vulnerable species listed under the Commonwealth Endangered Species Protection Act 1992 are being logged after approval from the Minister in 1993, and (v) in south-east New South Wales that are of wilderness value, that contain endangered or vulnerable species listed under the Commonwealth Endangered Species Protection Act 1992 and are listed on the register of the National Estate are being logged after approval from the Minister in December 1993.

(3) With reference to the same program during which the Minister stated that `the Australian Heritage Commission, to the best of my knowledge, its advice to previous Ministers has been accepted by those Ministers': (i) is the Minister aware of advice from the Australian Heritage Commission provided in December 1993 to the Minister which stated in relation to the following coupes in the Great Western Tiers National Estate Place: Gunns Kilndried F, C; NFI Lake Sorrel 86H, G, E, D1, C2, C1, B1/B2, A1/A2, that `in the absence of specific knowledge about Aboriginal places, it is recommended that representative areas with a high potential to contain places, or suites of places, that reflect Aboriginal occupation and exploitation of these areas, are excluded from logging until they have been surveyed and their significance assessed in a regional context', and (ii) has logging occurred in 1994 in the above coupes prior to a survey being carried out and regional significance assessed.

(4) Does the Minister share the view of the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner) that `it's just crazy to be assessing the values of old-growth forests while logging them at the same time'.
(5) Is the Minister committed to ensuring that an increase in the downstream processing of woodchips will lead to an equal reduction in woodchip export quotas.

answer.speaker: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

para.tab: (1) The National Forest Policy Statement establishes a co-operative approach between the Commonwealth, State and Territory Governments to identify and protect old-growth forests of high conservation value. The objective is to put in place a comprehensive, adequate and representative reserve system. The Statement acknowledges that some areas of old-growth forest which are not required for the reserve system, will be harvested for some years to come to meet timber needs of the Australian community.

answer.para: As the Prime Minister announced on 2 February 1995, the Commonwealth has put in place a process for assessing the conservation values of the 509 coupes identified as requiring further consideration before logging proceeds. Consistent with this process I have identified 57 coupes which satisfy the criteria for logging to continue. The Government is also considering the release of additional coupes which will be required to avoid stand-downs of forest workers. Coupes to be released are those where forest conservation values do not exist or where those values are well represented in conservation reserves.

para.tab: Remaining coupes will be assessed in accordance with the 8 week assessment process outlined in the Prime Minister's Statement. Export approval will not be granted for woodchips sourced from these coupes unless it is assessed that these coupes would not be required for a comprehensive, adequate and representative reserve system.

(2) Approval for the export of woodchips derived from timber harvested within native forests has followed detailed consideration of the applications to ensure protection of environmental values and included consideration of advice from the Australian Heritage Commission. In approving licences for 1994, the then Minister for Resources, on the advice of the then Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, did not approve export of woodchips from some areas proposed for logging and these were subsequently withdrawn.

(3) Successive Resource Ministers have consulted the Australian Heritage Commission prior to deciding whether to renew annual woodchip export licences. The advice of the Australian Heritage Commission is an integral part of the decision making process. Where there is no feasible and prudent alternative to carrying-out a proposed export woodchip operation that may have an adverse impact on the national estate, the Commonwealth relies upon the advice of the Australian Heritage Commission and State forest management agencies for ways to minimise those adverse impacts.

The Tasmanian Forest Practices Code specifically recognises the need to consult with Aboriginal people in matters of Aboriginal heritage. All areas with a high potential to contain significant Aboriginal sites are surveyed prior to logging by accredited and trained staff. If significant sites are found they are excluded from logging if appropriate.

With respect to the Gunn's Kilndried F, C coupes in the Great Western Tiers region, Forestry Tasmania has advised that these coupes are on the Silver Plains property owned by North Forest Products. An archaeological survey was carried out on the property in June 1992, under the supervision of Forestry Tasmania's Senior Archaeologist and with assistance from the Aboriginal community.
The coupes approved for logging in 1994 are not in or adjacent to any identified Aboriginal heritage sites or sensitive areas. Logging operations in these coupes have therefore proceeded this year.

With respect to the NFI Lake Sorrell coupes Forestry Tasmania has advised that the property is owned by Boral Timber Tasmania. The forests on the property have been logged since the 1950s initially for sawlog only and more recently for sawlog and pulpwood by logging of the previously cutover forest. Virtually all of the property has been logged.

In 1994 logging has continued in coupes 86 C, D, E, G and H under ongoing Timber Harvesting Plans prepared in accordance with the Forest Practices Code. The code includes provisions for the identification and management of cultural heritage during planning and operation of timber harvesting. As part of this process a roadline survey for Aboriginal heritage has been conducted by Boral and nothing found. The areas being harvested are considered to be of low Aboriginal heritage sensitivity.

(4) In the National Forest Policy Statement it is agreed that until assessments are completed forest management agencies will avoid activities that may significantly affect those areas of old-growth forest or wilderness that are likely to have high conservation value. This does not mean that all old-growth forest is to be avoided pending assessment of their values but refers to those areas likely to have high conservation value.

(5) The Government's objective on the export of woodchips was announced by the Prime Minister on 22 December 1994. By the year 2000 the Government will ban the export of woodchips from those areas of Australia's native forests which are not covered by Regional Forest Agreements incorporating a reserve system that comprehensively represents all forest types. The amount of woodchips exported from native forests where there has not been significant progress towards a Regional Forest Agreement will be reduced by about 20 per cent per year to nil by the year 2000.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, upon notice, on 23 January 1995:

para.tab: With reference to the Community Cultural, Recreation and Sporting Facilities Program (CCRSFP) and the terms of agreement between the department and the recipient organisations that stipulates that the final date for submitting claims under the program is 20 May 1995:
(1) What was the specific project approved under this program for the East Maitland Cricket Club.
(2) What claims have been made by the recipients of this particular grant to date.
(3) What work has been reported as being completed under this specific project.
(4) In the outstanding grants document for the CCRSFP 1992-1993 in NSW, the Eastern Suburbs (Maitland) Cricket Club still has $49,000 unspent, what was the total value of the original grant.
(5) Has the Eastern Suburbs (Maitland) Cricket Club notified any alteration to the nature and location of the project to be undertaken with this grant money.

(6) Have the local government authority, the Maitland City Council, and the Tenambit Oval Board approved a development application for certain works to be undertaken at Tenambit Oval with this $49,000 grant.
(7) What other applications for community sporting facilities were received from the Maitland City Council area at the time this grant was awarded.
(8) If the money cannot be spent by 20 May 1995, what will happen to the funds granted to the Eastern Suburbs (Maitland) Cricket Club.
(9) What correspondence has been received from the Member for Paterson (Mr Horne) in relation to this grant and the delay in its expenditure.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

para.tab: (1) A grant of $49,000 was offered to the Eastern Suburbs (Maitland) Cricket Club to assist with the construction of enclosed turf and concrete practice wickets at Metford Oval, Metford.
(2) No claims have been made to date.
(3) My Department is not aware of any work completed to date which may be eligible for reimbursement under the CCRSFP.

(5) Any deliberations regarding a suitable site are a matter for the local Council in the first instance. I understand that the Eastern Suburbs Cricket Club has been negotiating a suitable site with the Maitland City Council. The club advised my Department in writing on 4 October 1994 that problems were being experienced with a proposed site at Melbourne Street, East Maitland. A formal request for a variation has not yet been received.
(6) This is a matter for the Maitland City Council.
(7) Departmental records indicate there were five applications from the Maitland District in the 1992-93 round of the CCRSFP. These were:
Eastern Suburbs (Maitland) Cricket Club
Maitland City Council
Maitland Park Tennis Club Inc.
Walka Water Works Trust Inc.
Maitland Youth Development Unit Inc.

(8) All grant offers not fully claimed by 20 May 1995 will lapse. The use of any funds which remain unspent at the end of the program will be a matter for the Government to determine against Portfolio and budgetary priorities.
(9) The Member for Paterson has written to me on two occasions regarding this grant.
